IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The only effective means of breast cancer prevention in women with inherited BRCA mutations is prophylactic mastectomy, which, while effective, raises issues relating to quality of life and other psychological and physical consequences. The overarching objective of this application is to develop strategies to detect and eliminate pre-malignant cells in breast tissues from high-risk women. To accomplish this goal, we have used state-of- the-art single-cell technologies to detect and isolate subpopulations of breast cells that accumulate in BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutation carriers and propose studies to determine how these subpopulations contribute to tumor development and what causes their accumulation in order to develop strategies to interfere with cancer development in high-risk women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PARP inhibitors comprise the most important new drug class introduced into ovarian cancer practice in the last 25 years. This project will investigate ATR inhibition in preclinical models and in clinical trials as a strategy to reverse mechanisms of acquired resistance and to address those cancers under replication stress that are intrinsically PARP inhibitor-resistant. The work should provide new drug-based approaches designed to improve ovarian cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Behavioral experiments in humans and primates show that novel visual objects motivate behavior by capturing attention and gaze, and promoting the formation of new memories. Abnormalities in novelty seeking are associated with anxiety, depression, anhedonia and autism, but despite the importance of novel objects in our daily life, and the clinical relevance of novelty seeking, we lack an understanding of how primate brain circuits control novelty related behaviors. Our experiments will reveal the neuronal mechanisms of novelty seeking in non-human primates – a fundamental form of motivation that is uniquely dysregulated in many disorders of cognition and mood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Checkpoint blockade monotherapy exhibits only modest activity against ovarian cancer. Building on our ability to identify cancer determinants that can be recognized by the immune system (so-called ‘antigens’) from patient tumors, including from ovarian cancer, that are optimal because they are expressed only on tumor cells (and not normal cells) and are highly immunostimulatory, and based on promising data supporting new cancer vaccination efforts to target these personal tumor antigens that may synergize effectively with checkpoint blockade therapy, this proposal aims to investigate the therapeutic potential and biologic activity of this novel immunotherapy strategy for ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thrombosis is the leading cause of mortality among patients with JAKV617F+ myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs). Although JAKV617F+ endothelial cells are activated in MPN, treatments do not target the vasculature. Using endothelialized microfluidics models to assess endothelial function, we will determine whether reducing JAKV617F+-mediated signaling using JAK-STAT and Gas6-Axl-MERTK inhibitors decreases thrombosis in MPN and thereby establish a mechanistic rationale for novel antithrombotic therapies in MPN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 3 Project Narrative: Based on evidence that the RAS-ERK pathway is activated in a large percentage of ovarian cancers and evidence of efficacy of combined MEK- BCL-2/XL inhibition in (1) preclinical PDX models of chemoresistant high grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSC), (2) preclinical studies showing efficacy of combined MEK and BCL- 2/XL inhibition in Ras mutant tumors, and (3) a Phase 1 clinical trial showing safety and tolerability of combined treatment with trametinib (MEK inhibitor) and navitoclax (BCL-2/XL inhibitor), we hypothesize that combination MEK and BCL- 2/XL inhibition will have activity in refractory/relapsed ovarian cancer. To test this hypothesis, we will carry out a phase II clinical trial to test the efficacy of combined treatment with trametinib and navitoclax in recurrent platinum-resistant and refractory ovarian cancers harboring alterations in Ras and Raf pathway genes along with HGSC and low grade serous RAS wild type cancers . An active and ongoing study, Dana- Farber/Harvard Cancer Center (DF/HCC) Protocol 13-505 (CTEP 9525 supported by U01CA062490, NCT02079740) is a phase 1 study that has tested the combination of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib with the oral BCL-2 XL inhibitor navitoclax. The public health impact of this project includes the development of new therapeutic options for patients with hard to treat recurrent ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – DEVELOPMENTAL RESEARCH PROGRAM The goals of the Developmental Research Program (DRP) are to successfully identify, fund, monitor, and support high risk/high potential pilot projects that take maximum advantage of new research opportunities within the Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center Ovarian Cancer SPORE and to maintain this Program throughout the entire grant term. The success of this Ovarian Cancer SPORE DRP will be dependent upon our ability to engage researchers within and outside of the DF/HCC community who can contribute novel ideas to the diagnosis and treatment of ovarian cancer. Priority will be based upon the novelty of the proposals, evidence to support that the project can be completed within specified timelines and budget proposal, and a proven track record of accomplishment and productivity by the investigator; those projects that have demonstrated great progress and translational research potential will have the potential to become full SPORE Projects but only with the approval of the DF/HCC Ovarian Cancer DRP Executive Committee.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research program will utilize genetic and biophysical approaches to elucidate the organelle- specific roles of membrane lipid components relevant to human health. In the first thrust, the ability of unsaturated lipids to act as viscous and mechanical regulators of mitochondrial respiration will be tested. In the second, the mechanisms by which non-canonical sphingolipids dysregulate endomembrane structure and function will be determined.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  CAREER ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM  The overall goal of the Career Enhancement program (CEP) will be to increase the breadth and  depth of the ovarian cancer translational investigator pool at the DF/HCC and across the US.  We expect to train individuals who will become 2025’s National / International leaders in the  pathobiology, diagnosis, treatment and control of Ovarian Cancers.  The CEP will enhance the impact of the SPORE on the public health of the US population in  four principal ways: 1) The CEP will select and train new ovarian cancer investigators for  translational research; 2) Every candidate selected will be prioritized to require clear  translational impact of their work which can be translated to patients within ovarian cancer within  a 5 year period; 3) the CEP will prioritize gender and ethnic diversity during the selection  process to enhance the breadth of investigators serving the US population in all its diversity; 4)  the CEP is commented to long term mentoring and career development to deliver new faculty  through the early faculty stage and allow them to establish themselves as mature, independent  investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The immune system protects lungs during infections but sometimes an excessive and unchecked immune response can destroy the lungs, resulting in acute lung injury (ALI) or its more severe form referred to as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Macrophages are immune cells which can either enhance inflammation or instead dampen inflammation and bring about the repair the lung, depending on the type of macrophage. The proposed research program is focused on harnessing the plasticity of macrophages to increase their repair function and thereby set the foundations for future treatments to prevent lung damage during infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The cycle of repeated composite-restoration replacements is a pernicious problem―each replacement risks pulpal injury, increased tooth weakness, and eventually, tooth loss. The problem is pervasive—nearly 70% of all composite restorations are replacements for failures. High-risk patients, such as the 4 million U.S. children and more than 100 million adults who do not receive regular dental care, are particularly vulnerable. The leading cause of failure is decay at the interface between the composite and tooth. This interface is initially sealed by an adhesive but the adhesive seal is weak and readily degraded. The proposed project will result in the following patient benefits: 1) substantial reduction in bacteria that infect the tooth margin; 2) ability to repair tooth structure damaged by bacteria, acids, and enzymes; 3) a self-strengthening adhesive that resists degradation; and 4) ~90% reduction in unreacted adhesive that could leach into the tissues of the mouth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emerging field of comparative oncology may provide a novel solution to rare human cancer studies, as genomic resources, reference genomes and non-human model cancer sequencing data are proliferating rapidly. We propose to, for the first time, develop and apply new machine learning methods to jointly analyze and integrate information from hundreds of mammalian genomes to identify pan-mammalian mechanisms of cancer resistance and susceptibility, and apply those insights in human cancers. To disseminate this date to the wider community and catalyze further research we will develop a tumor compendium, portal, and toolkit that will allow other researchers to leverage pan-mammalian comparative genomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Meta-analyses shape clinical recommendations and policy, so it is critical to understand the extent to which their conclusions remain credible given the numerous biases that can affect their constituent studies. The current project will develop statistical methods that help rigorously characterize the credibility of individual meta-analyses by accounting flexibly for multiple biases, and that forecast the results of new studies based on potentially biased meta-analyses. This project will rigorously calibrate confidence in health-relevant conclusions from individual meta- analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: While it was initially believed that only a minority of CRC are driven by inflammation, studies showing that treatment with anti-inflammatory medications may prevent or delay the development of CRC in hereditary and sporadic cases, clearly identify inflammation as a key driver in the development and progression of all types of CRC. Yet, it is still unclear what are the mechanisms that in the complex intestinal environment contribute to the activation of the inflammatory pathways that initiate CRC. Our finding that the downregulation of the complement C3aR down-regulation may be an early event that causes CRC development in human and in our novel mouse model, suggest that identifying the mechanisms linking loss of C3aR to the development of CRC will not only further our understanding of CRC but is highly significant for the prevention of CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Despite decades of research and much progress, certain subtypes of leukemia remain highly resistant to treatment. Our recent work shows that one determinant of the aggressive behavior of leukemia is a protein that regulates post-transcriptional gene expression, insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA binding protein 3 (IGF2BP3). By determining how this protein contributes to leukemia causation and understanding the underlying mechanism, we will define novel diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic approaches in these highly aggressive malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) represents a very serious public health concern: in the United States, both men and women have an approximately 1 in 20 chance of developing CRC during their lifetimes, with 50,000 Americans succumbing to CRC annually. The ability of certain human gut bacteria to produce the genotoxic molecule colibactin has been correlated with incidence of CRC in humans and shown to affect CRC development in mice. This research program will elucidate how colibactin interacts with and damages DNA and will develop strategies for inhibiting colibactin production, providing a greater understanding of colibactin's role in CRC and laying the groundwork for new strategies to prevent and treat cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Persons with HIV (PWH) on antiretroviral therapy have an increasing risk of mortality from cardiovascular disease that is likely multifactorial. Chronic inflammation due to co-infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) alters the memory T cell repertoire and antibody responses and is likely important in the pathogenesis of cardiovascular disease. This proposal focuses on the role of CMV-specific immune cells in the progression of atherosclerotic disease in PWH; aligning with the NIH HIV/AIDS research priorities and NHLBI's mission to investigate newly discovered pathobiological mechanisms important to the onset of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and identify factors that account for differences in health among populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Title: Genetic Studies of Cortex Structure and Development PROJECT NARRATIVE (3 sentences) Dysregulation of cortical development is central to epilepsy, mental deficiency, autism and schizophrenia. Understanding the genetic circuitry controlling the development and function of the cortex is essential to interpret human allele variants in people who have neuropsychiatric disorders. Our results will provide critical information about the genetic control of cortical progenitors and neurons and, once integrated with human genetic information, this will lead to insights into how abnormalities in specific gene networks cause human neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are rare cells within human bone marrow that are responsible both for the life-long replenishment of all blood cell lineages and for the curative effects of bone marrow transplantation. The creation of human induced pluripotent cells holds great promise for cellular regeneration therapies, but we cannot currently instruct these cells to specifically generate HSCs in vitro. The overall goal of this application is to determine the molecular cues and behaviors that instruct HSC fate in the vertebrate embryo and from human pluripotent stem cells such that these events may ultimately be replicated routinely to generate patient- specific HSCs for clinical utility.

PHR: 8. Project Narrative The over-arching theme of this program is to train “comprehensive imaging scientists” in the skills necessary to identify clinically relevant problems and develop techniques to improve the prevention, detection, diagnosis, and treatment of human diseases. Trainees learn the full trajectory of medical imaging, including the application of machine learning methods, and emphasis is placed on experiential learning in clinical environments. The global program outcome is for our students to acquire the skill set needed to improve healthcare through imaging science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the intestinal parasitic infection, Giardia lamblia, is a globally distributed intestinal pathogen that causes both acute and chronic infections in humans; for unknown reasons, some people, especially undernourished children, are incapable of clearing Giardia. These children may become sick from Giardia without knowing it -- Giardia seldom causes symptoms, but the parasite independently associates with poor growth and gut dysfunction. Seeking to address the hypothesis that chronic Giardia and Giardia-induced gut damage result from a change in intestinal microbiota as a consequence of low dietary protein intake, this study will identify new pathways of disease following intestinal pathogen infection that could lead to new or improved treatments for impaired gut function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The U.S. is facing a serious health crisis of rising rates of maternal mortality and severe morbidity, which are attributable to multiple factors, such as the persistent, deep shortages of maternal care workforce in disadvantaged urban communities and rural areas. The proposed study aims to examine whether recent workforce policy interventions, especially the expansion of National Health Service Corps (NHSC) since 2009, help reduce disparities in maternal care and outcomes between shortage areas and other areas. Our study findings will have important implications for the upcoming implementation of the 2018 Improving Access to Maternity Care Act, the latest NHSC policy change intended to better serve reproductive-age women in shortage areas by further increasing the NHSC supported maternal care providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive disease that leads to death, but little is known about the mechanism of disease progression. In this project, we propose to develop an engineered lung slice model to study the biomechanical mechanism of differential stretch-induced spatial progression of pulmonary fibrosis. The proposed model will facilitate the research efforts in this important, while poorly examined and traditionally less accessible, area of pulmonary research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The University of Pennsylvania Innovation In Suicide Prevention Implementation Research (INSPIRE) Center’s overarching goals are: (1) to develop and adapt practice-based and other suicide prevention interventions for minority and disenfranchised groups, and (2) to design and test implementation strategies to optimize how evidence-based practices can be brought to scale efficiently and with high fidelity, for optimal effectiveness. INSPIRE will prioritize strategies that can be deployed rapidly in a range of practice settings, including those with limited resources, thereby increasing their reach and public health impact. Using state-of-the-science methods from participatory research to actively engage stakeholders from many sectors – patients, providers, and payers – and applying innovative, interdisciplinary behavior change and implementation science methods to develop, adapt, and evaluate cost effective interventions, INSPIRE will be poised to be transformational for suicide prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reductions in white matter microstructure have been implicated as a central feature of Alzheimer’s disease (AD); yet, the molecular drivers of white matter alterations are unknown. The goal of this project is to perform rigorous evaluation of the genetic and molecular pathways of medial temporal lobe white matter microstructure that contributes to accelerated cognitive decline in AD. Such work will serve as a catalyst for the identification of novel therapeutic targets for neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will use our model system to characterize the genetic mechanisms that underlie seasonal rhythms, including genes and molecular pathways that are conserved across animals. Since many human diseases exhibit seasonal rhythms but cannot be examined at the same molecular level as our model, our project will generate results that can be used to enhance human health. We will also use our model to shed light on the molecular and evolutionary processes that generate individual- and population-level patterns in human disease risk and are being used in personalized medicine to diagnose and treat human illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE The world’s population is rapidly growing older, with a concomitant decrease in physical function of older individuals. Pharmacological inhibition of the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) is an effective therapy in improving age-related impairment of physical function and is a potential strategy to slow human aging, but there is variation in improvement of physical performance following ACE inhibition that is likely due to genetic variation. This research will identify novel genes, pathways, and mechanisms that contribute to the beneficial effects of angiotensin- converting enzyme inhibitor therapy on age-related decline in physical mobility, one of the most debilitating effects of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of people in the U.S. and worldwide have been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, a progressively debilitating disorder characterized by abnormal movement function. The goal of this study is to identify the specific changes in neuronal activity and connectivity between cortical and subcortical brain regions that are associated with the onset and progression of individual motor abnormalities associated with Parkinson’s disease. The results of this study will provide the understanding necessary for the refinement of current and development of future therapies, e.g. deep brain stimulation, transcranial magnetic and electrical stimulation and gene therapy, directed at modulating the neuronal activity in the basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuit responsible for the development of parkinsonian motor symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Ribosomes are essential molecular machines required in all cells to make proteins, and different cell types produce different numbers of ribosomes to suit their varying needs. Tight control over ribosome production is essential for normal tissue function, but our understanding of the regulatory proteins that exert this control is limited. This proposal seeks to identify key proteins that control ribosome production in different cell types in mammals, and understand their roles in maintaining normal tissue development and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strokes caused by blood clots coming from the heart are the most feared types of stroke and cause a high rate of death and disability. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a type of ischemic stroke affecting the back of the eye whose mechanisms are poorly understood. The objective of this study is to clarify the relationship between disorders causing clotting in the heart and CRAO and, in doing so, identify a new group of patients who are vulnerable to future, preventable strokes from the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative With new HIV infections in the US stalled at about 40,000 per year, the US government has laid out an ambitious plan, End the HIV Epidemic (EHE), which aims to reduce new HIV infections by 90% over ten years. We propose to expand the Cost-effectiveness of Preventing AIDS Complications (CEPAC) computer simulation model, to determine the cost-effectiveness of biomedical interventions, including pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), strategies to engage patients along the full continuum of HIV care, and novel ART regimens. We will then use optimization modeling to identify the best combination of biomedical and implementation approaches, in different settings and populations, to achieve the goals of the End the HIV Epidemic Initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Given the prevalence and the personal, social, and economic burden of major depressive disorder, it is imperative to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the brain in this condition. This innovative research program will yield important advances for the neural conceptualization of depression that is based on person-specific brain organization. Addressing this important but underexplored issue promises to ultimately contribute to the development of brain-based treatments in psychiatry and thus improved interventions, not only for major depression, but also for other mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: The proposed training program at the University of Texas at Austin is an inter-professional education partnership between the Schools of Social Work and Medicine. The proposed program aims to recruit and retain promising pre- and postdoctoral scholars from underrepresented groups to train and engage them in behavioral, population, and implementation science research to promote health equity in heart and lung diseases. Key innovations include recruitment and mentoring activities firmly grounded in the reality that cultural and racial/ethnic diversity in the scientific workforce is critical to the production of innovative scientific knowledge, a team-based mentoring approach with a near-peer mentoring component, and cross-fertilization of social work and medical trainees.

PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training to Promote Scientist Diversity & Health Equity in Cardiovascular & Lung Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this study is to integrate elements from existing interventions developed by our team into a single intervention (QUIT-AD), designed to improve smoking cessation and favorable HIV/TB treatment outcomes among individuals with HIV and/or TB in Cape Town, South Africa. If feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy are demonstrated, the intervention will be ready for large-scale effectiveness/implementation testing. This program will has the potential to dramatically improve public health by increasing the smoking quit rate and facilitating favorable HIV/TB treatment outcomes among patients with HIV and/or TB in resource limited South African settings.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: This project is relevant to public health and the mission of NICHD because it will help determine how handling and pooling practices for human milk fed to preterm infants alter the digestive release of bioactive peptides with gut-health promoting functions. Understanding which milk handling practices will yield the optimal release of bioactive peptides will help guide milk handling practices to best promote healthy development of preterm infants. This proposal specifically addresses two of the NICHD Pediatric Growth and Nutrition Branch’s Research Priorities:1) Human Milk Composition and Function (particularly how milk handling practices affect milk function within the infant) and 2) Nutrition for Preterm Infants (particularly understanding the role of bioactive components of human milk (e.g., peptides) in feeding preterm infants).

PROJECT_TITLE: Effects of human milk handling practices on peptide release and bioactivity in the preterm infant intestine

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The Study of HIV Infection in the Etiology of Lung Disease (SHIELD) is a prospective cohort of over 2600 individuals with or at-risk for HIV that has made significant contributions to our understanding that HIV infection is associated with increased respiratory morbidity and lung function impairment. Exposure to air pollution and increased susceptibility to air pollution may contribute to the excess respiratory morbidity among persons living with HIV (PLWH), and we propose to the extend the cohort in SHIELD AIR, which adds innovative approaches to outdoor and indoor air pollution assessment, comprehensive lung function measurement, and novel biomarkers of airway and internal response to exposure. Study findings will provide new insights into modifiable risk factors and targets for interventions aimed at improving lung health for PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Mapping networks of protein interactions is central to discovering the mechanisms of disease. This work aims to dramatically improve the specificity and power of technologies for protein interaction discovery, and then apply those methods to explore avenues of research in cancer, neurology, and immunology aimed at establishing new targets for drug development. The data generated through these studies, and also the broader application of these powerful tools, are therefore expected to lead to the development of new therapeutic and diagnostic approaches which will improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy drinking places young adults at risk for severe negative consequences (e.g., sexual assault, injuries), and even efficacious interventions have small and short-lived effects. The present study improves upon personalized feedback interventions by using mobile-delivery to provide repeated event-specific personalized feedback delivered close in time to drinking events. This research has the potential to have a major impact on public health by reducing high risk drinking and consequences among young adults, both college and non- college.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Falls among older adults are a leading cause of disability, death, and high healthcare costs. This proposal addresses the National Institute on Aging and Healthy People 2030 objectives to develop strategies to reduce falls, their consequences, and fall-related deaths by developing and testing strategies to implement the CDC-developed STEADI (Stopping Elderly Accidents, Deaths, and Injuries) for falls prevention of all older adults attending outpatient rehabilitation. Our proposed research will investigate and test how best to incorporate falls prevention into outpatient physical therapy visits that many older adults already attend and, how to best help older individuals follow the recommendations they receive about how to prevent falls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a severe and often fatal disease, and novel therapeutic approaches targeting the pulmonary vascular remodeling process are desperately needed. Despite intensive research performed on the role of BMP receptors in PAH, only a few BMP ligands have been studied in the context of PAH. The present proposal will aim to investigate the regulation, role and mechanism of action of BMP3 in PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Behavioral and physiological changes driven by severe stress play a major role in numerous human disease states, including post-traumatic stress disorder and related diseases. This proposal uses a circuit-oriented approach to delineate brain mechanisms underlying the behavioral, physiological and molecular impact of traumatic stress, as a means of providing insight into processes that may be leveraged for treatment or prevention of stress pathologies.

PHR: NARRATIVE Thrombosis is the leading cause of mortality in patients with myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN), yet little is understood about the mechanism driving this increased risk. Hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-mediated upregulation of genes including tissue factor in neutrophils from MPN patients associates with thrombosis history. This proposal aims to evaluate the role of HIF in MPN-associated thrombosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic men and children experience health disparities for overweight and obesity-related medical conditions, and therefore family level obesity prevention programs for Hispanic populations are urgently needed. ‘Healthy Dads Healthy Kids’ is the first program to primarily target fathers for obesity prevention for themselves and their children, with significant and clinically relevant treatment effects. We propose an efficacy trial to assess a culturally adapted ‘Healthy Dads Healthy Kids’ for Hispanic families among a Medicaid and Children’s Health Insurance Plan sample of Hispanic families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of new synthetic methods for incorporation of medicinally important chemical moieties continues to drive new drug discovery. To this end, this research seeks to combine two transformative advances in chemical synthesis, biocatalysis and C–H functionalization, to develop new metalloenzymes that can convert ubiquitous C–H bonds in organic molecules into functional groups with high biomedical relevance. These newly created biocatalysts will offer powerful tools for drug synthesis and diversification and enable a more expansive chemical space of bioactive molecules that is beyond the reach of current small molecule catalysts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The precise localization of specific channels within the membrane of neurons plays a critical role in their normal functioning, while its disruption contributes to the emergence neurological disease. This project will develop tools to study how channels are localized within neurons and characterize their role in neuronal function. This will further the understanding of how neuronal physiology contributes to health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement In response to the worst overdose crisis in US history and calls for a more effective police response to behavioral health problems, the growing practice of diverting people with opioid use disorder to treatment instead of arrest can improve the health outcomes of police encounters with people who use drugs. To better understand the processes that lead to a police officer’s decision to divert a person to treatment, this project will 1) develop and validate an instrument to measure police stigma toward people who use drugs, 2) use the Theory of Planned Behavior to identify other key variables that determine police officers’ intentions to divert, and 3) determine the officer-perceived barriers and facilitators of effective diversion to treatment. Executing these aims will produce actionable training, policy, and process recommendations for communities seeking to increase connections to evidence-based care for opioid use disorder as a police behavioral health response to the opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: NARRATIVE  Vertebrate development is the result of a profound and controlled remodeling of gene expression following the fertilization of the egg by the sperm. Interestingly, I have developed new approaches to study the controllers mediating this essential transfer of information. The work in this proposal seeks to discover the regulators and the ways they interact one with each other to generate a fully-grown organism because it will ultimately help to understand human development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Diamond Blackfan Anemia (DBA) is characterized by defective erythropoiesis. Erythroid progenitors from murine and human models of DBA have chronic hyper-activation of Nemo-Like Kinase (NLK), while suppression of NLK improves erythroid expansion in vitro. Understanding the mechanisms by which NLK contributes to disease pathogenesis will potentially lead to novel approaches to treat patients with DBA and other bone marrow failure syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Homeostasis, or stability within the body is important for optimal functioning, however, the loss of the ability to maintain homeostasis and the subsequent effect on ideal swallowing function is not understood. The proposed study will provide an understanding of how the loss of the functional reserves that regulate homeostasis contributes to swallowing impairment in ALS and the frail elderly. This research is relevant to public health since the results will help facilitate the development of biologically informed therapeutics to treat swallowing dysfunction in a variety of patient populations in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA nanostructures have promise in biomedical applications such as biosensing, drug delivery and bioimaging, but the field faces several challenges for it to be used in practical applications. In addressing these challenges, I propose to develop robust, multifunctional drug delivery platform for treating multisystemic diseases and design self-assembled 3D DNA crystals as scaffolds for X-ray structure determination using the new technique of Serial Femtosecond X-ray Crystallography. In the long-term, I envision that our modular, platform technology using DNA nanostructures can be adopted by other labs for different disease treatments and drug screening and to obtain crystallographic information of hard-to-crystallize molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The overlying goal of the research program is to understand how timing of cell activities - patterning, signaling, and movement - is regulated in the Drosophila early embryo as development proceeds. In particular, the proposed experiments will investigate how initiation of zygotic gene expression is controlled; and how this results in the activation of cell signaling, including through FGFs, which is instrumental for the support of cell movements at gastrulation to transform the blastoderm embryo into multiple layers with distinct tissue types. This work has the potential to provide insight into how diverse cellular functions are coordinated to support normal embryonic development in higher animals, as the regulatory mechanisms are likely conserved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Recent epidemiological studies show a rapid increase in Alzheimer's Disease (AD) in Hispanics compared to non-Hispanics whites. However, there is limited understanding about AD determinants in Hispanics and the effect of genes by environment interactions. The proposed application aims to determine the influence of genetics and social disparities of health on age at onset, cognitive profiles, and biomarker trajectories in Hispanic populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progesterone is a sex hormone that governs the menstrual cycle, but it also has anti-inflammatory effects on the immune system in the female reproductive tract, and possibly throughout the body. We propose to study how and why progesterone affects the immune system in the whole body. The results of our studies may contribute to women’s health by explaining sex-based and menstrual cycle-related fluctuations in inflammatory disease and susceptibility to infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance  The State of Maine faces challenging cancer heath disparities, as it is the most rural and oldest state in the nation. Historically, cancer patients and their families in Maine have had inconsistent access to state-of-the-art federally-sponsored cancer research trials. The MaineHealth Cancer Care Network (MHCCN) Lifespan proposal provides a wonderful opportunity and departure point for our organization to be considered for inclusion in the NCI Community Oncology Program and to provide access for our patients to this vital resource. We value making substantive contributions and providing leadership to NCORP over the next award period.

PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) has been implicated in many diseases including cancer and neurodegenerative disorders. Advancing XL- MS technologies to define in vivo interaction landscape and structural dynamics of proteomes at the systems-level will enable detailed delineation of the UPS network to understand its association with human pathologies and uncover potential targets for improved therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Variants in SIX1, a transcription factor implicated in many cellular processes during craniofacial development and in branchio-oto-renal syndrome, have been recently linked to craniosynostosis (premature closure of the sutures between the skull bones); this is one of the most prevalent birth defects affecting ~1:2500 live births. The studies proposed in this NIDCR career development award application will address the major knowledge gap regarding the role of Six1 in calvarial bone development, and provide new knowledge regarding the pathogenesis of this prevalent birth defect, thus facilitating diagnosis and care of craniosynostosis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The dysregulation of autophagy is associated with cancer, neurodegeneration and aging, but the mechanistic details behind these relationships are poorly understood. The proposed research will elucidate the role of autophagy receptors in selective autophagy, focusing on the mechanism(s) by which receptors identify potentially toxic structures and induce their degradation. A thorough understanding of autophagy induction mechanisms will inform our understanding of how autophagy becomes dysregulated in disease and guide therapeutic attempts to ameliorate these deficiencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SGLT2 inhibitors are approved for the treatment of type 2, but not type 1, diabetes patients primarily because of the (i) increased incidence of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in the later group, and (ii) stimulation of endogenous (hepatic) glucose production, thus impairing their glucose lowering effectiveness. A clearer understanding of the pathophysiologic mechanisms responsible for the stimulation of ketogenesis and hepatic glucose production, as well as treatment regimens that can effectively block the SGLT2i-induced stimulation of these two metabolic processes, are needed. In the present grant we will employ innovative study designs in combination with isotopes: (i) to elucidate the mechanisms via which SGLT2 inhibitors stimulate ketone production and hepatic glucose production (HGP), and (ii) to examine whether coadministration of pioglitazone, an antidiabetic agent approved by the FDA, with empagliflozin can prevent the SGLT2i-induced stimulation of ketosis and HGP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggressive chemotherapy cannot be tolerated in the majority of adult AML patients due to advanced age. Novel, non-toxic therapeutic strategies are highly sought after to improve AML survival. We have shown that ascorbate treatment can block AML progression by enhancing the activity of TET enzymes without adverse effects. Our goal is to elucidate the mechanistic role of TET proteins in ascorbate-mediated AML sensitivity, identify rational drug combination treatment strategies using ascorbate as an adjuvant, and optimize the bioavailability of ascorbate to increase its efficacy as a TET cofactor for AML therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is one of the most lethal malignancies with poor long-term survival due to its delayed onset of symptoms and notorious resistance to existing chemotherapy and radiation. Hence, there is an unmet urgent need for better early diagnosis, screening and treatment methods. Here our project investigates a protein uniquely expressed in pancreatic tumors and released into patient blood, which we will test as a biomarker and therapeutic target.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microbiome-gut-brain dysfunction may be one of the earliest disease processes contributing to the development of Lewy body diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Chemical damage to DNA is a major source of replication stress that can induce genome instability and drive the progression of cancer and ageing. This proposal investigates the mechanisms that enable the cellular DNA replication machinery to tolerate and repair DNA damage. Insights generated by this work may therefore inform the development of interventions that modulate replication stress to treat cancer and genetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transplants, free flaps, and replantation procedures each require multiple microvascular connections in order to enable integration and vascularization of transplanted tissue. Thombosis at the anastomosis site is the most feared post-operative complication, and is a primary cause of re-operations, extended inpatient stay, potentially- devastating functional and cosmetic morbidity, and increased healthcare costs. Here, we describe a novel nanofiber-based suture platform that can provide immediate and durable release of anti-thrombotic agents directly to the surgical site to prevent thrombosis without modifying the clinical workflow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapies are FDA-approved adoptive T cell therapies that have been genetically engineered to recognize and kill cancer cells and have improved complete remission rates compared to existing treatments with potential of long term cure. However, effective CAR T cell therapy is highly variable across patients. The label-free single-cell metabolic imaging technologies developed in this proposal could streamline processes and interventions for consistently potent T cell therapy and increase our knowledge of CAR T cell metabolism in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While bacterial pathogens manipulate immune responses to cause deadly infections, it is appreciated that nonpathogenic commensals can also mediate these effects. Our studies focus on understanding how a protein domain conserved in numerous pathogens and commensals regulates inflammatory responses. This work could identify new targets or strategies to for development of anti-inflammatory or anti-bacterial therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative This research will provide insights into how processes at multiple levels of neural organization contribute to regulation of behavior. Using novel technology that may have broad applications to other nervous systems, we will examine how a combinatoric code of key interneurons generates a range of motor behaviors in response to changing challenges; how arousal and satiation are implemented throughout a complex nervous system, and how a distributed learning system modifies behavior to respond to changes in the environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Stimulation-responsive histone post-translational modifications (PTMs), including histone phosphorylation, play important roles in the immune response. However, studying these PTMs in primary immune cells, especially in rare cell types, is currently challenged by the limitations of existing chromatin profiling methods. Here, EpiCypher is developing EpiPrime-seq, an ultra-sensitive genomics platform that will enable the study of stimulation-responsive PTMs in primary cells for immunology research, including drug, biomarker, and vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Right ventricular dysfunction is an important determinant of long-term outcomes in patients with many forms of congenital heart disease. Our research will explore how genotypes affect right ventricular function, survival, and clinical outcomes. We will also test the effect of genotypes in human induced pluripotential stem cell- derived cardiomyocytes, providing functional evidence of how genotypes influence cardiac performance, and developing a resource for future testing of drugs and small molecules targeted at improving deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Adaptive control of behavior is critical for survival and requires not only brain control of muscle activity, but also descending control of organism physiology and internal organ function. We will dissect the neural circuits and principles governing the learning and adaptive “motor” control of internal organ function by investigating conditioned insulin release and conditioned immunosuppression, mediated by the innervation of the pancreas and spleen, respectively. We will employ state-of-the art viral tracing methods to map first, second and third- order innervation of spleen and pancreas, RNA sequencing to characterize neuron identity, in vivo calcium imaging to measure neuronal activity in descending circuits, and chemo- and optogenetic tools to causally test how descending circuits impact splenic and pancreatic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overtreatment of patients with low-risk thyroid cancer by removing the entire thyroid puts patients at significant for harm without improving length of life. This pilot study aims to address this problem by evaluating the feasibility and acceptability of a novel intervention to support patient awareness, activation, and preparedness for treatment decision-making. The findings will inform a large-scale clinical trial to test the effect of this intervention on patients’ treatment decisions and rates of total thyroidectomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Protein arginylation is increasingly recognized as a global biological regulator essential for physiological processes, including angiogenesis, embryogenesis, aging, and cell migration. ATE1 is the sole enzyme responsible for protein arginylation and has recently been implicated in human cancers and neurodegenerative diseases, but its catalytic mechanism and regulation remain poorly understood. This project aims to understand the structural, catalytic, and regulatory mechanisms of protein arginylation, which may lead to new therapeutic strategies for preventing the development and progression of Parkinson’s disease and Metastatic Cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC) Study enrolled more than 5500 adults with chronic kidney disease (CKD) to address overarching goals of identifying predictors of rapid progression of kidney disease and clarifying the relationship between kidney disease and the risks of cardiovascular events and death. During the earlier phases of CRIC, the UIC Clinical Center research team has been successful in terms of recruitment, retention, data quality, a strong focus on heath disparities in CKD, and scientific productivity. This proposal for the next phase will extend follow-up for another three years during which we will conduct data analyses with integration of findings from home testing done during the prior phase, and final study visits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal outlines a training and research plan to determine the effects of psychosocial stressors on Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (ADRD), including the total effects, whether social networks buffer that effect, and whether sleep disturbance is a pathway from psychosocial stressors to ADRD. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The establishment of specialized chromatin domains referred to as heterochromatin is critical for centromere and telomere function, silencing of repetitive DNA and maintaining lineage-specific patterns of gene expression. Our program of research aims to develop a basic understanding of the mechanisms that govern how cells memorize epigenetic patterns of gene expression. This research is relevant to human health since disrupting heterochromatin formation leads to chromosome segregation defects and genome instability which are the most common of abnormalities observed in cancer cells.

PHR: Project Narrative Mortality and morbidity are independently linked to cachexia, a muscle wasting syndrome present in many patients with chronic diseases. In this proposal, we examine how muscle tissue extracellular matrix remodeling may act as a barrier to response to therapy or exercise during the end stages of cachexia. Our findings will help develop new rehabilitation strategies that can be implemented across the spectrum of cachexia disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is primarily a chronic lung disease that occurs more in female patients than males (4:1 ratio). Here we propose that Uty gene on the Y chromosome protects from pulmonary hypertension, and aim to identify downstream effector genes of Uty that could serve as novel therapeutic targets in attenuating PAH in male and female patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance The United States faces an unprecedented drug addiction crisis, with one potent driver of relapse to drug-seeking the environmental context in which the effects of a particular drug were experienced. However, the circuit mechanism underlying this behavior remains incompletely understood. Here, we propose to apply cutting-edge technology to explore how the well-known reward-circuity, and its associated neuromodulators, interface with the hippocampus, a region that encodes environmental context and is ideally poised to engage with reward-related signals to form memories for later action selection based on learned associations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE An effective vaccine remains the most direct and cost-effective way to end the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Our Cytomegalovirus (CMV) vector-based HIV/SIV vaccine has shown a unique form of viral “replication arrest” efficacy in the Rhesus Macaque-SIV model mediated by an unconventional CD8+ T cell population that recognizes viral epitopes in the context of major histocompatibility complex E proteins. The work proposed in this application will delineate the immune mechanisms underlying this novel efficacy, which will then be used to guide human testing of this vaccine concept in ongoing and future phase I/II trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A core characteristic of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a deficit in mentalizing (our ability to create mental representations of others), which we have identified an underlying neural network with our pilot functional magnetic resonance imaging data. This proposal is a robust investigation into modulating this network with repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation sequences to uncover the optimal method to target and modulate the mentalizing network activity in ASD. Validating this neural mechanism in ASD is a necessary first step toward assessing the effectiveness of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation in modulating social behaviors in this group in future clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application seeks to understand how the replication stress response promotes completion of DNA synthesis each cell division cycle while maintaining genome stability. Genome instability causes many diseases including developmental disorders and cancer. Therefore, completing this project will provide insights into basic genome maintenance mechanisms with significant clinical application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The establishment of left-right (LR) asymmetry is a critical event required for the correct positioning of internal organs. Defects in human LR axis formation cause birth defects of the heart, vasculature, lungs, and intestinal tract. Our research aims to discover the central mechanism that links Hedgehog (Hh) signaling pathway and transforming growth factor-b (TGF-b) signaling pathway to the establishment of left-right asymmetry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Hypertension is a major risk factor for cardiovascular diseases such as stroke, heart failure and renal failure. With a greater than 33% prevalence rate in the United States, hypertension remains an increasingly important medical and public health issue. In this proposal, we aim to develop a novel therapeutic approach based on kinin B1 receptor blockade to treat neurogenic hypertension.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is to generate a reagent resource that enables the characterization and validation of Drosophila models of human mitochondrial diseases. These reagents will facilitate immunolocalization and immunoprecipitation and be used together with existing RNAi transgenic lines to validate fly models of human mitochondrial diseases. As mitochondrial diseases affect multiple organs, our proposal is relevant to most NIH institutes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastomas (GBM) are the most recalcitrant adult brain tumors affecting about 15,000 Americans every year and exhibit considerable resistance to chemo and radiation therapy. In this proposal, we have identified novel modulators of radiation resistance and propose to use synthetic combinations to target these pathways and sensitize glioma cells to radiation. The overall goal is to use these pre-clinical studies to design new and effective treatment options for patients with GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Basic Research to Diagnostics and Surveillance in Lower Resource Environments Foundation for Applied Molecular Evolution  Steven A. Benner NARRATIVE  The recent disappointing response of the CDC to the emergency created by the "Wuhan coronavirus" (2019- nCoV) reflects the fact that the CDC is not supported by basic science related to nucleic acid chemistry, and that the CDC is constructively unaware of what science is presently available to them to meet their needs. Specifically, had the CDC used two new technologies (self-avoiding molecular recognition systems, SAMRS, and artificially expanded genetic information systems, AEGIS) in their assays, the CDC would (at the time of this writing) be distributing robust kits to detect coronavirus, and an as yet unknown number of unnecessary deaths would have been spared. This project will provide the basic science research needed to support AEGIS and SAMRS, as well as to support their general use across many applications, to speed and lower the cost of regulatory approval of diagnostics kits, and to increase manufacturing robustness of multiplexed pathogen detection products. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop meaningful quality measures for Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) treatment by pediatric primary care providers, as a prerequisite for improving health outcomes for children with this highly prevalent condition. This project will leverage recent advances in machine learning methods and engage key stakeholders to develop robust quality measures for ADHD treatment, and to prepare for quality improvement interventions. The completion of this project will strengthen collaborations between stakeholders to continuously improve evidence-based practices in primary care settings and mitigate health disparities for individuals with ADHD and other mental and behavioral health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Dengue virus (DENV) and Zika virus (ZIKV) are mosquito-borne pathogens that cause substantial morbidity and mortality worldwide. We have found that both viruses require the function of the cellular ER Membrane Protein Complex (EMC) for stabilization of two viral proteins necessary for replication. The goal of this project is to define the mechanisms by which the EMC supports DENV and ZIKV infection, which will lead to insights into other viruses that are known to depend on the EMC and possibly to novel strategies to treat these viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Among people living with Alzheimer’s disease (PWD)-caregiver research, most studies concentrate on the caregiver-PWD dyad which is not representative of real-life as multiple family members and non-related friends are often involved in the care of PWD. To advance the measurement of PWD-caregiver networks in research, we will use an NIH-funded Social Network methodology software (Network Canvas) in a multi-site observational study of 200 PWD-caregiver networks. Through this research, we plan to have a better understanding of how to measure PWD-caregiver networks and operationalize a network measurement approach to understand caregiver systems that will be shareable with other researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The (dys)regulation of telomeres, the terminal structures of linear chromosomes, is associated with immortalization, aging and tumorigenesis. This fact is best exemplified by the bone marrow failure and cancer predisposition syndrome, dyskeratosis congenita, where mutations in eleven genes, all of which encode factors required for telomere maintenance, are known to cause the disease. Approbation of the belief that telomere maintenance is an important area of investigation was provided by the 2009 Nobel Prizes in Physiology or Medicine, which were awarded for the discovery of telomeres and telomerase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to develop a novel, noninvasive, and sensitive bladder cancer screening test using cells found in voided urine samples that are imaged with ultra-high-resolution atomic force microscopy. The proposed method will improve the current standard-of-care cytological evaluation of voided urine test (VUC) to detect bladder cancer with higher accuracy, and further help to identify the grade of cancer. We anticipate this innovative technology will remarkably improve patient participation for screening and follow-up on bladder cancer, and confidently nominate patients for the more invasive and expensive detection using cystoscopies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: The purpose of proposed study is to understand the molecular mechanism underlying the retarded regeneration of connective tissue and alveolar bone in periodontitis (Gum Disease) by focusing on death induced in mesenchymal stem cells (baby cells that can differentiate into bone, gum and many other cell types). Our preliminary data indicate that the pathogenic bacteria for periodontitis, P. gingivalis (Pg), but not other periodontal bacteria, can cause atypical cell death of periodontal stem cells, but not epithelial cells, which not only kills the periodontal stem cells, but also induce inflammation. This study is expected to lead to the development of a therapeutic strategy that prevents such a unique stem cell death and, thus, alleviating inflammation and inducing tissue regeneration in periodontitis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular fluid flows act signals, either by providing mechanical force or directing chemicals across cell surfaces, however, few proteins that sense and transduce fluid flows signals have been identified. The purpose of this research is to use the zebrafish left-right patterning system to characterize novel proteins that sense and transduce fluid flows. Through this work we will gain insight into diseases caused by aberrant fluid flows like polycystic kidney disease, heterotaxy, and congenital heart defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE The objective of this study is to improve the management and outcomes for people living with HIV (PWH) diagnosed with clinically localized prostate cancer. Towards this end, we will create a novel microsimulation model of prostate cancer natural history and treatment outcomes in PWH to perform comparative effectiveness analyses tailored to this population. Our results will identify the optimal prostate cancer management for PWH to reduce treatment toxicities, maximize survival and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papillomavirus (HPV), a vaccine preventable disease, is the most common sexually transmitted disease impacting young men and women. This study focuses on Korean Americans, a population at high-risk of HPV- caused cancers but who have low HPV vaccination coverage rates. This study proposes to refine a novel theory- guided, culturally appropriate storytelling HPV intervention that leverages artificial intelligence chatbot technology to facilitate timely, effective, and sustained motivation to increase the HPV vaccine uptakes of Korean American men and women aged 18-26 years old.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the Rutgers Training Program in Addiction Research is to provide a diverse group of trainees with an appreciation of modern interdisciplinary substance use disorder research, which could lay the groundwork for the development of novel and innovative addiction treatments. The program encompasses a diverse array of basic science approaches as well as human genetics and imaging studies. The didactic aspects of the program take full advantage of the broad expertise of our faculty mentors while continually emphasizing research ethics as well as training in scientific rigor and reproducibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative When people lack the means to consistently meet their material needs for food, housing, finances, and healthcare, their health suffers, particularly for those already managing chronic diseases such as HIV or diabetes. The proposed study brings together a multidisciplinary team of experts for a five-year study among over 3000 men and women living with or at risk for HIV to understand how these unmet material needs work together to harm HIV and cardiovascular disease health. The ultimate goal is to reduce HIV and cardiovascular disease disparities, consistent with both the goals of National HIV/AIDS Strategy and with the nutritional, health behavior, CVD, and health disparities goals of US Healthy People 2020.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histone Chaperones are emerging as regulators of cell fate decisions given their pivotal role in genome organization during DNA templated processes such as DNA replication and transcription. The goal of this research proposal is to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying the lineage specifying functions of histones chaperones. If successful, our work will be a stepping stone to developing new therapies and technologies where histone chaperone pathways can be manipulated to control cell fate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) pulmonary disease is an increasingly common orphan disease that causes progressive disability in older adults. Patient-reported outcome (PRO) measures are a patient- centered way to measure symptoms, functioning, and symptomatic adverse events over time. We seek to understand the trajectory of symptoms and their association with NTM pulmonary disease activity, response, and recurrence after treatment completion.

Of the congenital malformations, congenital heart disease (CHD) is the most common. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is the second-leading cause of death in adolescence, yet its neurobiology is poorly understood, and there is a desperate need for improved methods to treat youth with suicidal behavior. This project will study negative urgency, a type of impulsivity occurring in the context of negative emotions that has been associated with suicidal behavior, and how it relates to impairment in inhibitory brain physiology using a noninvasive technique (transcranial magnetic stimulation paired with electroencephalography) in youth with suicidal thoughts and behaviors. A comprehensive training plan and multidisciplinary mentoring team will ensure high productivity during the award period and the candidate’s successful transition to a career as an independent clinical investigator of adolescent suicidal behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Greater exposure to stressful situations, coupled with limited access to the financial and social resources needed to manage stress in healthy ways are believed to contribute to persistent racial/ethnic disparities in Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD). Our study combines personalized and objective indicators of the body's response to stressful experiences with multi-modal neuroimaging and longitudinal cognitive assessments in a unique multi-ethnic cohort. Our findings will inform stress management interventions and precision medicine initiatives designed to prevent ADRD and/or slow its progression

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use rates among American Indian adolescents have been greater than national rates for decades, and recent evidence indicates that some substance use disparities are increasing for American Indian adolescents living on or near reservations (hereafter reservation). This proposed study will continue to monitor rates of use for reservation American Indian adolescents and compare these rates to national rates, in addition to estimating relationships between substance use and measures of strength and resilience especially pertinent to this population. The findings from this study will be disseminated to key stakeholders including participating schools and local and national Native groups and organizations, and will inform prevention, intervention, and policy efforts designed to reduce substance use among this population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement Aberrant DNA methylation in gametes is associated with idiopathic infertility, poorer outcomes during fertility treatment, ovarian aging, and can be deleterious to embryonic development. In this proposal, I seek to elucidate the intracellular and extracellular cues that instruct the patterning of DNA methylation in oocytes and sperm. This study will further our understanding of how de novo epimutations that adversely impact fertility and development may arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Xenotransplantation (XTx) is a novel experimental treatment that involves transplanting organs from nonhuman animals into humans to reduce the organ shortage—a public health problem. Most guidance documents addressing the ethical and policy challenges for XTx are limited because they are 10-20 years old, do not reflect changes in the science of XTx, and do not account for stakeholder concerns. Our team of bioethicists and translational scientists will develop up-to-date ethics and policy recommendations and decision aids for transplant candidates, transplant clinicians preparing to conduct XTx clinical trials, and institutional review boards that will review XTx clinical trial protocols. Our proposed recommendations and decision aids will facilitate the ethical translation of XTx clinical trials to reduce the organ shortage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Elevated rates of depression in college students is a very serious public health problem resulting in poor academic performance and psychosocial functioning, increased risk of dropping out of college, a greater likelihood of self-harm and suicide, and a chronic course of illness. The proposed project is designed to investigate the dynamic interplay between social stress, social safety schemas, inflammation, and depression symptoms in freshman transitioning to campus for the first time. Better understanding of how social stress and socially- oriented cognitive vulnerabilities affect biological processes underlying risk for depression is crucial to inform the prevention of this highly burdensome disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Increased infectious disease outbreaks, highlighted by the current COVID-19 pandemic, serves as a constant reminder of the importance of diagnostics for infectious diseases and the large diagnostic gap in our response arsenal. Whispering Gallery Mode (WGM) devices that consist of microbubble resonators are a novel class of highly sensitive optical sensor with simple fluid handling. Through these studies, we will address this gap and leverage microbubble resonators for the rapid, multiplexed detection of viruses as a versatile biosensing platform both for laboratory and field deployment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic Kidney Disease is an extremely common medical problem. The consequences of chronic kidney disease include kidney failure requiring dialysis or a kidney transplant; cardiovascular disease and stroke; physical and cognitive disabilities; and premature death. The Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC) Study is a long-term, observational study designed to evaluate factors that might be responsible for these adverse outcomes in adults with chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE This project brings together a team of experts in genetics, genomics, and maternal fetal medicine to introduce whole-genome sequencing as a viable first-tier diagnostic test for fetuses with severe structural anomalies detected on ultrasound. Our team will leverage novel methods for prenatal genetic testing of fetal samples from amniocentesis and excess tissue from the most severe extremes of fetal developmental anomalies in humans. Our goal will be to characterize all classes of point mutations and structural variants, and support the introduction of routine genomic screening in fetal samples from both invasive and non-invasive procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although the survival rate of breast cancer (BC) increases over the years, BC survivors remain at elevated risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD)-related morbidity and mortality. Our overarching goal is to develop solid computational and theoretical foundations for learning from imbalanced real-world data, with an emphasis on BC-CVD outcome risk prediction. The successful implementation of this project would lay a computational foundation for imbalanced data and can provide more accurate tools for predicting BC

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The continuation of this unparalleled combined adoption/twin study will contribute to a greater prospective understanding of the manner in which cognitive abilities, physical health, and neighborhood environments promote cognitive functioning at midlife. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Exposure to elevated manganese from environmental sources (e.g. drinking water or air) leads to severe motor deficits in infants, children and adolescents. This proposal will establish the mechanisms by which environmental manganese exposure in vulnerable early-life periods induces motor disease, which are not yet known, and further contribute to the development of a treatment for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hippocampus is the central brain structure without which we could not navigate our environment or remember recent events. The hippocampal synaptic circuits that mediate information transfer and contribute to the storage and retrieval of memories are therefore crucial to our understanding of memory deficits associated with aging and neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease. In this project we will dissect the mechanisms that contribute to plasticity of a hippocampal synapse and determine how this contributes to specific forms of episodic memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) exhibits the highest potential to metastasize, and clustered circulating tumor cells are associated with a significantly higher incidence of breast cancer metastasis. The primary goal of this proposal is to investigate a novel mechanism of cell-cell interaction that promotes tumor cell clustering and metastasis in TNBC. Successfully accomplishing the proposed study will inspire the development of new strategies for the treatment of metastatic TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative How transcriptional enhancers communicate with their target promoters persists as one of the central mysteries in cell and developmental biology. We will employ a combination of genome editing, Hi-C contact maps, and quantitative imaging methods to explore the role of chromosomal looping elements--insulators and tethering elements--in the regulation of gene expression in the Drosophila embryo. We will test the hypothesis that looping factors stabilize enhancer-promoter associations by nucleating the formation of transcription hubs: clusters or condensates of transcription factors and RNA Pol II.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common primary malignant brain tumor and expresses the potently immunosuppressive factor indoleamine 2,3 dioxygenase 1 (IDO; IDO1) in >90% of patient-resected cases. The premise of this R01 renewal proposal is to characterize a newly appreciated mechanism of immune resistance that's mediated by GBM cell IDO, as well as to develop and optimize IDO protein degraders as new tools and therapeutic enhancers that fully reverse the immunosuppressive effects of IDO in GBM.
