IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The experiments in this proposal will explore cellular pathways involved in the development of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), a devastating disease with limited treatment options. In particular, we will explore whether specific protein-protein interactions featuring aquaporin 1 mediate the smooth muscle and endothelial changes in phenotype that contribute to vascular remodeling during development of pulmonary hypertension and whether these interactions can be targeted to reverse remodeling. Such information is crucial to advancing knowledge of disease pathology and developing new therapeutic options to treat this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE - OVERALL The goal of precision therapeutics is to give the right dose of the right drug to the right person at the right time, but rigorous data on precision therapeutics in children and pregnant women are lacking, and there is a shortage of adequately trained investigators in these areas. This Center of Excellence proposal leverages our institutional strengths in Precision Medicine and Bioinformatics to address knowledge gaps in pharmacogenomics and neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome using innovative analyses of electronic health datasets. Another major goal is the establishment and dissemination of educational resources to create and sustain a physician-scientist workforce in maternal and pediatric precision therapeutics at the national level through collaboration with the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aggressive B cell lymphomas are a very common type of cancer with varied outcomes for patients—some are cured with standard treatment, but others are not. The goal of this research is to identify biomarkers that can identify which patients are likely to be cured, and which patients might need new treatments. The biomarkers may also tell us if certain types of immune targeting therapies would be useful for certain types of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This proposal is relevant to public health because it addresses critical shortcomings of currently available methods for studying the relationship between cells and their microenvironment. The development of the proposed molecular, microfluidic, and computational tools will advance understanding of the role of fluid transport in regulating biological processes. In addition to laying the foundation for studying disease mechanisms that are not well captured by current model systems, the results of this work will inform the development of interventional approaches for the myriad diseases in which pathologic fluid transport plays a role, including cardiovascular disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is characterized by poor memory for positive events. This positive memory deficit exacerbates the hopelessness that characterizes MDD, and it may be a critical target for treatment—but, unfortunately, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. The current project will address this knowledge gap by using electroencephalography (EEG) and computational modeling to study the encoding and retrieval of positive memories in adults with MDD, and by testing whether mirth induction can alleviate the deficit by increasing positive affect and thus restoring neural responses to positive stimuli.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Aberrant regulation of stem cells by their niche can severely affect human health by causing tumor formation or tissue atrophy. Therefore we must improve our understanding of niche function as it pertains to stem cell regulation. This project will uncover the principles of how a niche is initially positioned during development, how this precise positioning is critical to niche function, and whether a niche receives feedback from the tissue it supports.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension affects half of American adults but poses an especially severe burden on African Americans. Understanding and eliminating disparities in hypertension and related social determinants of health is a national research priority identified in NHLBI’s Strategic Vision. This project will leverage unique opportunities in spatial epidemiology to quantify the fraction of hypertension disparities that can be eliminated by addressing disparities in geographic areas’ socioeconomic characteristics and structural environmental resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a major cause of acute and chronic liver failure and is now the most common reason for liver transplantation in the U.S. Historically, transplant centers have required at least 6 months of alcohol abstinence before considering patients with ALD for liver transplant; however early liver transplant for patients with severe ALD with less than 6 months of alcohol abstinence can save lives. This multi- center study will examine the patient selection process for early liver transplantation, identify strategies most helpful to prevent return to alcohol use and to optimize long-term health after transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: SOCIETY FOR THE ADV CHICANOS/NATIVE AMER
PHR: NARRATIVE:   Biomedical  and  Behavioral  Science  research  education  programs  across  the  nation  are  faced  with  challenges  (e.g.  changing  job  markets),  and  potential  opportunities  (e.g.  large  diverse  population),  that  must  be  collectively  considered  to  meet  the  needs  of  the  nation  and  drive  innovations.  SACNAS  (the  Society  for  Advancement  of  Chicanos/Hispanics  and  Native  Americans  in  Science),  the  largest  multicultural  and  multidisciplinary  STEM  diversity  organization  in  the  nation  with  a  more  than  46- year  history,  is  ideally  positioned  to  address  these  challenges.  SACNAS  will  develop  career  trainings  for  its  established  network  of  underrepresented  minority  students  and  postdoctoral  fellows  to  enhance  retention,  build  leadership  skill  sets,  increase  workforce  diversity,  and  facilitate  progress  along  various  career  tracks  (academia,  industry,  government,  nonprofits)  within  the  Biomedical  and  Behavioral  Sciences disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  The Department of Energy and predecessor agencies have been involved in the research, production and testing of nuclear weapons since the 1940s. During that time, numerous facilities, both government and privately-owned, were constructed or leased across the country to support the effort, generating large quantities of radioactive and hazardous materials that resulted in the contamination of many of the facilities and surrounding areas.  In 1994, to protect the staff and workers doing DOE cleanup and waste management work, legislation was enacted to allow the Department of Energy to fund NIEHS to develop Worker Training programs that would assure workers, other facility personnel, and community responders the knowledge and skills to protect themselves and their communities from hazardous conditions in the workplace.  The National Partnership for Environmental Technology Education (PETE) and its Community College Consortium for Health and Safety Training (CCCHST) has been continuously supported by NIEHS since 1995 to provide quality training that is efficient, consistent, flexible, and cost-effective for the multiple tiers of contractors at DOE sites including the Oakridge complex, Pantex, the Savannah River Site, with Los Alamos National Lab soon to be added, annually providing 7,000 students with 400 courses for a total 50,000 contact hours of training, with an average 75 courses delivered online.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The molecular motions of proteins underlie many important biological phenomena, such as allostery, yet they remain challenging to study at high spatial and temporal resolution. The goal of the proposed research is to implement a novel approach that combines temperature perturbations with structural, biochemical, and biophysical measurements to provide insight into the allosteric regulation of protein molecules that have key functions in health and disease. The knowledge generated from these studies will deepen our understanding of human biology and provide information that is actionable for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The behavioral response of an organism to its environment is the output of many synaptic, neuronal, and circuit processes that are regulated by a complex network of genes and proteins. Synaptic adhesion molecules are crucial for neuronal circuit function, as evidenced by their association with conditions characterized by changes in behavior, including autism and schizophrenia. To overcome challenges presented by the extreme complexity of neuronal circuits and synaptic adhesion genes in vertebrates, we will use modern neuroscience and genetic techniques in C. elegans to investigate the coordination and molecular mechanisms of many conserved synaptic adhesion genes across multiple conserved foraging behaviors and circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic defects in RUNX1, a master regulator of hematopoiesis and leukemogenesis, have frequently been identified in myeloid neoplasms particularly acute myeloid leukemia. Leukemogenic RUNX1 mutations may possess potential mutant-specific functionality and cooperate with other mutations in promoting leukemia and lineage specification. Our work aims to use our newly developed inducible and reversible RUNX1 mutant mouse models, a large cohort of RUNX1 mutant patients with banked samples, and basic molecular techniques to understand the molecular mechanism of mutant RUNX1 mediated leukemogenesis and lineage specification and identify novel targeted therapies in this pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lyme disease, caused by the tick-borne bacterial pathogen Borrelia burgdorferi, persists in the United States and parts of Europe. The project focuses on understanding how a select set of B. burgdorferi antigens that support microbial virulence contributes to pathogen persistence in the tick-rodent infection cycle and pathogenesis in mammalian hosts. Knowledge of these processes is critical for the development of novel preventative and/or therapeutic strategies to combat the infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the vacuolar protein sorting 35 ortholog (VPS35) gene are a recently discovered cause of autosomal dominant, familial Parkinson's disease (PD). Our studies aim to explore novel mechanisms by which mutant forms of VPS35 lead to dopaminergic neuronal degeneration in rat models of PD. These studies will have important implications for understanding the molecular pathophysiology of VPS35-associated PD and for future drug development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have identified 2.5-fold higher prevalence of doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity (DIC) in African American (AA) than European American survivors yet the biological basis of this racial disparity in DIC is poorly understood. We will use human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes derived from AA survivors to discover novel genetic variants for DIC and validate the mechanisms by which these genetic variants influence this potentially fatal drug complication. This knowledge will provide clinicians with a validated genomic tool to predict if a patient will experience DIC and a route to discover genotype-specific cardioprotective drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal aims to design proteins with high precision that can tightly and selectively bind to any small- molecule ligand. By designing small-molecule-binding proteins from scratch, this project aims to i) test and extend our understanding of the essential ingredients used by proteins for molecular recognition, ii) obtain atomic-level control of the protein/small-molecule interface, and iii) set the stage for the development of proteins that could serve as novel sensors, enzymes, drug delivery vehicles, or pharmaceuticals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Combining immunotherapies with other cancer drugs has emerged as a new hope for late-stage cancer patients, however, the lack of a principled approach to identify such effective combinations often led to poorly designed clinical trials. The proposed research engages state-of-art Artificial Intelligence techniques with drug-induced transcriptomic changes to identify drugs that synergize with immunotherapies and prioritize them for clinical trials. Its application, as well as the career development pursued by the investigator, will rationalize clinical trials, identify new treatments for advanced cancers, and advance precision immuno-oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The computer vision technologies and machine learning methods applied in this grant will facilitate a precision medicine approach for nephrotic syndrome patients through automated histologic assessment of renal biopsies and comprehensive characterization of kidney structure, function, and molecular endophenotypes. The computational pathology framework and understanding of biology and disease trajectory will serve as a support tool to guide pathologists and nephrologists in kidney research, clinical trials, and clinical care for proteinuric glomerulonephropathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor-derived exosomes are mediators of aggressive distant metastasis by contributing to the establishment of a pre-metastatic niche. Therefore, it is critical to investigate the molecular mechanism(s) that drive tumor- derived exosome-mediated immune modulation and pre-metastatic niche formation for aggressive metastasis in TNBC. Furthermore, determining the mechanisms that drive the aggressive metastasis in TNBC will lead to developing novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome-wide association studies have identified a wealth of non-coding regions in the human genome associated with human health. A goal of these studies is an improved understanding of the etiology of the disease and the construction of animal models that precisely mimic the human condition. Towards these efforts, we will construct maps of non-coding regions between mouse and human that share similar functions, which will transform our ability to develop better organismic models of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To interrupt the cycle of obesity that runs in families, it is important to identify early and modifiable risk factors that affect infants’ appetite. This study proposes that maternal and infant sleep and circadian rhythms influence infant appetite development and may be targeted to reduce obesity risk in the first year of life. Thus, studying how maternal-infant sleep and circadian rhythm patterns are associated with infant appetite, and how they together impact infant weight gain, will inform (1) our understanding of behavioral factors related to intergenerational obesity risk transmission, and (2) our development of critically needed behavioral interventions that effectively reduce obesity risk and promote cardiometabolic health among infants, women, and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease is a significant and growing public health problem that currently affects an estimated >37 million Americans. The NIDDK-sponsored prospective Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC) Study was established to identify factors leading to worsening of chronic kidney disease and to understand the complex relationship between kidney dysfunction, cardiovascular disease, death, and other clinical and patient- centered outcomes. The overall purpose of the proposed renewal of the Kaiser Permanente Northern California/University of California, San Francisco CRIC Clinical Center is to complete follow-up of its existing Phase 4 participants as part of the anticipated overall eligible CRIC cohort of >2100 adults with chronic kidney disease, with a focus on ascertaining clinical outcomes, creating mechanisms for future data collection and analyses, and generating tools and resources to facilitate ongoing use of CRIC data and biospecimens by the broader scientific community during and beyond the final phase of the CRIC Study.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deep crypt secretory cells are important for maintaining colonic homeostasis and express a class of proteins— host defense peptides—known to be dysregulated in intestinal inflammatory disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Organ preservation, storage, and transport technology is of paramount importance to the field of organ transplant and plays a lifesaving role, yet organ transplantation still suffers from very narrow time windows for organ transport. If preservation techniques could be sufficiently advanced, more time would be available to improve the allocation of donated organs leading to reduced geographic restriction, faster patient recovery, drastically shorter hospital stays, and greatly diminished healthcare costs – all while tackling the biggest challenge of all – to increase the amount of available organs for transplant and improve patient outcomes. This proposal aims to further develop organ storage technology to extend the time with which kidneys can be transported and successfully transplanted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) represents the major cause of morbidity and mortality in diabetic subjects with insulin resistance. In these studies, we will examine whether a novel drug may be effective at attenuating atherosclerosis by burning fat, reversing hyperinsulinemia/insulin resistance and reducing plasma lipids. In addition, we will explore how the diabetic milieu (hyperinsulinemia and hyperglycemia) may alter the metabolism and normal activity of immune cells (macrophages) to accelerate atherosclerosis.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will study nearly 2500 patients to better understand the factors and pathways leading to end stage kidney failure, cardiovascular disease, and premature death in individuals with diminished kidney function, using data collected both in clinic visits and home-based tests. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposal seeks to improve mental health, pregnancy, and HIV outcomes among pregnant and postpartum women living with HIV with common mental health disorders in Kenya. We will tailor a collaborative care model for peripartum women with HIV experiencing mental health symptoms and evaluate its impact on their mental health, antenatal, and HIV care outcomes. We will actively engage key stakeholders throughout the process and assess scalability and sustainability through multi-method approaches. This study will contribute to the overall goal of achieving optimal health outcomes for women living with HIV and their families in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The research proposed in this application will advance the genetics of addiction by using innovative technology to provide experimental measurement of the consequences of thousands of genetics variants in regions of the human genome that code for proteins, as well as those regions that turn genes on and off. By contributing significantly to an understanding of the molecular contributions to addiction, this work will enable future development of treatments that directly target its underlying biological basis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There is a compelling need to foster the development and research careers of clinician-scientist faculty at accredited academic institutions that graduate complementary and integrative health (CIH) professionals both to ensure high-fidelity innovative research on CIH and advance the science of CIH, but also to expose students to critical thinking and careers in research. The overarching goal of this application is to create a virtual resource center for REsearch Across Complementary and Integrative Health (REACH) clinical institutions to provide resources for collaborative research across clinician-scientist faculty located at these institutions. This REACH Center will take advantage of and build upon a successful effort begun in 2020 by Drs Herman and Coulter, called the RAND Center for Collaborative Research in CIH (RAND Center).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The CRIC study was to established in 2003 to study chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression by identifying novel predictors of CKD progression and risk factors for cardiovascular disease among individuals with CKD. The CRIC Study recruited and followed a racially and ethnically diverse cohort of 5,625 participants and has defined trajectories of CKD progression, catalogued development, and evolution of comorbidities in CKD, and identified a diverse array of factors that explain the progression and complications of CKD in adults. The final phase of CRIC will focus on ascertaining clinical outcomes for all participants including those enrolled in the at home sub-protocols and integrate data from multiple domains to identify sub-phenotypes underlying the heterogeneity in CKD progression outcomes and create mechanisms for future data collection via linkages with external sources of health data to generate tools and resources to facilitate ongoing use of CRIC data and biospecimens by a broad group of investigators in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This study proposed to evaluate the effectiveness of repeated, systemic delivery of extracellular vesicles (EVs) in three doses secreted by Wharton’ Jelly derived mesenchymal stem cells (WJMSCs) in a murine myocardial infraction (MI) model. The optimal dose and regimen will be determined by evaluating the improvement in cardiac function and reduction in remodeling and proceed to the translation toward clinical effectiveness by evaluating in large animal (porcine) MI model. The study will also evaluate the molecular mechanism of EVs for cardiac repair and establishing characterization criteria to reduce donor-to-donor variability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Defects in mitochondrial and lysosomal functions are common hallmarks of aging and many aging- associated degenerative diseases, but whether and how these two organelles interact to affect cell fitness and disease development are poorly understood. We propose to investigate a novel mitochondria- to-lysosome proteostatic signaling pathway that causes vacuolar/lysosomal damage. The results may help us to better understand the mechanism of endolysosomal stress that is observed during aging and in aging-associated degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this K01 Career Development Award, I will lead an in-depth study of risk factors associated with poor maternal and newborn health outcomes in a Medicaid population with disabilities in Texas to better understand the disparities faced by this population with respect to race and ethnicity, area-level socioeconomic conditions, and quality of healthcare. This study will include birthing people and their newborns across an urban-rural continuum and diverse socioeconomic environments with a comprehensive assessment of low birthweight, small for gestational age, preterm birth, neonatal mortality, and four quality of care indicators. The findings will add to our knowledge of adverse birth outcomes among racial and ethnic minorities with disabilities in the U.S. and inform targeted interventions and policies aimed at reducing the health inequities experienced by this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death worldwide and new therapies are needed to treat this very prevalent disease. We have identified a protein called STK25 that is able to downregulate one of the central signaling pathways that controls how strong the heart is able to contract. We propose to study how this protein is able to regulate cardiac function and whether this new relationship has therapeutic potential in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early recognition of cognitive impairment and timeliness in Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) diagnoses are key to optimal dementia care. To the best of our knowledge, no studies have examined the effect of the annual wellness visit (AWV) policy on reducing disparities in ADRD diagnosis and health outcomes among community-dwelling Medicare beneficiaries with ADRD, based on the Institute for Healthcare Improvement (IHI) 4Ms framework of an age-friendly health system, 4Ms: "what matters," "mentation," "mobility," and "medication." This 5-year project will adopt IHI's 4Ms framework, as recommended by the Alzheimer's Association, in conducting a convergent parallel mixed-methods study to address this gap to inform AWV policy and practice guideline development to improve the timeliness of ADRD diagnosis and post- ADRD-diagnosis dementia care, thereby decreasing health disparities among Medicare beneficiaries with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebrovascular dysfunction, which severely impacts brain health, is an early pathological feature of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA) brains. The mechanisms that link cerebrovascular dysfunction to AD and CAA widespread pathology are not known. The proposed study will help in understanding how endothelial cell mitochondria mediate cerebrovascular dysfunction and how mitochondria-mediated endothelial activation signaling pathways contribute to neuroinflammation, precipitating AD and CAA pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative For organisms to reproduce, their genomic DNA must be copied faithfully. This process, DNA replication, requires frequent repair events to ensure that it occurs efficiently and without error. We seek to identify and understand factors in microorganisms that facilitate repair of blocked replication in order to understand similar processes in humans that prevent cancer, aging and genetic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Durable antitumor immunity requires presentation of tumor antigens by professional antigen presenting cells (APCs) for priming of antitumor T cell responses, but APC function is repressed in the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. This project will decipher the mechanisms of the unique immune stimulation provided by recombinant poliovirus, resulting from non-lethal infection and pro-inflammatory activation of APCs. The significance of this research is the potential to achieve significant clinical benefits for cancer patients by reinstating tumor immune surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spending time outdoors increases children’s physical activity and improves mental, cognitive and behavioral health outcomes, but measurement of outdoor time is varied and often self- or caregiver-reported. The proposed research will capitalize on existing data from several trials to develop a set of analytic guidelines for using accelerometer measured ambient light sensor data as an objective measure of children’s outdoor time. With the ubiquitous use of accelerometers in research, these guidelines can be applied to further understand the relationship between health and the outdoors, identify disparities in access to outdoor settings, and inform policies and regulations to promote physical activity and outdoor time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of comprehensive metrics to determine the maturation status of pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes (PSC-CMs) remains a key obstacle to assess the effects of ongoing efforts to mature PSC-CMs. We have developed a novel entropy-based metric that enables quantitative assessment of PSC-CM maturation, and this proposal focuses on using this metric to directly compare PSC-CMs matured by new and existing strategies with native CMs undergoing maturation. This will provide quantitative and mechanistic insights into generating mature adult CMs from PSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Enterovirus D68 (EV-D68) is a viral pathogen that causes moderate to severe respiratory illness in children and immunocompromised person, and in rare cases also leads neurological complications such as polio-like acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) as well as death. Currently there are no approved antiviral drugs or vaccines for the diseases associated with EV-D68 infection. To address the unmet medical need, we will develop potent and selective EV-D68 2Apro inhibitors with favorable pharmacokinetic properties and use them as chemical probes to validate EV-D68 2Apro as a viable antiviral drug target in both in vitro cell cultures and in vivo mouse model studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE IBD is a model, complex trait for which genetic factors play a substantial role. Major effect loci show major differences in allele frequencies and effect sizes across populations, for which expanding case-control genetic data will provide substantial mechanistic insight. Treatments for Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis are increasingly diverging, and multi-omic data integration, with serial tissue and blood-based biosampling in clinical scenarios of unmet clinical needs, will broadly advance Precision IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations affecting enzymes involved in epigenetic regulation are frequently identified in human developmental disorders and cancers, but how they facilitate disease pathogenesis remains poorly understood. This project proposes to invent and apply novel molecular and genetic tools to investigate the regulation and function of a conserved chromatin modification – methylation of histone H3 lysine 36 (H3K36). Our studies are expected to establish the conceptual framework required for developing therapeutic strategies against diseases driven by abnormal H3K36 methylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Schizophrenia (SCZ) has a tremendous economic and societal impact, which could be mitigated by the discovery of novel treatment interventions targeting specific neuronal circuit dysfunction, especially early in the illness. The overarching goal of this proposal is to establish whether, by acutely enhancing prefrontal oscillatory activity, we see a corresponding improvement in working memory (WM) function in early course SCZ patients. Building on these findings, future neuromodulation-based treatment interventions applying chronic doses of TBS may more persistently ameliorate/restore DLPFC oscillatory parameters and related WM impairments in SCZ patients early during the illness, thus significantly improving their cognitive functioning and overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aortic stenosis ultimately leads to heart failure and death, but valve replacement is curative. For many patients, valve replacement is performed too late, after damage to the heart muscle is no longer reversible, resulting in persistent symptoms and increased risk for death. The goal of my research is to identify compounds within the blood that can serve as an early warning that the heart is struggling to overcome aortic stenosis and can therefore help physicians plan the optimal timing of valve replacement surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to the public health because primary and metastatic central nervous system (CNS) tumors are associated with high morbidity and mortality; and few effective therapies are currently available. Upon conclusion of the study, we will have developed and validated a CSF liquid biopsy assay for early molecular characterization and monitoring of primary or metastatic tumors affecting the CNS. This will facilitate the incorporation of precision medicine strategies in the management of adult and pediatric patients with primary or metastatic CNS tumors, and avoid the need for brain surgery in some patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep disordered breathing (SDB) is a heritable common disorder associated with adverse cardiometabolic outcomes, and the underlying molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. We will develop a novel pathway-level transcriptional Mendelian randomization approach to identify causal molecular associations for SDB. This study will improve our understanding of the underlying biological background of SDB and inform novel biomarker and/or treatment target for SDB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cells with activated proto-oncogenes or inactivated tumor-suppressor genes remain pre-cancerous and asymptomatic until elusive mechanisms transform them into cancer cells. We discovered that PITX1 and SOX2 become expressed when skin epithelial cells form squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs), and propose to determine how their expression is regulated, and whether and how they reprogram pre-cancerous epithelial cells into SCC cells. Answers to these questions will improve the mechanistic understanding of tumor promotion and reveal novel approaches to prevent or treat SCCs, which kill >20,000 patients in the United States each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Narrative In multicellular organisms, distant cells can readily exchange information by sending out signals via molecules enclosed in nano-sized extracellular vesicles and particles (EVPs). EVPs are involved in the pathogenesis of diverse diseases including cancer and provide an attractive disease marker for non-invasive early disease detection. A high throughput optical nanotweezer and enhanced Raman spectroscopy technology will be developed for understanding the heterogeneity of single nanosized EVPs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of empathy is a core symptom of behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) that negatively impacts daily functioning and is highly distressing to families and caregivers. A relatively unexplored but promising avenue of scientific inquiry is the role of autonomic nervous system (ANS) activity in empathy loss in bvFTD. The overarching goal of this project is to use a smartwatch to identify abnormalities in autonomic activity that are robustly associated with empathy loss in bvFTD and validate digital markers of autonomic abnormalities against behavioral measures of empathy loss and neuroimaging of the salience network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: In an effort to overcome the ability of numerous cancers to evade the immune system, a drug lead development campaign utilizing cutting-edge drug discovery methods to identify small molecule inhibitors of the lysophosphatidic acid (LPA) subtype 5 (LPAR5) receptor is proposed. Activation of the LPAR5 subtype, blocks antitumor immunity by inhibiting activation of tumor killing by cytotoxic T lymphocytes, critical for eliminating cancer cells. Small molecule inhibitors of the LPAR5 receptor should cause a reversal of the inhibition of cytotoxic T cell activation and re- energize the anti-tumor immune response to treat immune-resistant cancer. Hit compounds identified in preliminary studies support this hypothesis and form solid premise for the project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE: The K24 proposal will support Dr. Robert Peck to train clinical investigators in the conduct of patient-oriented cardiovascular disease research in Tanzania and Kenya, and to conduct a new study that investigates putative biomarkers of diastolic dysfunction in people living with and without HIV in Tanzania. United States trainees will spend ~50% of their time at international research sites, which have onsite Weill Cornell faculty such as Dr. Peck, long-standing international collaborators, and outstanding environments for research training. All of the projects focus on patient-oriented research on cardiovascular disease and offer trainees a broad experience in the conduct of mentored research in the topics of global cardiovascular disease epidemiology, clinical trials and implementation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced age is associated with distinct changes in physical capabilities, cognitive functions, and the experience of pain. Despite known overlap between these changes, the majority of research to date has investigated these domains separately. This project will provide an established investigator with the skills necessary to pursue future research from a perspective which integrates principles and concepts from of each of these fields; to ultimately address broader issues including recent epidemics related to relief of chronic pain and age-related cognitive disorders (e.g. mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer’s, other dementias).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The storage and future research use of newborn bloodspots has itself experienced a long history of national controversy given that state newborn screening programs do not obtain informed consent for collection and testing, and only a few states have subsequently added consent for the research use of leftover bloodspots. Ongoing lawsuits among some state programs and policy debates at both the state and federal levels have further mired any progress to promote the use of newborn screening bloodspots for important health research, including studies that assess health disparities. We will address this national problem using an implementation science framework to assess consenting quality and implement an electronic consent progress within hospitals serving diverse and underserved populations for the retention and research use of residual dried bloodspots.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The importance of early disease detection in Parkinson's disease (PD), dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), and multiple system atrophy (MSA) is demonstrated by the failure of promising clinical trials to slow disease progression, quite possibly because those interventions occur when the disease is already established and too advanced. In the current grant period, we have identified highly predictive biomarkers in the spinal fluid and on MRI imaging that allow for predicting a future diagnosis of PD/DLB or MSA when the disease is still at a limited stage without motor or cognitive symptoms or signs. We now propose in this renewal application to apply these promising markers to an even earlier stage, when only sleep abnormalities are present (REM sleep behavior disorder), in order to allow for detection of these neurodegenerative diseases at a prodromal stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Penn State PROMISE program (Penn State Research training in Oncology and Medicine to Inspire Student Engagement) is an holistic approach to inspire, attract, and retain the next generation of cancer researchers and oncologists. PROMISE will instill in participants a gestalt understanding of cancer as a disease (how it is prevented, controlled, and treated), while stimulating interest in oncology careers and providing the skills needed for durable research careers. In the long-term, PROMISE will promote a deep and life-long understanding of how cancer research impacts the lives of individuals in the 21st century, which will drive the on-going discovery of new knowledge by retaining a diverse cohort of trainees in cancer research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project will investigate the impact of tick seasonal activity patterns on populations of human  pathogens carried by black-legged ticks. Different seasonal activity patterns may cause dramatic changes  in parasite populations including population extinctions or explosions. The proposed research provides  the framework to investigate the impact of seasonal activity on the multitude of disease systems involving  multiple host species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chromosome segregation errors cause aneuploidy, a hallmark of cancer and a major cause of birth defects and mental illness. Kinetochores execute chromosome segregation by bridging chromosomal centromeres and spindle microtubules. The proposed project will identify the molecular rules that govern kinetochore assembly and show how errors in this process can cause aneuploidy; the findings can be exploited for diagnosis and therapeutic intervention in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the clinical benefits of antiretroviral therapy, persons with HIV remain at high risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, which is a growing clinical and public health concern as the HIV population ages. This study will adapt an intervention promoting statin adherence from the general population to persons with HIV and evaluate the adapted intervention’s acceptability and feasibility by conducting a pilot in an HIV clinic. This grant will produce preliminary data and a prototype intervention for future intervention studies aiming to improve atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease prevention efforts for persons with HIV.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Treatment models applied with more than 400,000 children in out-of-home-care (OOHC) settings show limited and inconsistent effects on children’s rehabilitation and mitigation of long-term sequelae of developmental trauma. To address this concern, this project aims to develop and evaluate the Developmental Interactions Workshop Series (DIWS), a targeted professional development program that builds capacity among caregivers and care teams to improve the relational environment within the residential care milieu by increasing the breadth and frequency of developmentally enriching interaction between caregivers and children. This new approach provides a method for boosting the rehabilitative impact of OOHC services through widespread dissemination of a broadened paradigm for recovery in OOHC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular diseases, which arise from a complex interplay between genetic predisposition and environmental influences, remain the leading cause of global death. The current proposal aims to take advantage of the human induced pluripotent cell-derived endothelial cell platform to establish a model system to stratify the patient risk of genetic variants in nicotine receptors for smoking-induced vascular diseases, and to study the potential mechanisms, with the ultimate goal to discover biomarkers for diagnosis and precise treatments for cardiovascular diseases and risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Change in personality and behavior is one of the clinical criteria for the diagnosis of dementia. To further understand the evolution of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, the proposed work aims to better define the timing and trajectory of personality change with the onset of mild cognitive impairment and the transition to dementia. Further, the proposed research on the behavioral and biological processes that lead to dementia among individuals with a vulnerable personality profile will contribute to the development of tailored interventions to increase resilience against cognitive decline and risk of dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasingly, organelles are been found to signal to each other via intimate contacts. This new mode of signaling, whereby information is transferred without the organelles fusing, has wide-ranging impacts on health and disease. I propose to create an electrochemical atlas of organelles, apply it to study aberrant inter-organelle contacts in neurodegenerative disease and thereby identify common pathways one can target to restore contacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pregestational diabetes is the number one non-genetic factor in inducing human congenital heart defects; however, the epigenetic mechanism and memories in the offspring hearts and cardiomyocytes are still unknown. Revealing the role of hypoxia and hypoxia inducible factor 1 in maternal diabetes-induced DNA hypermethylation during embryonic heart development will guide the potential development of inhibitors to hypoxia and DNA methylation and hyperoxia in reducing CHDs in diabetic pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The plasticity and functional diversity of regulatory T cells (Tregs) is essential for the maintenance of healthy immunity but it is also exploited in disease. Our findings implicate β-catenin, TCF-1, and HEB in partnering with Foxp3 to independently regulate the diverse Treg suppressive activities which can be modulated during chronic inflammation. Our current findings support the hypothesis that Wnt/β-catenin signaling differentially regulates Treg suppressive functions and diversity, by controlling access of Foxp3 and HEB to select chromatin sites bound by Tcf-1 which we will address in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is a gold standard treatment for patients with advanced coronary artery disease, however saphenous vein graft (SVG) failure after CABG is a pressing clinical problem, with 40- 50% of SVGs failing within 5-10 years, and there are no clinically available proven treatments. We aim to develop growth and remodeling models of vein graft arterialization, informed and validated with animal and human data, culminating in a novel fluid solid growth model of vein graft disease progression that will be used to test a novel 3D printed device for prevention of graft failure. Our ultimate goal is to increase mechanistic understanding of SVG disease progression, develop a device to mitigate failure, and ultimately improve outcomes of CABG patients, for whom there are limited treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While some patients with pancreatic cancer are living longer, additional approaches, including combinatorial therapies against new targets are needed. Therefore, we propose to investigate a validated therapeutic target, Redox factor-1 (Ref-1), alone and in combinations that selectively kill the tumor by impinging on critical pathways the tumor is using to survive. After advancing the first-generation Ref-1 inhibitor (APX3330) to a phase I clinical trial in adult patients, we have identified next generation Ref-1 inhibitors, a strategy to screen for patients that have sensitivity to Ref-1 inhibition, and molecular targets that are likely to synergize with Ref-1 inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In this proposal, our interdisciplinary team brings together expertise and stakeholders from neuroscience basic and clinical research, cognitive and social psychology, and experimental methods education to develop a unique set of curricula focused on increasing rigor and transparency in biomedical research. Through modules that focus on the decision-making crossroads at various phases of the research process, we aim to address the root causes of the ‘Reproducibility Crisis’ and set the stage for the next frontier of neuroscience research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our studies will define the role(s) of septin6 group proteins in murine and human hematopoiesis with a focus on the unique versus overlapping roles of Septin6, Septin8, and Septin11, specifically in hematopoietic cell migration and homing, differentiation, proliferation, and engraftment and correlate these phenotypes with cytokinesis, cell cycle, polarity, apoptosis and the aging phenotype. We will investigate the nature of the abnormal blood and marrow findings in humans with mutations of SEPTIN6 that we have recently described.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Glioblastoma Multiforme is the most common and deadliest cancer in the central nervous system. Our research seeks to take existing patient genomics information and translate that through biological modeling to understand the molecular mechanism of the disease and associated co-morbidities. Through our approach, we will identify patient specific pathways driving this disease, providing a much needed advance towards personalized medicine for this most deadly of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: After an RNA is transcribed, it contains numerous regulatory elements within the RNA transcript that enable trans-interacting proteins and regulatory RNAs to regulate processing steps including splicing, RNA decay, and translation into protein. Although the development of genomics approaches has enabled the large-scale mapping of protein:RNA interaction sites, sifting through these thousands (or more) sites per protein to identify the small subset that correspond with functional regulation of RNA processing remains underexplored. In this work, we will perform large-scale assays to screen these interactions to generate true regulatory maps for RBPs and regulatory RNAs, building unique insights into the RNA processing landscape in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Leveraging our previous HIV surveillance work with health departments, the goal of this study is to refine, based on community feedback, an mHealth app, WiseApp, to recruit, screen, enroll, and retain a large digital cohort of people with HIV (PWH) over age 18 years (N=1000) who have non-sustained viral suppression (nVS) or who have no evidence of HIV labs within the past 12 months. The study will be conducted in the Deep South, the area of the country with the highest rates of morbidity and mortality, including the states of Alabama, Louisiana, and Mississippi. The findings from this study will inform efforts to recruit large, digital cohorts of PWH, will be among the first to demonstrate effective methods of retaining digital cohorts for HIV as well as other health conditions, and help identify multilevel factors that contribute to nVS in the Deep South, thereby elucidating areas for intervention in future research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease remains an enormous health burden in the United States. Abnormal Ca2+ release in the diseased heart is closely coupled to increased oxidative stress, yet clinical trials aimed to reduce this stress have largely failed to elicit any functional benefits on cardiac Ca2+ handling. This proposal will uncover new molecular mechanisms that link oxidative stress to the regulation of Ca2+ release, and provide insights into new therapeutic approaches to reduce Ca2+-dependent arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Heart disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States and mitochondrial dysfunction is a major contributor in disease progression. Better understanding of the pathological mechanisms underlying mitochondrial dysfunction during heart disease will improve preventive and therapeutic interventions. In this proposal, we will investigate the function and mechanism of a novel mitochondrial Ca2+ signaling regulatory factor, namely, family with sequence similarity 210 member A (FAM210A), which is required for maintaining mitochondrial homeostasis and cardiac health. These studies will lead to identification of novel therapeutic targets for treatment of mitochondrial cardiomyopathy and ischemic heart failure such as myocardial infarction among other mitochondrial disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fracture of the tibia and other osteoporotic fractures have a heavy societal burden with devastating consequences including morbidity and death. This project explores the role of saphenous nerve injury in controlling tibial bone mineral density through sensory nerves. A greater understanding of the impact of nerve injury on bone mass will aid in elucidating new risk factors predisposing individuals to tibial fracture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is consistent with the National Cancer Institute’s commitment to advancing behavioral health in cancer patients and to implementation science as a core research opportunity. The proposed project will combine these priority areas by developing interdisciplinary research infrastructure to support research on the dissemination and implementation of behavioral health interventions for older adults with cancer. The proposed Center for Implementation Research in Cancer in Later Life (CIRCL) will provide training and research support that will infuse dissemination and implementation research methods into new and existing projects across all stages of behavioral intervention development for older adults with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it represents a new and alternative strategy to the urgent threat of infections by opportunistic fungal pathogens like the Candida spp. By focusing on how the stress response regulatory networks in the commensal yeast diverged from related non- commensal relatives, this research will generate novel, foundational knowledge on the adaptive strategies and potential weaknesses of the opportunistic pathogens, which will enable the future identification of novel antifungal strategies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIGMS core mission of supporting basic research to increase our understanding of biological processes and reduce illness.

PROJECT_TITLE: Evolution of Stress Response Gene Regulatory Network in a Commensal and Opportunistic Yeast Pathogen

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative High levels of androgens in women is associated with disrupted neuroendocrine function and infertility, whereas low androgens decrease sexual behavior and fertility, and induce fatigue, depression, and bone loss in both sexes. High density of androgen receptors is observed in the brain, but their function in specific neuronal populations is unknown. We will use genetic mouse models and molecular tools to determine the role of androgens receptor in chemically defined subsets of neurons and the underlying mechanisms associated with reproductive deficits caused by altered androgens signaling in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative To assemble and sustain functional tissues, cells need to establish and maintain an asymmetric organization of their membrane and cellular contents, a phenomenon referred to as cell polarity. Polarity must be coordinated between cells and controlled by extracellular signals in order for cells to behave normally; loss of this coordination is associated with developmental defects, early embryonic lethality and metastatic cancer. This proposal makes use of innovative experimental methods to study how cells polarize and how polarity is controlled during development, which is relevant to the NIGMS mission because it will increase understanding of a basic biological process and lay the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Beidas, Rinad Sary PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing access to firearms is a key strategy for suicide prevention in youth, yet many young people live in homes with firearms that are not safely secured. The proposed work has the potential to radically impact public health by testing which strategies are most effective in helping pediatric primary care clinicians to deliver an evidence-based firearm safety promotion program in pediatric primary care as a universal suicide prevention strategy. This clinical trial will take place in two large health systems in Michigan and Colorado and will use principles from behavioral economics to support clinician behavior change while also gathering information about effectiveness, acceptability, and costs, in order to inform large-scale program implementation efforts within the Mental Health Research Network and nationally to save the lives of American youth. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Binge-eating behavior is a central feature of eating disorders (e.g., binge-eating disorder, bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa-binge-eating/purging subtype) and is associated with higher rates of psychopathology, psychosocial impairment, medical comorbidity, and more severe obesity, all of which pose significant public health problems. Passive detection of binge eating episodes combined with a context-based reminder intervention could assist a patient in resuming healthy eating patterns. We propose developing and testing a smartwatch app that identifies binge eating behavior and provides CBT strategies to the patient after the episode.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: How the body processes O2 is central to human health with metalloproteins being essential for maintaining proper regulation. Thus, the function, and dysfunction of key health related processes can be understood within the context of protein active site structures. These issues are being investigated with an integrative approach that leverages the power of synthetic chemistry with protein science/molecular biology to develop artificial metalloproteins as a means to establish key structure-function relationships that are inherent for superior processing of O2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL TMC - PROJECT NARRATIVE  Many stressors, including aging, can cause cells can enter a state termed senescence. Senescent cells are likely important drivers of many age-related pathologies, from neurodegeneration to cancer, but are poorly characterized. Within the SenNet Consortium, we will establish a Tissue Mapping Center to characterize senescent cells -- molecularly, spatially and during aging -- in three very different human tissues: ovary, breast and skeletal muscle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will be the first to compare lower-intensity (standard) and higher-intensity implementation strategies to deliver GlobalConsent—an efficacious web-based sexual-violence prevention program—to men attending six universities across Vietnam. Following a rigorous, mixed-methods, comparative interrupted-time-series design, we will collect novel data to compare implementation fidelity, drivers and outcomes, effectiveness, and cost- effectiveness across implementation strategies groups. Our partnership includes universities also engaged in a violence-prevention training grant (D43TW012188), offering an unparalleled opportunity for capacity strengthening and evidence generation to guide national leaders on best strategies for launching GlobalConsent at scale, to address a gendered risk factor in adolescence, and thereby, improve an array of health outcomes into adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH) has an established grants management system that has limited capacity to support pre-award grants management processes for the researchers in the institution. This application proposes to create pre-award grants management processes at Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH) and other local institutions by leveraging the existing >35 years collaborative partnership with the University of Washington (UW). This will be achieved by training two senior KNH administrators through hands-on training at UW and NIH, who will then facilitate development of institutional pre-award processes, and building capacity of other research administrators at KNH and other Kenyan institutions that receive NIAID funds through job training, mentorship, and participation in research administrators’ community of practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL OF SOUTH AFRICA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Very few pregnant women were included in the clinical trials of a new all-oral 6-month regimen for the treatment of RR-TB. In the proposed study we will: 1) compare adherence to this new regimen in pregnant and non-pregnant women; 2) determine if there is an association with depression, especially in the postpartum period; and 3) explore the effect of pregnancy on the exposure of drugs in this regimen and determine the concentrations of these drugs in breastmilk and breastfed infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Extrachromosomal circular DNA (eccDNA) elements are known to play a role in a variety of normal and pathological cellular processes; however, isolating and characterizing different classes of eccDNA to determine their role in these processes is a unique challenge. To address this, Phinomics is developing an innovative, unbiased technology that provides a comprehensive toolkit to isolate every size of eccDNA molecules in an intact state suitable for next-generation sequencing together with a suite of biophysical and novel bioinformatic methods to characterize these molecules. Surveillance based on eccDNA biomarkers is aimed at a minimally invasive strategy to determine the immune response to therapies, predict recurrence likelihood, and monitor residual disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Global Infectious Disease Research Administration Develop Program for Low-and-Middle-Income Countries is an intervention to increase the capacity of Research Administrators and Finance Managers of NIAID/NIH projects to support the mission of the institute in ameliorating infectious diseases in the world. This investment by the institute has rippling positive effects, on not only the prime institution, but also other local in-country institutions as well as regional institutions; through this, information of funding opportunities for health research, establishing grant management offices, and strengthening existing ones, has been implemented. It has brought great awareness to the business of grants administration, among Faculty Researchers, and institution management support for new policies and procedures for the implementation of external funding; it has also impacted on internal funding operations, for global health or social researches, by other international or local funders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Conference on  Protein Homeostasis in Health and Disease  April 24 – 28, 2024 PROJECT NARRATIVE Proteins are composed of polymers of amino acids (or polypeptides) and execute essential tasks in all living organisms. Protein function is critically dependent on the folding of their constituent polypeptides into active three-dimensional structures through the interactions of molecular chaperones. Protein homeostasis is achieved by balanced synthesis, folding, translocation and degradation of proteins. Experimental evidence accumulated in the recent past has revealed that failure of protein homeostasis in aging leads to some of the most devastating diseases affecting humanity. The latter include common neurodegenerative disorders, such as Parkinson’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease, common metabolic disorders such as Diabetes and a host of other age- related conditions. The Cold Spring Harbor Meeting on Protein Homeostasis in Health and Disease brings together experts in diverse aspects of protein folding, the cellular response to protein misfolding and diseases and therapeutic approaches for age-associated diseases of protein homeostasis. As such it serves as the premier clearinghouse for ideas on how to eventually translate the basic discoveries in the area to future treatments of recalcitrant diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative The Columbia Population Research Center (CPRC) will contribute to the public’s health by facilitating and supporting collaboration for researchers from across Columbia University who, because they are in different departments, schools, or disciplines, would not otherwise connect. Our activities will enhance affiliates’ research in five primary research areas – children, youth, and families; climate and environment; reproductive health and HIV/AIDS; immigration/migration; and urbanism and neighborhoods – with a cross-cutting focus on inequalities and policies, and a particular emphasis on promoting the development of junior scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our lack of understanding of the mechanisms of T cell mediated protection against Tuberculosis, a disease responsible for 1.6 million deaths in 2021, has hampered our ability to develop new vaccine strategies. Antigen- independent T cell activation, termed bystander activation, has shown protective effects in response to M.tb infection but has not been fully explored or characterized. Here, we will comprehensively analyze the role of bystander activation in two T cell subsets in the context of M.tb infection to extensively explore this protective pathway as a possible vaccine target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is mainly associated with neonatal meningitis but is also the third leading cause of death from skin and subcutaneous infection. In fact, GBS is increasingly associated with diabetes as a common colonizer of diabetic wounds, but little is known about GBS factors that allow colonization and persistence in the highly inflammatory wound environment. This proposal seeks to understand how GBS metal homeostasis and methylglyoxal detoxification contributes to GBS survival during diabetic wound infection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with transfemoral amputation fall significantly more often than the general population, and when fitted with a traditional prosthetic limb, nearly one-third of people experience severe complications with their prosthetic socket. Today, a secondary procedure called osseointegration is offered to address socket-related issues with a direct bone-anchored prosthesis implant, which offers a novel potential benefit to balance through improved sensation and body control. Understanding the effects of an osseointegrated prosthesis on sensation and postural control will help to identify specific functional movement deficiencies to target during therapy and rehabilitation to decrease fall risk.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In contrast to major food-producing species such as cattle and swine, for which many antimicrobials are labeled for treatment of respiratory disease, there is currently only a single antibiotic (ceftiofur) approved by the FDA for treatment of respiratory disease in goats. Ceftiofur sodium requires daily administration which may decrease efficacy in situations where owner compliance with labeled instructions is lacking. Therefore, there is an urgent need for additional FDA-approved products for treatment of respiratory disease in goats.

PROJECT_TITLE: Analytical method validation to detect and quantify tulathromycin residues in caprine liver

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic pulmonary disease characterized by vascular injury and progressive fibrosis of the lungs. This project aims to develop a bispecific antibody, VTC-890, for the treatment of IPF. Since present therapies for IPF fail to prevent death or improve quality of life for patients, successful commercialization of VTC-890 would ultimately provide profound relief for an incurable, fatal disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Most individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD) do not receive treatment due to persistent, complex and nuanced barriers to OUD care; and OUD commonly co-occurs with depression (dually diagnosed population) further complicating treatment pathways. Using both publicly-available and Medicaid claims data, the goal of this study is to develop a composite index that quantifies the potential to access resources for OUD treatment, examine longitudinal treatment utilization patterns of dually diagnosed individuals to determine the optimal trajectories of depression-OUD treatment combinations, and use the index to contextualize each treatment utilization trajectory. This research addresses an understudied population of those with dual diagnosis and in the long term, will contribute to generating a whole-person view towards the treatment and health outcomes for people with OUD and those dually diagnosed with depression.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Towards a Better Understanding of Access Factors Associated with Treatment and Outcomes among Medicaid Enrollees with Opioid Use Disorder and Depression

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the high prevalence of HPV infections which are the cause of 5% of all human cancers, prevention of HPV-associated malignancies is limited by a lack of antivirals suitable for HPV-infected individuals. In order to address this significant public health burden, we selected ERBB2 as a candidate target for the prevention of HPV-driven pathologies based on high level single cell sequencing approaches and publicly available data on HPV-associated cancer types. Herein we aim to define mechanisms of ERBB2 regulation by HPV, and the contribution of ERBB2 signaling to HPV-driven pathologies, with the goal of targeting ERBB2 via re-purposing FDA-approved drugs for antiviral cancer prevention and perhaps treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the identification of m6A modifications in pre- treatment CD138+ tumor cells that are associated with treatment outcomes of multiple myeloma (MM), the 2nd most common hematologic malignancy and generally incurable, will improve our understanding of early relapse and therapy response. This contribution will be significant because patients at higher risk of treatment failure could be treated with more aggressive strategies up front. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the mortality of MM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this project is to uncover biological and sociological factors that contribute to poor outcomes for prostate cancer in African American men. To address this goal, we propose to leverage a large, national, population-based cohort study (RESPOND) comprised of 12,500 African American men with prostate cancer identified through nine SEER and NPCR U.S. cancer registries. Over the next five years, we will continue to enhance the RESPOND cohort through additional measurement of exposures and outcomes to facilitate translational research that addresses critical scientific questions and hypotheses that have been suggested to contribute to prostate cancer outcomes in African American men, those being access to health care (Aim 1), structural and social neighborhood drivers (Aim 2), modifiable lifestyle factors, co-morbidities and genetics (Aim 3), and histopathologic-based risk prediction (Aim 4).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We discovered a group of neurons in the forebrain, namely proenkephalin (Penk) neurons in the diagonal band of Broca (DBBPenk neurons), promote homeostatic feeding but suppress hedonic feeding, a “healthy eating” behavior that can ensure sufficient nutrition and at the same time avoid obesity. Here we propose to identify the circuitry mechanisms and further reveal the physiological relevance of these neurons, which will provide the necessary framework to develop therapeutic strategies towards treating obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Between 25-50% of adolescents with mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBIs) have substantial mental health sequelae during their recoveries. We will use an experienced team of sites and investigators to develop a clinical tool to predict mental health sequelae in adolescents after mTBI. This tool will provide evidence for clinical decision-making, helping to reduce uncertainty amongst clinicians and decrease health disparities.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-23-008, Development and Validation of a Clinical Tool to Predict Mental Health Sequelae After Mild TBI in Adolescents

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative Firearm violence is a pervasive, preventable public health issue that disproportionately impacts Black youth and young adults due to structural racism in the form of systematic economic disenfranchisement. Economic security policies are promising primary prevention strategies for firearm violence that provide economic support to low-income families, including Black families, who experience persistent inequities in concentrated poverty and associated firearm violence. Our study proposes a series of complementary quantitative and qualitative analyses to evaluate both the effectiveness and potential underlying mechanisms of Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, Minimum Wage, Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, and Earned Income Tax Credit for preventing firearm violence among Black youth and young adults aged 10-34.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE23-005 Evaluating Economic Security Policies to Prevent Firearm-Related Violence and Injuries among Black Youth

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the past few decades, prosthetic hand technology has significantly improved, but rejection rates remain high. This proposal addresses three of the limitations of commercial myoelectric prostheses underlying prosthesis rejection: limited function, versatility, and robustness. We will test and compare the performance of a novel research myoelectric prosthetic hand, the SoftHand Pro, with a commercial hand prosthesis in a large number of individuals with upper limb loss in the laboratory and during daily activities to determine the extent to which the SoftHand Pro can address their unmet needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Human T-cell leukemia virus type-1 (HTLV-1) is an oncogenic human retrovirus which has infected over 20 million people worldwide but lacks any vaccines or direct-acting antivirals. I will characterize the substrate specificity of HTLV-1 protease so that I can design inhibitors to mimic substrate interactions with the protease active site. I will design and characterize novel, resistance-preventing, potent inhibitors against HTLV-1 protease using structural and biochemical techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Dental caries is one of the most prevalent chronic diseases in the world and the oral bacterium Streptococcus mutans is the major etiological agent of this multifactorial disease. We recently discovered that S. mutans tolerates unusually high concentrations of zinc by utilizing the ZccE exporter and ZccR regulator pair. Because zinc can be safely delivered in high concentrations via oral healthcare products, a better understanding of the importance of ZccR to dental caries and determination of ZccR structure can help us devise new anti-caries therapies by specifically targeting S. mutans without damaging either host cells or disturbing the bacteria associated with oral health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitosis is a pivotal point during which a cell divides and gives rise to two genetically identical daughter cells. However, transcriptional programs must also be transmitted to ensure cell identity is properly re-established with each cell division. This proposal will study the molecular mechanisms that allow cells to maintain and faithfully re-establish the proper magnitude of gene expression through mitosis towards understanding how cell fate and identity is encoded.
