IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infertility affects ~48.5 million couples worldwide, and half are due to male factors. This project aims to discover novel mechanisms underlying male reproduction regulated by mitochondrial dynamics. Study findings will provide critical insights into the poorly understood mitochondrial coordination during mammalian germ cell development and may critically inform novel strategies to treat impaired male fertility due to mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to shed light on the fundamental mechanisms by which proteins interact with each other in order to control the flow of regulatory information in the cell. The project uses yeast as a model system to study how protein domains recognize and bind to short peptide sequences in their interaction partners, which is central to the function of signaling proteins and protein modifying enzymes throughout eukaryotic biology, from yeast to humans. The resulting discoveries about the recognition rules and specificity determinants that control the binding of short peptide sequences will further our understanding of cellular regulation mechanisms relevant to human health and pathology, such as tissue differentiation, neoplastic growth, and drug design.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: Rising rates of obesity and its complications in pregnancy may be contributing to escalating risk of obesity and chronic disease in the next generation of children. Recent research has shifted obesity management priorities to preconception weight loss, for which bariatric surgery is becoming increasingly more common in women with severe obesity. Findings from this study will provide much-needed evidence about the benefits and risks of preconception maternal weight loss in general, and specifically by achieving this weight loss after bariatric surgery, on long-term childhood health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of new technology/media forms has often been accompanied by panic over the likely societal and personal harms they might engender, especially with respect to developing youth. The proposed project seeks to inform our understanding of the particular precursors, correlates, and sequelae that may be linked to the escalating presence of smartphone and social media technologies in teens' lives, and to guide us in determining when these technology habits should, and should not, concern policy-makers and care-givers. The project will enact a multi-methodological cross-sequential longitudinal study to investigate the psychological and brain factors that predispose individuals of different ages to intensified use of smartphones and social media (SSM), and to explore the relationship that such habits may have with specific aspects of cognitive and brain development, psychosocial maturation, and everyday functioning.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative While genes are important, an equally important part of our genome is the sequence between genes that controls which genes are switched on or off in each cell of our body, and defects in these “genetic switches” are a major cause of common diseases such as diabetes and cancer. Revolutionary “single cell” methods are allowing scientists to study these genetic switches in thousands of single cells at once, and may lead to the identification of previously unknown types of cells, and to differences between people in the activity of their genetic switches. In this project, we will use a nematode worm as a simple genetic model on which these single cell methods can be improved and comprehensively tested, and get closer to understanding how different cell types arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will help clarify the order of influence among emergent literacy constructs for preschoolers with hearing loss compared to preschoolers with normal hearing. These results will inform our theoretical understanding of the impact of hearing loss on emergent literacy development and may lead to the creation of effective interventions to improve literacy outcomes for children with hearing loss. This research is consistent with the mission of the NIDCD because it will help us understand literacy development for children with hearing loss and may lead to improved literacy outcomes for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The annual meeting of the American Auditory Society focuses on translating basic research in humans in order to improve the lives of people with hearing and balance problems. Support from NIH will enhance clinical and translational research by promoting synergy among basic scientists, clinicians including physicians and audiologists, and those working in industry in the areas of hearing and balance disorders. Highly successful aspects of the meeting include translational and interdisciplinary research sessions that stimulate thinking, interaction among attendees and promote new research collaborations, travel awards for students/residents to present their research, and career development sessions that provide opportunities for all attendees to enhance their career paths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Developmental language disorder (DLD; AKA specific language impairment) results in poor academic and social outcomes and affects 7% of young school age children. Grammatical deficits are hallmarks of this disorder, though sound pattern learning (which emerges in infancy) underlies both grammatical and word learning difficulties experienced by these children. By linking sound pattern learning to both grammatical and word learning deficits, this research will potentially contribute to the earlier identification of children with DLD and also provide new avenues of treatment, and thus is consistent with the mission of the NIH.

PHR: The goal of this Academic-Industrial Partnerships project is to develop, validate, and clinically translate a multimodal intraoral imaging system for oral cancer detection and diagnosis in low resource settings (LRS). PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells rewire their metabolic programs to support tumor growth. We found that metabolic pathways to manage nutrient and redox stress are activated in pancreatic cancer, and that these may represent targetable vulnerabilities. This research proposal will study the mechanisms by which metabolic stress is regulated to define new drug targets and therapies for pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Forty years after the onset of the HIV/AIDS pandemic, still more than 2,000 people per day die of HIV globally. The virus is 100% fatal and, while there are medications that improve and prolong life, there are no cures and no vaccines. We are developing a new model organism that will transform research on the transmission of HIV- 1 and serve as a model for HIV-1 vaccine and cure development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: RELEVANCE Fetal organ development is an intensely physical process that requires coordinated signaling between developing tissues and their surrounding microenvironment to ensure maturation prior to birth. Defects in the timing of morphogenesis or differentiation result in suboptimal organ function and are associated with birth defects and chronic diseases later in life. Here we present a unique combination of experimental approaches to test the innovative hypothesis of a “mechanical clock” that controls the rates of lung, kidney, and pancreas development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This implementation science study utilizes the multiphase optimization strategy (the MOST framework) to comprehensively optimize and evalulate implementation strategies to improve PrEP adherence among young women (≤24 years) at high risk for HIV acquisition in South Africa. The design (1) leverages existing programmatic data and interventions along with the strategic collection of de novo data to inform implementation adjustments intended to promote PrEP uptake, adherence and persistence, then (2) optimizes the existing interventions through modifications of actor/intensity/duration, evaluating the overall effectiveness of these approaches in two short-duration cluster randomized trials embedded within the existing program infrastructure. Finally, population effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the implementation strategies will be estimated through tranmission modeling to inform PrEP scale-up for women in South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying factors that contribute to risk or resilience for long-term post-traumatic distress is a pressing public health problem, particularly for urban racial minorities who are at high risk and experience significant chronic socioenvironmental stress. This work seeks to identify whether dysregulation in emotion regulation neural circuitry two weeks following trauma predicts PTSD and other post-trauma symptom twelve months later among urban Black adults. Moreover, we will examine how environmental risk (e.g., discrimination) and protective factors (e.g., neighborhood cohesino) in the months following trauma impact neurobiological stress systems and how this interplay impacts neural health and risk for chronic distress. These data will advance our understanding of both socioenvironmental and neurobiological factors associated with vulnerability to specific trauma-related pathology and provide an important step toward identifying appropriate early interventions in the wake of trauma.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Recent population-based studies established that teen drivers with ADHD have 30%−40% higher risk of being involved in a motor vehicle crash—the leading cause of death for US teens. This project is designed to identify the specific factors—both within and outside the immediate vehicle environment—that explain why crash risk is elevated for teen drivers with ADHD. The knowledge generated from this project will lead to the development of interventions and programs for teens with ADHD that aim to optimize their safety as independent drivers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Our long-term goal is to understand how cell death takes place during normal animal development and disease. We uncovered a novel cell death process in the nematode C. elegans with similarities to normal and disease-related cell death in humans, and aim to understand the details of this novel killing mechanism. Our studies may, therefore, provide in-roads towards understanding and, perhaps, treatment of degenerative human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT: Cancer immunotherapy is revolutionizing the treatment of cancer, however, less than half of patients treated with immunotherapy experience a response or long-term remission. Recent discoveries suggest that the outcomes from cancer immunotherapies depend on complex interactions among the tumor, host immune system and microbiome. The complexity of this interaction presents a challenging task and a huge unmet need in the education of cancer researchers, because research in this area requires synthesis across multiple disciplines: cancer biology, immunology, microbiology, statistics and bioinformatics. This proposal fills a gap in the education of the cancer researcher and will help train a work force with the knowledge and skills needed to advance interdisciplinary research in cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postoperative Pulmonary Complications are common, costly and drivers of major inpatient morbidity. While risk models predict patients who may be at risk, few evidenced based management strategies exist, this approach has not been updated in light of the wealth of EHR derived data now available in contemporary practice. This study will apply data science to precisely define patient risk and identify modifiable care practices which would from the basis of interventions to reduce risk.

PHR: Narrative: The proposed research will elucidate the roles of thermal K2P channels in controlling trigeminal nociception and their dysfunction as a mechanism underlying trigeminal neuropathic pain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Overall Public Health Relevance  Cochlear neural degeneration (CND) is the loss of nerve connections between the sensory cells and the brain, which occurs in noise-damaged and aging ears. Although not detected by the threshold audiogram, this nerve damage is likely a major contributor to difficulties understanding speech in a noisy environment and may also instigate changes resulting in tinnitus and hyperacusis. Our Research Center aims to understand the prevalence of cochlear synaptopathy, measure/infer its consequences to suprathreshold sound processing, and to identify diagnostic markers. Therapies to reconnect nerves and sensory cells are on the horizon, and proper diagnostics are key to the design of clinical trials. The results are important to the public health, because noise- and ototoxic drug exposures may be damaging the ear well before the effects are seen in the threshold audiogram.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project 1 Narrative – Public Health Relevance  Sensorineural hearing loss can be caused by overexposure to noise, certain ototoxic drugs as well as the aging process itself. Each of these can permanently damage the sensory cells and neurons of the inner ear and lead to problems hearing in noise as well as perceptual anomalies such as tinnitus or hypersensitivity to sound. Here, we use animal models to study the relations between well-characterized patterns of cellular damage and hearing outcomes to refine diagnostic tools for use in human subjects. Such refined diagnostics are increasingly critical as therapeutic approaches to the repair of inner ear damage are coming to clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project 2 Public Health Relevance  The ear damage that underlies the hearing impairments cannot be imaged in living humans. The only way to reveal the patterns of cellular degeneration is by the evaluation of autopsy specimens. This Project will determine the extent of damage to nerve fibers and sensory cells in the inner ears of patients with several of the most common forms of acquired hearing loss. Since therapeutics to regenerate nerves and sensory cells in a damaged inner ear are on the horizon, understanding the damage patterns, and how they relate to the audiometric profiles in the same patients, is key to diagnosis and the selection of subjects for clinical trials.

PHR: NARRATIVE Our Program Project will develop an integrated engineering approach to de-risk emerging immunotherapies during their pre-clinical development and direct them toward the patient populations that stand to benefit the most. This will allow the field to potentially move past historic 5% cancer therapy trial success rates so that more cancer patients benefit from immunotherapy sooner with less risk and at lower cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1 Brain tumors remain among the most malignant and deadly cancers, with adult glioblastoma (GBM) patients having a median survival of 15 months and five-year survival of less than 10 percent. We aim to use new and innovative simulation tools to better screen GBM immunotherapies before they reach clinical trials. We will also use these simulators to develop and test immunotherapies in mouse GBM models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project 3 Public Health Relevance – Project Narrative Tinnitus, reduced sound level tolerance and difficulty understanding speech in noisy backgrounds are the most common complaints associated with age-related hearing loss, the most prevalent type of sensorineural hearing loss in adult populations. This proposal aims to identify biomarkers of cochlear neural degeneration that can be associated with these common hearing complaints. This research will help identify candidates and track the efficacy of emerging treatments meant to 1) provide better speech intelligibility outcomes to hearing aid users, 2) shed a new light on strategies to silence tinnitus and 3) reduce the physiological activity leading to hyperacusis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will follow participants from two randomized trials to evaluate the impact of the REDI-Classroom and REDI-Parent Head Start enrichment programs on the late adolescent and early adult outcomes of children who attended Head Start. Benefits in areas of educational attainment, employment, health, and reduced risky behavior (antisocial behavior, substance abuse, and risky sexual behavior) will be evaluated with self-reports, parent reports, teacher reports, and administrative data review. The project will contribute to public health by evaluating the long-term impact and mechanisms of action of preschool enhancements that aim to improve the educational attainment, productivity, and health of children growing up in low-income families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project 4 – Project Narrative Difficulty hearing in background noise, tinnitus (ringing of the ears), and hyperacusis (auditory hypersensitivity and discomfort) are linked to noise exposure, aging, and hearing loss, but the connection between these risk factors and any particular set of hearing complaints is obscure. Here, we will measure intermediate layers of sound processing in the human nervous system that more directly underlie these common hearing complaints. This research will advance our understanding of the biological causes for these hearing disorders and will promote new approaches for their objective clinical measurement and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prosthetic infection of metallic implants is one of the most serious complications in orthopedic surgeries, occurring in 1-4% of primary total joint replacement and up to 30% of revisions. Existing prophylactic antibiotic delivery involves high drug loading doses that are unsafe, ineffective and could lead to the development of drug resistance. The proposed metallic implant surface coating strategy enables on-demand release of covalently tethered antibiotics in a timely and sustained manner, bringing together safety and efficacy in addressing the daunting challenge of periprosthetic infections. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Scientific Core – Narrative Public Health Relevance  Our P50 Clinical Research Center assembles a team of four clinician scientists and basic scientists to study the mechanisms underlying three of most vexing aspects of sensorineural hearing loss, i.e. problems understanding in a noisy environment, reduced tolerance for even moderate-level sounds, and the phantom sounds of tinnitus. The Scientific Core leverages the considerable additional expertise of the numerous other hearing and deafness researchers at the Eaton-Peabody Laboratories by tapping into the longstanding technical Research Cores of this group, that have long been sharing expertise and a technical support staff to push the collective research further and faster.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In adults and children, drug dosing for biologic agents do not account for the substantial physiologic alterations resulting from obesity. These changes may result in a high inflammatory state and can affect drug disposition, thereby leading to therapeutic failure, increased disease activity, and poor clinical outcomes. This proposal will systematically characterize disease activity and biologic agent disposition in obesity using advanced pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic modeling, and use the model to optimize dosing and improve outcomes in inflammatory arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pancreas cancer is an extremely lethal disease and is now the fourth leading cause of cancer- related mortality in this country. We propose a systematic and integrated program of investigation to elucidate how engineered T cells infiltrate and migrate through fibroinflammatory and refractory pancreas cancer. We will test promising strategies to further modify the T cells and/or the robust stromal response to inform next-generation cell-based immunotherapies that are safe and maximally effective for pancreas cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rotator cuff tears (RCTs) that involve primarily the supraspinatus and infraspinatus shoulder tendons and muscles are among the most common debilitating shoulder injuries. While RCTs can be surgically repaired, the rate of retear is significant and has been correlated to pathological levels of rotator cuff muscle fatty infiltration, fibrosis, and muscle atrophy. In this application we identify a potentially important regulator of the RCT pathology and propose both genetic and pharmacologic approaches to delete/inhibit this signaling pathway, while also performing genetic reporter analysis, histology, IHC/IF, bulk-RNA sequencing, and sophisticated single cell RNA-sequencing assays in order to determine the detailed cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the RCT pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Health disparities in neuroscience and genomics are hindering the development of effective and equitable neurotherapeutics, and potentially increasing health disparities for neurological disorders. The proposed research project will identify and characterize genetic and epigenetic variation influencing ancestry differences in four postmortem brain regions. These findings will enhance our understanding of genetic variation in the human brain allowing for improved drug discovery models based on genetic ancestry, which would pave the way for equitable personalized medicine and take a much-needed step toward reducing health disparities in neuroscience and genomic research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE  Early and prolonged parent-child separation due to parental migration or immigration may result in attachment disruption that can threaten the long-term mental health and functioning of affected children, and these risks can persist following reunification and through adulthood. Although sending infants back to the home country for rearing is often practiced among Chinese immigrants, especially low-income families, research has been sparse in understanding the long-term impact of early and prolonged parent-child separation and reunification on disparities in mental health and functioning among separated-reunited children and the mechanism through which such relationships may operate. The proposed exploratory sequential mixed-methods research comprises 3 studies—(1) qualitative interviews with affected children and parents, (2) a quantitative survey, and (3) mixed-methods analysis—to understand the mental health impacts, risk/protective factors, and service needs among separated-reunited Chinese American children.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative HIV disproportionally affects men who have sex with men, who report low retention in HIV care, which is associated with decreased survival, viral resistance, and HIV transmission. The World Health Organization strongly recommends mobile technologies to improve adherence; however, evidence on the role of mobile health for retention in HIV care is scarce. I will adapt the WelTel system, which has been proven to increase adherence to HIV treatment, in order to deliver a text messaging-based intervention and assess the efficacy to increase retention in HIV care among HIV+ gay men in Peru.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE This study evaluates the enduring protective impacts of a multi-level evidence-based intervention, ParentCorps, in high-poverty schools with pre-Kindergarten programs serving primarily Black and Latino children in New York City neighborhoods hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic. Specifically, we examine the long-term impact of ParentCorps implemented in high-poverty schools with pre-Kindergarten programs on family-school connections, child mental health and school performance. We also engage with parents, educators and community stakeholders to understand school assets and needs not addressed directly by ParentCorps, and develop and integrate crisis mitigation strategies into the ParentCorps model.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will establish which HIV immune target cell populations found in the human foreskin can be infected with HIV-1. The objective is to identify molecular pathways and activation signals that determine this susceptibility and whether a male with an asymptomatic sexually transmitted infection has enhanced susceptibility. Repurposing interferon agonists will be assessed for activity as anti-virals in human foreskin and other cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PUBLIC HEATH RELEVANCE: Intervening with preschool-aged children to help them initiate a positive trajectory of interpersonal relationships and foster social and emotional learning is of key importance for meeting key developmental tasks and to foster school readiness. However, little research to date has investigated intervention programs for reducing multiple forms of aggression and bullying behavior and promoting positive social and emotional skills among typically developing early childhood populations. This research will extend the existing program to a teacher-coaching model and will test three hypothesized but untested mechanisms that are targeted with the program as well as the moderating role of physiological reactivity and gender in a diverse sample; findings will provide important information to guide future large-scale prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2017, an estimated 101,000 Kenyan adolescents aged 10-19 were living with HIV, the majority of whom are enrolled in school. Schools provide unparalleled access to adolescents, are critical for shaping long term health and life trajectories, and could be leveraged to support achievement of treatment goals. We propose a human centered design approach to gain an in-depth understanding of the school environment and its contribution to treatment goals, develop a school based intervention and pilot it for non-health outcomes (acceptability, feasibility and appropriateness), which aligns with the NIH K43 PAR non-clinical trials requirement.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative To prevent the spread of COVID-19, states have closed work sites, child care, and schools and introduced social distancing requirements. For many families, these policies have led to lost economic and other resources and an increase in parental emotional distress which together can contribute to a disruption in family routines, impacting children's diet, sleep, and physical activity and contributing to excess weight gain or obesity. This study will evaluate these concepts, in addition to examining the disproportionate effects of COVID-19 policies on children's health by race/ethnicity, family socio-economic status, and where they live (rural, urban, or suburban areas) and seeking to understand the economic impact of these policies on future health care costs as these children get older.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Degenerative disc disease afflicts over 80 million Americans a year, and bears significant health care costs. We aim to define the pathways leading to intervertebral disc (IVD) degeneration. The research work proposed here examines the role of Advanced Glycation End-products (AGEs) in the context of aging and diabetes, and the signaling of its receptor (RAGE) as a novel disease mechanism for the degeneration and inflammation of the IVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cholera surveillance and control strategies rely primarily on detecting symptomatic cases that seek care; mild infections and infections in individuals with barriers in access to healthcare are often unobserved. This project aims to examine the degree to which unobserved infections contribute to the burden and transmission of Vibrio cholerae. The approaches used in this study are relevant to a broad range of infectious diseases and will lay the groundwork for addressing critical questions about the host, microbial, and socio-demographic factors that contribute to infections going unobserved, ultimately leading to more effective mitigation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Development of a SYF2 antisense oligonucleotide treatment for ALS and FTD Project Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) are complex diseases that result from many diverse causes. While there are currently no drugs that slow the progression of ALS or FTD, most of the new promising therapeutic strategies are focused narrowly on modifying the specific genetic mutations known to cause disease, however these treatments won’t work for the vast majority (>80% in ALS) of patients for whom the genetic cause of their disease is not known. Therefore, AcuraStem’s focus has been to develop treatments that can work for all ALS and FTD patients, including those for whom the genetic factors driving their disease have yet to be discovered - a large population with urgent unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Tissue repair is essential for organisms to survive and involves a coordinated set of cellular behaviors. My laboratory is interested in the basic cellular and genetic mechanisms that control diverse tissue repair responses like epithelial wound closure, spreading of inflammatory cells, and nociceptive sensitization. We employ the fruit fly Drosophila in our studies and our goal is to understand the basic mechanistic conserved biology that underlies a successful multi-tissue healing response to tissue damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, affects millions of people in Latin America and is an emerging disease in the U.S. and other nonendemic countries. Currently, the only approved drugs for treating Chagas disease are benznidazole and nifurtimox, which are toxic and have low efficacy in the treatment of chronic infection. In this clinical trial study, we propose to test new regimens of these drugs to improve their safety and efficacy, and develop novel diagnostic tools that will provide a more efficient measure of disease state and treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tacrolimus is utilized to prevent rejection of the kidney transplant but has a narrow therapeutic window with subtherapeutic tacrolimus levels associated with acute rejection and supratherapeutic levels associated with nephrotoxicity and neurotoxicity. The overall objective of this study is to define the relationship between the gut microbiota and tacrolimus trough variability in kidney transplant recipients. Our study will enable development of gut-based and blood-based biomarkers to identify kidney transplant recipients at high risk for tacrolimus trough variability.

ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is to develop a Total Artificial Heart (TAH) to provide a durable destination therapy as an alternative to heart transplantation. The approach uses two independent rotary blood pumps with integrated inflow pressure sensors. This approach provides flexibility in anatomic positioning in small patients, and the ability to control left atrial pressure and total pump output according to physiologic demand.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Uncertainties in the current offline feedforward processes of radiotherapy delivery are limiting its tumor curative effectiveness, or increasing the exposure of uninvolved normal tissue resulting in short- and long-terms side effects, or both, therefore, this proposal will investigate an online feedback, ultrasound-based system to better guide the delivery of the radiation beam onto the tumor at the time of treatment. This system integrates X-ray acoustics and ultrasound imaging, which uniquely enables simultaneous imaging of the deposited dose and the targeted tumor anatomy during radiation delivery. The system will be evaluated for measurement accuracy and motion compensation using phantoms and animals; and for clinical use for tumors in the liver and pancreas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 25 million people suffer from posttraumatic stress disorders (PTSD) in the United States at any given point in time; with 30-50% of PTSD patients not responding to first line therapies, novel treatments are needed. The goal of this K01 proposal is to provide critical training in focal neuromodulation, clinical investigations and functional connectivity analyses, and to test the scientific premise that 1Hz DLPFC Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) improves PTSD neuroimaging and psychophysiological biomarkers. Investigating the effect of TMS on measurable neuroimaging and psychophysiological targets within the fear neurocircuitry is the next step for defining novel targets for brain stimulation in PTSD and identifying phenotypes that best predict response to TMS for a personalized treatment approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This Program trains predoctoral researchers in mechanobiology: the relationship between molecular events and mechanical forces in living systems. Training in both the quantitative and biological sciences will foster creative thinking across disciplinary lines, leading to the development of innovative materials, methods and measurement tools to advance human health. Trainees from diverse disciplines, backgrounds, and groups will be prepared to lead rigorous biomedical research programs and promote scientific advances in academia, industry, national labs, and technology and policy careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Glaucoma is a progressive, blinding disease for which intraocular pressure is the most significant risk factor, and yet, the mechanisms of how the eye senses pressure remain largely unknown. This project will investigate the role of mechanosensitive ion channels in glaucoma, and how human variants in mechanosensitive ion channel genes may be associated with glaucoma risk. These studies will provide fundamental insights into the mechanosensitive responses of retinal cells at the molecular and physiological level and will lay the foundation for the development of new neuroprotective therapies for glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: JOHN JAY COLLEGE OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE
PHR: A lot of chemotherapeutic agents function through the activation of p53 and other apoptotic pathways, however at least 50 percent of all cancers do not have a functional p53-pathway. The proposed research will reveal molecular and cellular networks up or down regulated in the p53-independent mode of cell death triggered by mitomycins ICLs in correlation with the ICLs structural features. Results may be used for personalized treatment consideration based on the genetic makeup of tumors, particularly tumors lacking the p53 transcriptional factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is an insidious epidemic with few signs of abating. Over 70% of the adult U.S. population is overweight or obese, as is nearly 20% of children under the age of 19. Despite knowing that diet and exercise can prevent weight gain and promote weight loss, obesity and its associated health risks continue to rise. Is it all simply due to human behavior, or are there other factors at play? This study aims to answer whether certain bacteria in the gut can migrate out of the gut and into surrounding fat tissue where they do not typically belong. When this occurs in other parts of the body, an immune response is mounted that can lead to chronic inflammation. This may occur locally in fat tissue as well, leading to metabolic dysfunction. Therefore, findings from this study may offer a new approach to preventing accumulation of high-risk abdominal fat by eliminating the causative microbes before they leave the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Astroviruses are emerging causes of central nervous system disease in humans with a mortality rate over 50%, however, the models to study how these viruses cause human disease are limited. We have developed a human cerebral organoid (“mini brains”) model that supports replication of astrovirus VA1, enabling deeper insights into the mechanisms of astrovirus neuropathogenicity. By understanding how these viruses cause central nervous system diseases, we can develop better interventions and therapeutics to prevent and treat human infections caused by astroviruses.

PHR: There is a need to link brain activity to human movement, perception and cognition, and social communication in real time, and in the Everyday World. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States faces a crisis due to the high prevalence of chronic pain and associated opioid use disorder and overdose deaths. New non-addictive pain treatments using both pharmacological and non-pharmacological approaches including physical therapy and psychotherapy, are urgently needed. This multidisciplinary training program is designed to prepare new investigators in the field of pain to become independent researchers that can address the chronic pain problem from a multidisciplinary approach that includes discovery of new mechanisms and treatment, and translation of these to clinical pain populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: Pain Research;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Interdisciplinary Training Program in Pain Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The mortality and morbidity due Sickle Cell Disease, a genetic blood disorder predominantly found in sub- Saharan Africa, has been reduced in high income countries using evidence-based interventions. This project aims to implement innovations including electronic registry, standards of care, as well as cohort and implementation science research to transform SCD outcomes in this setting. The anticipated findings of the project will inform policy formulation and sustainable roll out of evidence-based interventions in Uganda and the rest of sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Family-based treatment (FBT), the current gold standard for program for child weight management, is not effective for children who are high on food cue responsiveness, a risk factor for weight regain. This application tests a novel model that targets appetitive traits, called Regulation of Cues (ROC), and compares ROC to FBT, ROC + nutrition education and caloric restriction, and a health education comparator. Results of this study could provide a more potent and durable model for the treatment of children with overweight or obesity who are high in food cue responsiveness and can inform clinical decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: The lack of knowledge surrounding the role of human pericytes in microvascular homeostasis and fibrosis have prevented us from developing appropriate therapeutic strategies that will prevent the genesis, progression and dysfunction of tissues that are affected by fibrosis. Therefore, this proposal describes the investigation of mechanisms that facilitate pericyte remodeling of the vascular wall and interstitial tissue in support of tissue health and dysregulation. This work will translate basic understanding of pericyte biology to therapeutic intervention for fibrotic disorders of pericyte abundant tissue, including the lung, skin, heart, kidney and liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: RELEVANCE About half the people aged 85 or over suffer from Alzheimer disease. Increasing evidence implicates herpes simplex virus type 1, a common herpesvirus, in this disease, and this project aims to investigate how certain genes influence immunity to this virus in patients with Alzheimer’s disease. Results of this investigation may help identify novel targets of immunotherapy against this disorder.

These studies will support novel clinical trials, designed to overcome the hitherto insurmountable challenge of controlling many epithelial malignancies using cellular therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fexinidazole is the promising first oral monotherapy against Human African Trypanosomiasis and is being explored for the treatment of other trypanosomatid infections, yet its mechanism of action, cytotoxic effects, and potential for drug resistance have not been thoroughly investigated. Here, a state-of-the art forward genetic screen has identified proteins with functions in redox and ROS metabolism in a putative fexinidazole resistance pathway, the specificity of which will be evaluated in this proposal through additional targeted genetic screens. Proteins promoting fexinidazole resistance will be analyzed using an unbiased phenotyping pipeline that will provide functional data, determine the role of ROS and redox in drug resistance, evaluate their potential as novel drug targets, and, ultimately, be transformative in the treatment of trypanosomatid infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Migraine, a chronic intermittent headache disorder, ranks in the top five causes for years lived with disability. One promising non-pharmacologic and integrative treatment for migraine may be chiropractic care due to the co-occurrence of migraine and musculoskeletal complaints. The goal of this application is to perform a pilot study of chiropractic care for episodic migraine to help inform the design of a future, full-scale pragmatic effectiveness trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to reduce cardiac side effects for cancer patients who undergo radiation therapy. Using advanced image processing methods and a new radiation machine that uses MRI to change the radiation and track tumors during radiation delivery, precise model of sensitive heart components and determine the best way to effectively spare them from radiation. A clinical trial will be conducted to evaluate potential improvements in cardiac function, side effects, and quality of life using our innovative techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Acute pancreatitis is common and increasing in both incidence and prevalence in the United States, with risk of subsequently developing exocrine insufficiency and/or diabetes approaching 30%. Hence, efforts to understand the mechanisms, risk factors, and predictors of diabetes following acute pancreatitis are of significant public health importance to facilitate the development of strategies for early detection, prevention, and effective management. Through the framework provided by the Type 1 Diabetes Acute Pancreatitis Consortium (T1DAPC), the combined University of Florida and AdventHealth team will serve as a high-volume center contributing to patient enrollment and collection of biological samples for mechanistic and clinical studies to characterize diabetes pathogenesis following acute pancreatitis, ultimately in support of future efforts to identify accurate biomarkers and more effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systematic classification of molecularly defined neurons has dramatically increased in recent years, but the function of these cell types is largely unexplored due to bottlenecks in relating gene expression to neuron activity. In this proposal we will optimize for broad dissemination to the research community a pipeline of imaging, gene expression, and viral tools for highly parallelized evaluation of molecularly defined neuron activity during behavior. This approach is greatly needed to understand cell types associated with physiological and emotional functions in the healthy brain and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing number of U.S. middle and high schools are implementing commercially available social media surveillance (SMS) of students in an effort to address youth mental health and school safety. Although SMS technology is increasingly being purchased by schools, there has been no systematic assessment of the ethical, legal, and social implications, including how it affects the students whom it purportedly aims to help. This project will document the ways in which SMS is currently being used by school administrators across the U.S., assess the perspectives of students and parents, and develop and disseminate student-centered policy recommendations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ovarian cancer is usually diagnosed at a late stage when survival is only about 10%, rendering this disease the deadliest gynecological malignancy. Disease recurrence is the major cause of mortality and despite a greater understanding of ovarian cancer biology there have been no significant improvements in mortality rates in the last five decades. Investigation of tumor cells that are resistant to chemotherapy and have the capacity to regenerate tumors is crucial for achieving cures for ovarian cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The ubiquitin E3 ligase, UBR5 is one of the most commonly mutated genes (~18%) in mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) with the majority of mutations identified in UBR5 were frame shift mutations found within the HECT domain. Here we will study the molecular function of ubiquitin E3 ligase, UBR5 mutations in lymphomagensis. Deciphering the role of the UBR5 and pathways dysregulated by mutations in mantle cell lymphoma will provide clues to lymphoma transformation with the goal of identifying targets for future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Individual hosts vary in their susceptibility to pathogens, which has important consequences for outbreak dynamics and pathogen evolution. Our work will elucidate relationships between prior exposure of hosts to pathogens, as occurs naturally and via vaccination, and the degree of variability in host susceptibility. The models generated will be broadly useful for understanding and managing any pathogens, including those of humans, where host protection generated by prior exposure is variable, incomplete, or wanes over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) offers a computational bridge between genome biology and clinical medicine and is used across the globe for analysis and exchange of phenotype data in rare disease. The use of HPO is rapidly growing in academia and industry, including diagnostic laboratories, health software applications, and health-care delivery, and—with improvements, new capabilities, and wider community adoption—has significant potential to improve the diagnosis and treatment of many more genetic diseases. We propose to advance the HPO to meet this need and improve computational disease modeling in a cost-effective, community- supported initiative that will address an expanding set of medical disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to expand the portfolio of evidence-based treatments for urologic chronic pelvic pain syndrome (UCPPS) by evaluating the immediate and longer-term efficacy of a brief version of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) as well as the active ingredients (mechanisms) explaining why, how, and for whom it is most beneficial. An effective and relatively simple “across disorder” or transdiagnostic treatment that targets simultaneously what UCPPS and frequently co-occurring (and complicating) disorders have in common rather than their differences would improve on conventional behavioral pain approaches whose narrower focus, length, cost and/or complexity have limited their transfer from well-controlled laboratory to “real world” settings accessible to more individuals in need. By capitalizing on cutting-edge cognitive science research that emphasizes the importance of how patients think, not simply what they think about, we plan to demonstrate how a parsimonious, transdiagnostic, mechanistically-driven behavioral treatment of low intensity can reduce both painful urinary and co-occurring nonurological symptoms with minimal clinician oversight and maximum patient engagement, safety and benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Positron emission tomography (PET) is a highly specific and sensitive imaging technique that visualizes molecular interactions, having a significant impact on biomedical research and translational medicine. This proposal develops high-performance and cost-effective time-of-flight PET detector modules based on the ultra- dense and fast ceramic scintillator. The proposed research will lead to next-generation PET scanners with superior performance and lower cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of reading ability due to stroke, called alexia, likely affects over a million Americans at any given time and causes difficulty performing many daily life functions. Understanding the brain and cognitive basis of alexia could improve diagnosis and treatment of this important disorder, but modern methods and larger sample sizes are needed to address this gap in knowledge, along with an improved understanding of the brain and cognitive basis of reading in typical older adults in whom stroke is most common. In this project, we will perform a large- scale behavioral and brain imaging study of stroke survivors and typical older adults to improve our understanding of the brain and cognitive basis of reading in both of these groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Training the next generation of physician-scientists who will tackle the important clinical issues in infectious disease and immunology requires a robust and innovative program to provide superb training on an integrated platform. We propose the Massachusetts General Hospital Next Generation Physician-Scientist Training Pathways program will provide dedicated research time to residents in the Departments of Medicine and Surgery to foster longitudinal mentorship, skill development, and perform high-quality research related to fundamental questions in infectious diseases and immunology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Latinx children experience behavioral and physical health disparities early in development that persist into adulthood; it is not known how children’s physiological stress regulation relates to disparities in Latinx children or how Latinx caregivers can buffer their children from these negative outcomes. This proposal examines positive parenting as a buffer of the link between child physiological stress regulation and behavioral and academic adjustment during early childhood. The results will identify family and contextual factors that can be leveraged into culturally informed intervention programming to reduce disparities and improve the overall well- being of Latinx families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death among women. Over one third of women report intimate partner violence (IPV) across the lifecourse, yet it is unclear if history of IPV increases women’s risk for CVD, particularly during midlife, a time of biological and psychosocial transition for women. This study will investigate the relationship of IPV to subclinical CVD in midlife women and will yield results that inform the development of interventions to improve cardiovascular health in women with trauma histories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Substantial disparities exist in childhood obesity and cardiovascular disease among racial and ethnic minorities and children from disadvantaged backgrounds. Despite availability of proven-effective interventions that aim to improve childhood obesity, substantial gaps remain in the adoption of recommended practices, particularly in settings that care for low-income children. The overall goals of this K24 application are to provide Dr. Elsie Taveras with protected time to perform equity-focused implementation research to accelerate the adoption of effective interventions to reduce childhood obesity and to train students, fellows, and junior faculty who wish to perform patient-oriented outcomes research in childhood obesity disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Over one hundred million people worldwide consume arsenic-contaminated drinking water, which increases risk for a wide array of health conditions, including cancer. The goal of this project is to identify features of the human genome, both inherited and acquired, that reflect susceptibility to arsenic toxicity or response to arsenic exposure, using data from a large arsenic-exposed Bangladeshi cohort. Achieving these goals will reveal biological mechanisms of toxicity and susceptibility, identify potential targets for pharmacological intervention, and provide strategies for identifying high risk individuals and reducing their exposure.

PHR: Project Narrative The development of diabetes mellitus following an episode of acute pancreatitis (termed AP- related DM) is now recognized in approximately 25% of patients; however, its epidemiology and pathophysiology remain poorly characterized. The Ohio State University Clinical Center (OSU- CC) has developed a prospective, longitudinal, observational cohort study in AP, along with a series of hypothesis-driven investigations to address knowledge gaps in AP-related DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: NARRATIVE Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) is one of the primary causes of intellectual disability in western nations, with neurobehavioral hallmarks such as deficits in learning, memory and mood. Of the many long-lasting consequences of developmental ethanol exposure, sleep disruption has been identified in human and other animal studies, and our previous results indicate that sleep deficits are associated with specific interneuron reduction. Given the importance of sleep in memory consolidation, mood and attention, here we will explore how developmental ethanol affects GABA interneurons and how modifications of the cell numbers or activity improve developmental ethanol-induced sleep disruption, which may help identify treatments for FASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adverse effects of Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor (TKI) drugs negatively affect survivorship in cancer patients and is a serious and growing problem. A major knowledge gap is the lack of a comprehensive delineation of the kinase networks responsible for the anti-cancer and adverse effects of these drugs. This proposal supports a physician-scientist in her final 2 years of training (K99 mentored phase) and her initial independent career (R00 phase) to develop a comprehensive molecular level understanding of the kinase inhibition networks that will inform the development of safer and more effective anti-cancer drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mucosal type 2 immune response is essential to orchestrate immunity to helminth infection, but if dysregulated can drive chronic allergic diseases such as asthma or food allergy. These infections and allergic diseases impact over 2 billion individuals in the world, representing a major socio-economic and public health challenge. The fundamental focus of this application is the define two novel pathways that critically regulate type 2 mucosal immunity and inflammation, which could provoke novel preventative, therapeutic or curative treatment strategies for these infectious and inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to identify risk factors for anotia and microtia in Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations. This proposal will accomplish its objective by evaluating the associations of individual and neighborhood-level social/environmental factors, genetic variation, and maternal exposures with anotia and microtia, using data from population-based birth defects registries, biobanking programs, and the National Birth Defects Prevention Study. This information may inform future etiologic studies, facilitate targeted prevention efforts in high-risk populations, and reduce ethnic disparities in the prevalence, diagnosis, and treatment of anotia and microtia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Patients who have experienced a stroke or other brain injury frequently experience anomia - a condition in which they are unable to produce words when speaking. One major challenge in this area is the lack of theoretically driven and psychometrically robust metrics to support treatment efficacy research, and to provide a unified measurement framework for rehabilitation, reimbursement, and policy decisions. Our goal is to create a computerized system for measuring relevant aspects of an individual’s anomia that will link existing tests to a universal metric, thereby opening the door to new ways of treating anomia and reducing clinical workload.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Moving our eyes between targets located at different distances from us requires disjunctive saccades and holding our eyes on each target requires the integration of vergence signals to produce a maintained vergence angle. Individuals with strabismus do not coordinate their eyes sufficiently to fixate targets in this way, but little is known about the neural control of disjunctive saccades and vergence integration in normal subjects. Our proposed studies aim to understand the role of the interconnected neural circuitry in the central mesencephalic reticular formation, supraoculomotor area and cerebellum that allows individuals to make disjunctive saccades and maintain vergence angle as they view targets in three-dimensional space.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a burgeoning obesity-associated complication that is more common in men. The molecular and genetic basis for NAFLD and its sex-biased risk is incompletely understood. In this project, we elucidate a gene switch controlling liver sex-specific programming and fat accumulation. Insights from these studies may identify a therapeutic pathway to halt or reverse fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) are part of a devastating neurodegenerative disease spectrum for which there are no biomarkers and only limited treatments, stemming from a poor understanding of its pathogenesis. Here, we propose to integrate novel biophysical tools with spatially resolved transcriptomic and proteomic analyses of mouse models and clinically well-characterized post- mortem ALS-FTD brains to determine the specific molecular underpinnings of functional impairment in this disease. By integrating our analysis across different scales (from the cellular to the organismal), our ultimate goal is to unveil how disease-associated pathology is linked to dysfunction in specific cell types in ALS-FTD, which may in turn foster precision medicine-based treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The survival of pathogenic bacteria such as Bacillus anthracis, Yersinia pestis, and Salmonella enterica relies on ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters for the acquisition of extracellular nutrients from the environment. Despite this crucial role of ABC transporters, how these transporters identify substrates and utilize ATP is not fully understood. The overall goal of this project is to dissect individual steps in the mechanisms of ABC transporters which will aid in the development of new strategies to combat infection and attenuate virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose to develop an implementation-ready intervention that allows patients to intensify their antihypertensive medications at home under guidance from their primary care physician and following a titration algorithm. To achieve this, we will conduct qualitative interviews with key stakeholders to determine barriers and facilitators to implementation of antihypertensive self-titration in routine practice, use a large real- world dataset to assess adherence to antihypertensive medications, develop the intervention and supporting materials, perform usability testing, and prepare a proposal to test this intervention in a pragmatic, randomized trial. The overarching goal of the project is to develop an innovative alternative model of hypertension care that has the potential to improve blood pressure control, patient self-efficacy, and disease understanding, and it is highly aligned with the central mission and priorities of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  PARP inhibitor resistance is a growing clinical problem, and alternative therapeutic strategies are needed. Hyperactivation of Wnt/beta-catenin signaling drives PARP inhibitor resistance and immune evasion. Thus, we hypothesize that combining a Wnt inhibitor with a checkpoint blockade (e.g., anti-PD-1) could overcome PARPi resistance and activate an anti-tumor immune response. In our unique PARP inhibitor- resistant models, we propose to examine the anti-tumor effect of a first-in-class Wnt/ beta-catenin inhibitor in a syngeneic and humanized mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Follicular lymphoma (FL) constitutes the second most common B-cell Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (B-NHL) with an annual incidence of ~15,000 cases and more than 100,000 patients in the US living with the disease. Despite improvements in the survival of FL patients, the disease remains incurable and patients go through cycles of treatment, remission and relapse. In this proposal we outline our approach for the study of common STAT6 mutations that drive this disease with possible future opportunities for novel therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrosis, or scarring, causes dysfunction and ultimate failure of numerous tissues with aging and disease, and is characterized in part by increased tissue stiffness. Despite estimates that fibrosis contributes to 45% of U.S. deaths, no adequate model system exists to study fibrotic stiffening on individual cells in real time. This project aims to develop novel dynamic material platforms that enable user-directed manipulation of stiffness and to apply these systems to identify the molecular mechanisms by which fibrotic stiffening leads to cellular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project narrative Following inpatient surgery, more than 80% of patients are prescribed opioids for use after discharge, yet up to 90% of patients report leftover opioids, and only 16% maximize non-opioid therapy. The proposed research seeks to test a provider-facing decision support tool and a patient-facing smartphone app to reduce the amounts of opioids prescribed and taken following discharge, while ensuring effective treatment of pain after surgery. Increasing access to safe, affordable, and high-quality pain therapy for surgical patients will drive the positive impact of this proposal.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Efficiency And Quality In Post-Surgical Pain Therapy After Discharge - EQUIPPED

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative PACS1 R203W pathogenic substitution is solely responsible for over 200 patients presenting with the ASD- associated disease, PACS1 Syndrome, yet the mechanisms that lead to the neurodevelopmental defects remain largely unknown. Moreover, genome-wide association studies (GWAS) identified the human PACS1 locus as a susceptibility gene in severe early-onset obesity, developmental delay, and bipolar disorder, suggesting a broader role in neural development and function. In this proposal, we will use modern molecular biology and stem cell techniques combined with neuroscience tools to better understand the pathogenic mechanisms by which PACS1 deficits affect the developing nervous system, possibly revealing convergent therapy targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac arrest, as well as cardiac dysfunction, are major causes of mortality and morbidity, carrying great economical and societal impact. Our research focuses on an inherited disease called “arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy” caused by mutations in the PKP2 gene, coding for a desmosome protein, plakophilin-2. We will use modern physiology, genomics, proteomics, and microscopy methods to investigate the mechanisms underlying the onset of the disease at the molecular level.

PHR: Project Narrative This project develops computational tools for automatically and accurately determining atomic structure from low-resolution cryo-electron microscopy data. The proposed work will lead to dramatic improvements in our ability to model dynamic structures of protein complexes. Obtaining accurate structures from this data will reveal insights into the workings of biomedically important protein complexes, and what goes wrong in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Affinity Gradient-Based Transport of HIV Capsid Cores Through the Nuclear Pore Complex: Project Narrative HIV-1 infects cells by passing its capsid core with the viral genome through the Nuclear Pore Complex (NPC), a process that involves intricate and poorly understood interactions between the viral and NPC components. We propose a hypothesis that HIV-1 capsid core is a complex transporter that is translocated via an opportunistic affinity gradient that consists of various “signatures” on specific NPC components naturally distributed along the nucleo-cytoplasmic axis of the NPC. Knowledge of the molecular interactions during HIV-1 nuclear import will shed light on the strategy HIV-1 deploys to deliver its genome to the nucleus; our fundamental understanding of NPC function; provide a framework for studies of the nuclear import of other viruses; and potential approaches to novel antiviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal aims to develop an interconnected set of modeling tools to support elimination of communicable diseases. A variety of processes used to achieve disease elimination will be considered including use of mass drug administration to eliminate neglected tropical diseases such as trachoma, vaccination for preventable diseases such as SARS-CoV-2, and antibiotic stewardship efforts to curtail drug resistant infections such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Besides improving our scientific understanding of disease transmission, hypotheses validated through mathematical modeling provide public health practitioners with a more structured, quantitative assessment of how elimination of specific pathogens can be achieved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Traumatic stress disorders increase the risk for developing alcohol use disorder (AUD) and are associated with higher incidence of chronic pain in humans. The proposed work will test 1) traumatic stress effects on the activity of amygdala cells that project to reward/aversion and pain centers and 2) the role of specific amygdala cells in mediating stress effects on alcohol reward/aversion and sensory nociception & pain avoidance. We will use an established animal model of traumatic stress in combination with brain slice electrophysiology, neuroanatomical tract-tracing, retrograde neural labeling, molecular biology, pharmacology and circuit-based approaches to test neurobiological mediators of stress effects on behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over the past 30 years techniques of obtaining allografts for stem cell transplantation has shifted to increasing use of blood stem cell grafts collected by apheresis, in spite of higher rates of chronic graft-versus-host disease seen among recipients of G-CSF-mobilized grafts compared with marrow grafts. Our research has shown that rare antigen presenting cells in the graft, called dendritic cells, have a significant influence on the incidence and severity of graft-versus-host disease. Our work will define the type of donor dendritic cell that most effectively limits graft-versus-host disease without compromising the graft-versus-leukemia activity of the transplant, and will optimize novel ways of obtaining donor grafts that are enriched for this cell population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Emerging evidence suggests that autophagy abnormality is implicated in metabolic dysfunction, but the mechanism by which autophagy regulates insulin sensitivity is largely unknown. Recently we discovered a mechanistic link between autophagy and the secretion of adiponectin, an adipose tissue-derived hormone whose reduction in circulation is strongly associated with type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome. In this proposal, we will demonstrate the novel non-degradative, non-cell autonomous, mechanism by which the ULK1-Vps34-Becn1 autophagy machinery in adipose tissue improves systemic insulin sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rib fractures account for over 40% of all bone fractures sustained in the United States, however there remain few options for non-invasive rib fracture stabilization. This proposal will determine the utility and the efficacy of using resorbable, phosphorylated PEU (pPEU) copolymers as an innovative, non-invasive treatment for rib fracture stabilization and fracture healing. The studies of this proposal are relevant to public health in that they will lead to new therapies for a common traumatic injury for which efficacious, non-invasive treatment strategies are currently lacking.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: BARAU DIKKO TEACHING HOSPITAL/ KADUNA STATE UNIVERSITY
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke is a devastating complication of sickle cell anemia (SCA) still occurring in approximately 11% of children affected with the disease in resource-limited countries, compared to 1% in high-income countries. In Nigeria, the country with more than 50% of the global burden of SCA, screening for at risk children using transcranial Doppler ultrasound (TCD) measurements is limited to tertiary hospitals. This mentored award is focused on initiating a stroke prevention program in a resource-limited community hospital by task shifting of TCD screening to nurses, a strategy that is expected to increase access for affected children with prompt institution of a primary prevention strategy for those with increased stroke risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: The purpose of this training program is to increase the numbers of under-represented students (specifically American Indian and Hispanic) from community colleges who pursue baccalaureate and graduate degrees in the biomedical and behavioral sciences. The training program promotes inter-institutional partnerships among New Mexico State University in Las Cruces, NM, and two regional community colleges: Dona Ana Community College and San Juan College in Farmington. The overall programmatic goal is to apply well- integrated developmental activities based on summer and academic year research training to increase student preparation and skills to successfully pursue baccalaureate and graduate degrees in biomedical and behavioral sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality, however development of effective therapies for sepsis treatment represents a major challenge. This study will focus on the investigation of novel molecular mechanisms promoting reduction of inflammatory signaling caused by Gram-positive infection. The results of this project will expand our knowledge about molecular regulation of inflammatory response and may lead to discovery of a new group of pharmacological molecules for the treatment of sepsis and other diseases associated with increased vascular leakage and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Although epigenetic therapeutics are promising treatment options for cocaine use disorder, many epigenetic inhibitors are non-selective and have adverse side effects, significant issues that restrict mechanistic insight and translational applications. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Psychotic symptoms (delusions and hallucinations) during Alzheimer disease cause substantial added burden for patients and families. Current medication treatments for psychosis in Alzheimer disease have limited benefits and cause substantial side effects. This project looks to accelerate the development of more effective medication treatments by generating detailed characterizations of altered protein levels in cortical synapses of individuals who experience psychosis during Alzheimer disease and using these characterizations to identify and test available medications for their ability to reverse the protein changes in mouse models of Alzheimer disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Current antiretrovirals, although effective in controlling HIV-1 infection, do not cure the disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) drug development relies on both mouse and clinical research, but translational resources to bridge the gap between mouse and human AD are limited. Building upon my previous research creating the mouse Hippocampus Gene Expression Atlas (HGEA), this proposal will investigate translational gene expression patterns across hippocampal neuronal cell types in mouse AD models and humans (with and without AD). The completion of this research will produce a comprehensive human HGEA that, together with the mouse HGEA, can help guide AD drug development and reveal the hippocampal neuronal cell types that are primarily affected by AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Successful completion of the experiments listed in this proposal will characterize, in detail, the Clostridioides difficile spore small acid soluble proteins. These proteins contribute to the extreme resistance properties that are characteristic of endospores, C. difficile included. By understanding how C. difficile spores maintain their resistance to genotoxic chemicals / treatments, a better strategy to reduce their burden in the healthcare environment can be designed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Dana Farber/Harvard Cancer Consortium Career Development Program in Clinical Oncology Project Narrative New insights from genome sequencing and technical advances in genome editing, chemical biology, and cellular engineering are providing unprecedented opportunities for advances in cancer treatment. The emerging complexity of cancer biology and increasing sophistication of experimental therapeutics demand a level of understanding and training in research methodology beyond the scope of conventional fellowship programs. To address these challenges, the goal of the Dana Farber/Harvard Cancer Consortium Career Development Program in Clinical Oncology (DF/HCC K12) is to recruit and select a highly qualified and diverse group of Scholars to complete a rigorous two-three year program of didactic instruction and mentored research that will prepare them for independent careers in clinical oncology research.
