IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goals of this proposal are to shed light on the nature, sources, and behavioral consequences of the large neural variability of sensory cortical neurons, the contribution of internal state fluctuations to this variability, and to generate cortical circuit models that account for the observed neural variability. Our three laboratories have developed a computational and experimental strategy leveraging our ability to perform whole-cell intracellular recordings in awake, behaving animals performing well-controlled and demanding visual tasks. Novel datasets will be used to provide critical constraints on cortical circuit models that mediate sensation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria play a critical role in the life of the cell as they control metabolic rates, energy production and cell death. Many devastating diseases arise from insults to the mitochondrial genome. This project will explore how insults to the mitochondrial genome alter mitochondrial dynamics and impacts bioenergetic function; ultimately regulating cellular function, multiple organ failure and disease severity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are expressed ubiquitously on mammalian cell surfaces and interact with a wide variety of biological molecules to modulate processes, including immune response, regulation of cell growth and blood-stream clotting. Disruption of GAG-binding has the potential to prevent infection by viruses, such as HIV-1, and to reduce inflammation caused by autoimmune disorders. This project will utilize recently developed synthetic GAG libraries and NMR-based structural models to develop a pipeline to identify key interactions between heparan sulfate and heparan sulfate binding proteins, which can be used as a basis for development of drugs to target and disrupt GAG-protein binding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We will test whether the extracellular milieu of the brain is altered by glial scarring after brain injury. One component of this milieu, the extracellular concentration of chloride ions, is a critical component of the brain’s endogenous anticonvulsant system. Changes to this component are not effectively compensated by anticonvulsant treatment, but could be prevented by short-term treatment with stabilizers of the extracellular milieu immediately after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impoverished social relationships have been linked to poor cognitive functioning and Alzheimer's and related dementias (ADRD) in older adults, but the relative contribution of loneliness and social isolation to cognitive decline and dementia across the adult life span are not well understood. This project investigates social asymmetry or the degree of overlap or discordance between subjective feelings of loneliness and objective social network size, its consequences for established indicators of cognitive morbidity and decline, and the extent to which these associations are amplified during the COVID-19 pandemic. We will utilize 11 existing longitudinal data sets to address these aims using coordinated integrative data analysis (IDA), thereby enhancing the rigor, reproducibility, and replicability of our results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Liquid–liquid phase separation of proteins and nucleic acids drives the biogenesis of diverse membraneless organelles with important biological functions. Dysregulated phase separation of RNA-binding proteins leads to the formation of toxic fibrils, which is a pathological hallmark in multiple fatal neurodegenerative diseases. Elucidating molecular mechanisms of phase separation regulation and developing strategies to reverse aberrant phase transition and fibrillization will lay the foundation for advances in novel therapeutic strategies to combat these fatal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: To understand the etiology of metabolic disorders and motivated behavior it is essential that we gain better insight into the neuronal mechanisms that regulate metabolism and behavior. We propose studies that will assess and define the role of lipid metabolism in the arcuate melanocortin neurons in the regulation of feeding behavior and energy metabolism. The proposed studies are a logical continuation of our ongoing studies and, if successful, their completion will unmask a novel mechanistic principle in central regulation of feeding and systemic metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. The goal of this project is to use human induced pluripotent stem cells, micropatterned culture, synthetic biomaterial scaffolds, and microfluidics, to recreate the dynamic microenvironmental cues that coax tissue self- assembly and maturation. We anticipate that this holistic approach will enhance our understanding of multi- germ layer communication in lineage specification, as well as the role of mechanical and chemical cues in directing stem cell fate. Collectively, these approaches will build a framework for elucidating the mechanisms of human development and improve stem cell models of morphogenesis and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE NARRATIVE The University of California and University of Texas Southwestern Diversity Patient-Derived Xenograft Development and Trial Center leverages the collective strengths of six NCI- Comprehensive Cancer Centers to create minority patient cancer models and characterize targeted treatment responses to stomach and lung tumors. The responsibility of the Administrative Core is to create an efficient infrastructure to a) coordinate specimen collection and data exchange, b) manage scientific progress and fiscal responsibilities, c) sustain quality assurance and quality control procedures, d) maintain communication with key stakeholders, and e) centralize standard operating procedures. Through UCaTS activities, we expect to extend our large repository to facilitate the discover of new therapies that could impact vulnerable racial and ethnic minority cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic minority groups and those from low socioeconomic groups suffer disproportionately from the effects of tobacco marketing, have less access to evidence-based treatments for tobacco use, and report needing more support for cessation efforts. Pediatricians are uniquely positioned to help medically underserved families to address smoking and protect children from secondhand smoke (SHS) exposure, but a major barrier to protecting children from SHS exposure and extending tobacco use treatment to underserved adults who smoke is identifying an effective and scalable method to engage all household members who smoke, not just parents who present to the pediatric clinic with the child. To address this barrier, we will conduct a pragmatic trial through a large, urban pediatric network to evaluate a novel, proactive intervention that uses population health and clinical informatics implementation strategies to increase the reach, effectiveness, and health equity of tobacco use treatments for underserved families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PDX CORE NARRATIVE The University of California and University of Texas Southwestern Diversity Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) Development and Trial Center leverages the collective strengths of six NCI- Comprehensive Cancer Centers to create minority patient cancer models and characterize targeted treatment responses to stomach and lung tumors. The PDX Core will establish, maintain, characterize, store, and distribute lung and stomach cancer minority PDX models adhering to applicable guidelines, standards, quality control procedures, and ongoing surveillance procedures for animal and human pathogens. Through UCaTS activities, we expect to extend our large repository to facilitate the discover of new therapies that could impact vulnerable racial and ethnic minority cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vision is a unique process, depending upon both the eye and the brain. This Core Facilities grant will support work on basic and clinical aspects of vision research, such as understanding how the eye and the visual brain develop, the brain mechanisms that underlie visual behavior, the treatment of diseases like macular degeneration, glaucoma, and myopia and the behavior of patients with ocular disease. By providing technical support, the Core modules will enable its participants to work effectively on problems related to the causes and treatment of blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Psychoactive substances have disruptive and compounding eﬀects on memory circuit function. However, the mechanisms through which these substances alter gene expression to aﬀect circuit plasticity and behavioral choice are not well understood. We propose to discover the gene regulatory networks altered by the synergistic eﬀects of polystimulant use that drive escalation in drug self-administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Obesity is the most important risk factor for diabetes. Dysfunctional adipocytes play a critical role in insulin resistance and obesity associated comorbidities. Studies laid out here will dissect the contribution of uridine biosynthesis in adipocytes in obesity and diabetes progression, which will provide new insights into the underlying pathophysiology of insulin resistance and shed light on novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal will institute a care pathway across seven emergency departments with the goal of improving guideline adherent care for children with sickle cell disease presenting with an acute vaso-occlusive pain crisis. If successful, this work will improve pain, decrease hospitalizations and improve the quality of life of children with sickle cell disease and acute vaso-occlusive pain crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Older adults with PTSD are at an increased risk for age-related cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s disease. Increased inflammation is known to associate with PTSD, age-related cognitive decline, and Alzheimer’s disease, and central to the neural circuitry underlying these disorders are medial temporal lobe structures such as the basolateral amygdala. The proposed research is relevant to the aging population because it seeks to identify both neurobiological mechanisms at the core of these disorders and a feasible therapeutic intervention, and furthermore, this contribution will be significant because identifying neural mechanisms of fear-based neuropsychiatric disorder in aging will reveal targets for interventions to promote improved quality of life outcomes across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE The University of California and University of Texas Southwestern Diversity Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) Development and Trial Center leverages the collective strengths of six NCI-Comprehensive Cancer Centers to create minority patient cancer models and characterize targeted treatment responses to lung tumors. This project focuses on the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutation in non-small cell lung cancer, which is a tumor driving gene that occurs with a higher frequency in Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, Pacific Islanders (AANHPI ~50%), and Latinos (~38%). Through UCaTS activities, we expect to extend our repository of minority PDXs focused on EGFR mutant lung cancer and to facilitate the discovery of new therapies that could impact vulnerable racial and ethnic minority cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Recently a gut microbe derived metabolite, Trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO), was identified as a novel risk factor for cardiovascular diseases, however, the mechanism by which it causes cardiovascular injury is unclear. In this application, we have proposed innovative studies that will delineate TMAO’s role in producing both inflammation and injury to cells which lead to hardening of the arteries and ultimately cause heart or blood vessel diseases. We believe that knowledge derived from these studies will help understand the molecular basis of TMAO induced cardiovascular injury and will provide novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative The World Health Organization identified cataract as the leading cause of blindness. In the US, cataract extraction is the most common Medicare surgery, adding a financial burden to healthcare of more than $6.8 billion annually. Better knowledge of the biological mechanisms that regulate lens transport, and how their failure contribute to its age-related decline will suggest new therapeutic strategies to prevent or postpone the progression of cataract, thereby alleviating the need for surgical intervention, and possibly save billions in Medicare expenditures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health since it is likely to contribute a mechanistic understanding for novel drug-drug interactions that contribute to treatment-limiting toxicities during immune checkpoint inhibi- tor therapy. This knowledge will be clinically impactful since it is likely to inform clinical strategies to identify pa- tients at highest risk for immune checkpoint inhibitor-related drug interactions and to prevent these drug inter- actions. The long-term goal of this translational research is to identify clinical strategies to enhance the safety, and thereby the clinical benefit, of immune checkpoint inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project narrative Erythropoiesis is the life-long process by which red cells are formed in the bone marrow, and its failure leads to anemia. This project investigates a stage of erythropoiesis when erythroid precursors replicate unusually fast, a situation that might lead to errors in genome replication and genomic instability. The proposal will determine whether genomic instability does in fact take place in fast-cycling red cell precursors, or whether they are somehow equipped to handle fast cycling without compromising genomic integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PILOT PROJECTS AND TRANS-NETWORK ACTIVITIES CORE NARRATIVE The University of California and University of Texas Southwestern Diversity Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) Development and Trial Center leverages the collective strengths of six NCI- Comprehensive Cancer Centers to create minority patient cancer models and characterize targeted treatment responses to stomach and lung tumors. The Pilot Projects and Trans-Network Activities Core will administer NCI-funded pilot project opportunities to facilitate interactions among UCaTS, the PDXNet Consortium, and non-PDXNet investigators. Additionally, this Core will coordinate the development of standard operating procedures and develop methods of experimental validation and reproducibility that will be shared within the Trans-Network and in collaboration with non-Network projects. Through UCaTS activities, we expect to extend our large repository to facilitate the discover of new therapies that could impact vulnerable racial and ethnic minority cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phenylketonuria (PKU), hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (HT1), and mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPSI) are inherited disorders of metabolism that cause debilitating and even life-threatening medical problems as early as birth. We seek to use a type of CRISPR gene editing technology, called base editing, to directly and permanently correct gene mutations or otherwise alter genes at the DNA level in the liver, either after or before birth—a “one- and-done” treatment strategy that could substantially improve the long-term health of patients with these diseases .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: A subset of Immunoglobulin (Ig) heavy chain classes, including IgA and IgM, assemble into polymeric (p) antibodies, which are delivered to the mucosa where they play crucial roles mediating interactions with commensal microbes and eliminating pathogens such as Clostridium difficile. Building upon cryoelectron microscopy structures of secretory IgA, recenty published by our group and others, we aim to investigate pIg assembly mechanisms, determine unknown structures, and engineer IgAs that can bind and neutralize human mucosal pathogens including C. difficile. These studies will expand knowledge of mucosal immunity and host- microbe interactions while also delivering the ability to modify pIg structure for therapeutic benefit.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a pressing clinical need to develop new strategies to both encourage and accelerate axon regeneration in the peripheral and central nervous systems; however, we need to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying what restricts rates of axon regeneration to the 1-2 mm/day seen for peripheral nerves. Translation of mRNAs in axons has been shown to promote axon regeneration; this proposal focuses how levels of those mRNAs are regulated to sustain localized protein synthesis and promote regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Liver fibrogenesis is the active scarring of liver tissue that occurs in chronic liver diseases like nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). If left unattended liver fibrosis can progress to liver failure, cirrhosis, or primary liver cancer. There are no methods to noninvasively detect and quantify fibrogenesis. The goal of this project is to develop a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) probe that can detect fibrogenesis, monitor disease progression and drug treatment response, and is safe for human use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need for a well-tolerated intervention to slow autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) progression and improve vascular health and symptom burden. Sodium-glucose cotransporters-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) have a track record of tolerability and safety in patients with proteinuric kidney diseases but have not previously been studied in patients with ADPKD. This pilot and feasibility randomized trial of the SGLT2i empagliflozin in patients with ADPKD at high risk of progression will test the safety and tolerability of this medication, and provide preliminary estimates of its efficacy on disease progression, vascular health, and symptoms, to support a subsequent definitive phase III clinical trial of the clinical efficacy of SGLT2i in ADPKD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will investigate fundamental cellular and molecular mechanisms of how the vascular network of the skin - the largest organ in our body - develops, maintains adult homeostasis, and repairs itself to support life-long function and health. I have established a state of the art live imaging approach to visualize, manipulate, and longitudinally track blood vessel cells in the live mouse skin, to interrogate for the first time the cellular dynamics underlying skin vascular remodeling and homeostasis. This research is of paramount importance, given the indispensable function of the vasculature to all tissues in our body and the yet unknown mechanisms that differentiate neonatal versus adult vascular regeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal growth restriction (FGR) raises the risk of stillbirth and neonatal death. It is well known that FGR develops when the normal rise in uterine blood flow is curtailed and that growth-restricted fetuses have lower blood O2 levels but it is unlikely that lower blood flow is solely responsible for restricting growth because O2 supply still exceeds fetal O2 consumption. This project will identify how and when lower blood flow and hypoxia affect placental and fetal metabolism so as to slow fetal growth. Such information is essential for refining therapeutic strategies for restoring fetal growth under conditions of hypoxia, a goal that has, to date, proven elusive

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Lewy body dementia (LBD) is a devastating disorder of thinking, memory, and emotional disturbances that currently has no cures or effective therapies. Novel biomarkers of LBD promise to advance our ability to manage and treat this disease. We propose to develop novel high-impact protein biomarker panels for LBD in blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) using an innovative proteomic strategy that incorporates network analysis, brain- biofluid integration, and targeted biomarker validation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural, process, and outcome measures of home- and community-based services are fragmented by setting, service, and payer, and are not specific to dementia. This Research Network will build the data infrastructure to promote the development, harmonization, and utilization of measures that are necessary to ensure equitable access to, and outcomes of, these services. The Network will also build and diversify the research bench by engaging and supporting underrepresented researchers, coordinating activities with other networks, and training researchers to develop and disseminate policy-relevant research to improve dementia HCBS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with nephrotic syndrome are exposed to prolonged courses of steroids and other immunosuppressant medications with serious side effects. Given the adverse side effect profile and variable efficacy of these medications, there is an urgent need to identify novel and safe therapies to treat nephrotic syndrome in children. The proposed research utilizing transauricular vagus nerve stimulation will provide preliminary data that are essential to conduct a large-scale trial that will address a significant knowledge gap and will pave the way for evaluation of an innovative, non-pharmacologic, non-invasive, steroid-sparing approach to the treatment of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The “Randomized Trial of Assisted Ambulation to Improve Health Outcomes for Older Medical Inpatients” will test the hypothesis that compared to usual care having a designated mobility technician to provide supervised ambulation up to 3 times daily will improve patients’ mobility at discharge. We will then use prediction modeling to identify which patients benefit most from the intervention. Finally, we will assess the economic impact of the mobility technicians from the health system perspective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this study, I will leverage single-cell RNA-sequencing analysis to identify novel, important locally acting soluble factors in a functional human lung microvascular niche to improve pulmonary microvascular maturation in acellular lung scaffolds. This work will lead to the creation of a novel pulmonary microvascular platform which specifically resembles many physiological aspects of the native lung environment. Such a platform could be used for pulmonary vascular disease modeling and drug testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Prognostic biomarkers are critically needed to determine patients with oral dysplastic lesions at risk for malignant transformation. We propose an innovative approach that combines high-dimensional imaging mass cytometry (IMC) and machine learning predictive modeling (iEN) to analyze a total of ~200 Formalin-Fixed Paraffin-Embedded (FFPE) patient tongue biopsies from the Oral Pathology Archive at the University of the Pacific (UOP), Arthur A. Dugoni School of Dentistry. Our goal is to establish a single- cell atlas of premalignant immune microenvironment in oral dysplasia and to identify immune features that predict the malignant transformation to oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OCSCC).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is consistent with broader public health goals focused on improving patient end-of-life care and patients’ expressed preferences for help with more comprehensive end-of-life care planning that includes advance care planning as well as other end of life issues such as emotional, relational, and financial. The proposed study will address this public health issue by refining and pilot testing a web-based program designed to assist cancer patients in comprehensively planning for their end of life, including advance care planning, estate planning, organizing documents and contacts, and addressing emotional, social, and spiritual needs. Therefore, this study is aligned with patients’ expressed preference for a more comprehensive approach to planning for end of life, as well as the NCI’s long-term goals of improving end of life planning and development of digital health tools, the NINR’s goals of identifying multi-dimensional palliative care needs of older adults and their family caregivers, and the NIA’s objective of incorporating social determinants of health and patient-centered variables.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Circulating platelets are implicated in the development and progression of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), a deadly disease of the lung vasculature for which there is no cure; but how these cells contribute to the disease is unknown. In this study, we will determine how changes in metabolism inside the platelet cause the platelet to spark inflammation in the blood vessels of the lung, which leads to injury of the blood vessel wall and development of PAH. If successful, this project will define the long unknown role of platelets in PAH progression, which will potentially lead to the development of therapies that target the platelet to treat PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: “Evolve to Next-Gen ACT” (ENACT) will develop and distribute new software tools that allow scientists and clinicians from 57 CTSA institutions to search for and analyze de-identified data from the electronic health records of over 142 million Americans across the country. Our user- friendly ENACT interface can be used on standard laptops to access many types of data from many sources to advance new medical discoveries for everyone and help with clinical care planning for individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), a common pregnancy complication, face elevated risk for later developing type 2 diabetes. Health professionals recommend that women with GDM be screened for diabetes after delivery and participate in lifestyle programs to help prevent type 2 diabetes; however, most women do not receive these services. This study will develop an outreach strategy to help maximize the number of women with GDM who take advantage of health services for type 2 diabetes prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many cancer patients suffer from pain, sleep, and mood problems and are using cannabis to relieve these symptoms. Cannabis may provide such relief but may also produce negative side effects including cognitive impairment, an especially problematic issue for cancer patients, indicating more research on cannabis use in the cancer context is required. In this endeavor, the present study seeks to compare the use of hemp-derived CBD with and without THC versus placebo on measures of sleep, pain, mood, subjective and objective cognitive functioning, and quality of life within 185 cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Antimicrobial resistance is an urgent problem that will result in millions of unnecessary deaths in the near future if the development of new antimicrobials is not significantly increased. We have worked diligently in developing a novel class of peptide-based antibiotics named A4X that successfully overcomes the limitations of current antimicrobial peptides and the urgent antimicrobial resistance problem associated with existing standard-of-care antibiotics. Our proposal outlines a rationalized design with the milestone-driven approaches to carry out a series of mechanistic and preclinical testing studies to further develop A4X. The goal of this proposal is to deliver a safe and effective new antimicrobial drug into IND-enabling ready at the end of the study to help initiate future clinical trial and overcome the crisis of antimicrobial and antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Cravings precede drug relapses in Substance Use Disorders, and the sequence from craving to relapse is poorly understood, as is the cravings a construct, which spans affective and behavioral components. In this project, we plan to develop novel data science methods to synthesize and characterize craving and affective signatures and build craving and affect detection and prediction models with multi-modal data along neuronal, physiological, affective, behavioral, and contextual dimensions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE The lifespan of people with HIV has been considerably extended, but the burden of age-related comorbidities remains high among them. This proposal will evaluate the role of mitochondrial function and DNA methylation in biological aging (represented by frailty phenotypes, epigenetic clock acceleration, and immunosenescence) among people with HIV, as well evaluate the potential of exercise to reverse mitochondrial function damage and epigenetic clock acceleration caused by HIV. Completion of this proposal will enhance the understanding of the role of mitochondrial function in age acceleration among people with HIV as well as highlight potential interventions to mitigate the damage, which ultimately could lead to improvements in treatment and long-term care strategies for people aging with HIV.

PHR: NARRATIVE Much mental health research relies on measurements of brain activity across different parts of the brain, and often poses difficult problems in statistical analysis. Of special interest is the way networks of interacting brain components may change under varying conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Corneal diseases and injuries that are often manifested through limbal stem cell dysfunction and loss are the major cause of visual impairment and corneal blindness. Our previous studies and scRNA- seq preliminary data formed the premise for the present proposal to uncover the regulatory role and contribution of each miR-146a main targeted pathways such as EGFR, Notch and NF-κB signaling in corneal epithelial regeneration in wounded and unwounded states in normal and diabetic corneas. This research will significantly advance our understanding of miR-146a mechanisms of regulation in corneal epithelial homeostasis, wound healing, and disease-related alterations for future therapeutic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The Multidisciplinary Research Training in Dental, Oral, and Craniofacial Sciences (MARTDOCS) program is designed to train the next generation of basic and clinical research faculty in dental, oral, and craniofacial research. This comprehensive program is built on the strong foundation of more than 20 years of successful training of PhD, DDS-PhD, and postdoctoral scholars by the OSU College of Dentistry Oral Biology Graduate Program (OBGP) and its partner programs in the OSU College of Medicine, the Biomedical Science Graduate Program (BSGP) and Neuroscience Graduate Program (NSGP). MARTDOCS uses a flexible graduate curriculum and established interdisciplinary research programs to provide high quality training and career development in a highly interactive health sciences center that has support from the College of Dentistry, College of Medicine, OSU Graduate School, OSU Center for Clinical and Translation Science Translation Science (CCTS) and the NIDCR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Humans are exposed to a complex mixture of chemicals through their environment, and it is of critical public health importance to assess how these exposures impact human health and risk of adverse outcomes. However, it is very challenging to disentangle the health effects of the different exposures due to dimensionality, nonlinearities, interactions and high correlation. This project develops transformative new tools for obtaining interpretable inferences on exposure effects for both mixtures and toxicological screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative:  This project develops a novel, continually adaptive learning framework which automatically and continually integrates and curates biomedical literature and knowledge. It allows researchers and curators to continually integrate individual lab-generated articles with large-scale public repositories, thereby enabling biomedical users to perform custom and context-based integrative literature analysis and exploration. This project produces a novel web-based tool for biomedical researchers and curators to access and navigate the useful scientific information at a personal level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Differences in disease risks among individuals in human populations can be characterized as quantitative traits with a complex genetic basis. However, our understanding of how DNA variation causes phenotypic variation remains incomplete. The proposed studies will reveal how DNA variation can lead to variation in the efficiency of mRNA translation, improving our knowledge about the genetic basis of complex quantitative traits, including human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: While nearly 6 million Americans are currently living with the debilitating effects of Alzheimer’s disease, the lack of treatment options and impoverished understanding of the underlying causes of cognitive decline, metabolic impairment, impaired gut function and other symptoms leads to severe impairments in quality of life. The proposed research will utilize an aged rat model of Alzheimer’s disease (TgF344-AD rats) to determine whether alterations in gut microbiome composition influence cognitive outcomes and the degree to which this is mediated by alterations in metabolic functioning. Findings from the proposed experiments may reveal specific peripheral targets that can be leveraged for the generation of potential therapeutic strategies against Alzheimer’s disease and related symptoms.

PHR: Project Narrative The IRACDA program is an opportunity for University of Chicago postdocs to combine a high-quality research experience with a mentored teaching and training experience at two local partner institutions. Participants will have a Research Mentor at the University of Chicago, where they will develop research-related skills and Teaching Mentors at partner institutions, where they will experience classroom teaching and pedagogical training. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Most disease-causing genetic variants do not directly affect genes, but rather the DNA sequences that control when and where genes function. This project introduces a new method to measure the activities of these control sequences, along with a quantitative framework for using the resulting data to predict the effects of genetic variation in these sequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study is designed to enhance understanding of the measurement of experiences, roles and dynamics for sexual and gender minority (SGM) caregivers of persons living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). The study will identify existing domains and develop new measures of ADRD caregiving, test and validate these measures, and ensure measures are inclusive and accurately capture caregiving constructs and experiences of diverse SGM ADRD caregivers. Our long-term goals are to ensure that SGM ADRD caregivers are included in ongoing ADRD caregiving research and measures, and that future interventions can support all ADRD caregivers and their care recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The size of heart attacks and patient survival even following successful current treatment is worse in elderly patients. Using mouse models of this problem, we will test a promising new application of a currently used drug to reduce heart injury during the heart attack. If successful, this new use of an approved drug could be fast-tracked toward clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Public Health Relevance Statement Difficulty communicating (aphasia) is one of the most common and debilitating results of left-hemisphere stroke. While aphasia symptoms are highly variable and recovery is difficult to predict, stroke size and location are significant determinants of outcomes. Research that leads to a more complete characterization of how stroke lesions affect residual brain function over the course of recovery will lead to a better understanding of the brain-behavior relationship in aphasia and has the potential to inform clinical decision-making in aphasia neurorehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal hematopoiesis, a highly prevalent condition in the elderly, arises from somatic mutations that endow a proliferative advantage to hematopoietic cells and imparts a substantial risk of coronary heart disease. Of the diverse mutations that promote clonal hematopoiesis, JAK2V617F and PPM1D mutations have been associated with DNA damage. The studies proposed here will elucidate the consequences of macrophage DNA damage and Ppm1d mutations on atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Clostridioides difficile is a major nosocomial pathogen that costs the US health care system ~$5 billion to treat each year. Since spore germination is required for C. difficile to initiate infection, elucidating the molecular mechanisms by which C. difficile senses bile acids and co-germinants to activate spore germination could inform the development of strategies for preventing C. difficile disease and recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The acute inflammatory response is the body’s first line of defense to invading pathogens or injury, which naturally resolves with the biosynthesis and actions of specialized pro-resolving mediators (SPMs). The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanisms that govern resolution programs in the bone marrow and to map the role of SPMs in directing hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell (HSPC) function(s) during homeostasis and infection to promote host defense using cutting-edge technologies. The improvement of our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that govern HSPC functions and their environment has direct clinical relevance by providing needed pre-clinical results for new therapeutic approaches that may help prevent complications associated with transplantation, such as infections and diseases with uncontrolled inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Asthma is a highly prevalent disease composed of different clinical and biologic phenotypes with variable responses to therapy. We have previously described the presence of Type 1 inflammation in approximately 30-40% of asthma patients which associates with more severe disease and poor response to therapy. This project seeks to expand our understanding of the of the pathologic mechanisms underlying this phenotype as well as the clinical manifestations over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electrophysiological recording systems allow direct observation of neural activity in animal subjects. This facilitates the study of crucial neuroscientific topics such as development, learning and memory, and cognition, as well as brain diseases such as Alzheimer’s, epilepsy, Parkinson’s, and depression. LeafLabs’ tools for performing high-channel count electrophysiology experiments in freely-moving rodents will allow researchers to collect and interpret neural data at a large scale, with few experimental constraints to environment complexity or the types of naturalistic behaviors studied.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Worldwide, Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) is surging, increasing health complications for mothers and infants. Therefore, it is necessary to improve our molecular understanding of GDM to prevent better and treat this pregnancy condition. In this context, studying the role of nutrient-sensing O-GlcNAc modification is highly significant not only to tie environmental influences on GDM development but also to explore new treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Closing critical gaps in the understanding of health outcomes for older adults with neurological disorders by clarifying the role of drug-drug and drug-disease interactions and systemic disparities in care processes may inform basic science and clinical practice research the development of care models able to achieve health equity. The proposed K24 research and training program will also expand the candidate's ability to effectively mentor trainees approaching neuroaging POR from multiple disciplines and clinical specialties. Ultimately, this project will help the candidate achieve her long term goals of (1) being a thought leader in neuroaging POR at the intersection of epidemiology and health services research, (2) producing new scientific knowledge that improves care and outcomes for older adults with neurological diseases, and (3) mentoring the next generation of leaders in multidisciplinary neuroaging POR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) are generated at unprecedented scale, with millions of people enrolled—presenting unprecedented opportunity to learn about the map between genetics and vulnerability to disease and other complex traits, but as the name suggests, GWAS only generate correlation data—and numerous challenges follow. We will develop statistical approaches to learn about the genetics and evolution of complex traits in humans, using biobank and other data. Our central aim is to understand the causes for the poorer performance of disease predictors based on GWAS data, thereby making a pivotal step towards a more equitable application of the genomic revolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The mission of the UCSF Biomedical Sciences training program is to train a diverse generation of new leaders in the biomedical sciences, equipping them with the knowledge and skills to perform rigorous and reproducible research that will uncover the biological mechanisms that underlie human health and disease. We prepare trainees for success in a variety of careers in which they will contribute to the biomedical scientific enterprise. Society will benefit from the discoveries and treatments that will result from the training of scientists who are motivated and able to apply fundamental and patient-based research approaches to advance human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The multidisciplinary UAB Immunology T32 Training Program, “Immunologic Diseases and Basic Immunology”, is focused on training highly motivated predoctoral students and PhD and MD graduates in the fields of translational and fundamental immunology. Our trainees are selected for their commitment to research and academic medicine. The success of their future investigator-initiated studies, which are best represented by R01-caliber projects, requires the development of skilled creativity and the ability to identify and achieve scientific goals of significance to the biomedical research enterprise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease is associated with bone loss and fractures in both children and adults, but bone protective therapies that are both proven and safe to use across the life-course in CKD are lacking. In this study, we will conduct a pilot, double-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 15 children and 88 adults evaluating the skeletal effects of potassium alkali therapy. These data will form the basis for a larger U01 proposal to determine the efficacy of potassium citrate on mitigating the effects of CKD on bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A number of recent experimental observations suggest that complex brain functions in the mammalian brain emerge from highly parallel and distributed computation in which information about sensory inputs, internal states, and behavioral parameters are mapped onto brain-wide neuronal populations. Recording the activity of such brain-wide distributed populations of neurons at adequate speed and resolution across tissue depths has remained a superb challenge. Here we propose strategies for development, optimization, and broader dissemination of a new optical imaging technology for recording large-scale brain activity of awake and behaving rodents with potential to provide a major advance in our understanding of how cognitive brain functions emerge from neuronal activity across distributed brain circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The adaptive immune response is shaped by a constellation of factors including genetics, immune preparedness, and antigen exposure that can protect us from or predispose or drive us to illness. While isolated data repositories exist that cover each of these factors, the proposed work will harmonize, integrate, and enhance those resources to enable a holistic understanding of adaptive immune responses. The systems-level analysis made possible by this knowledge integration will improve public health by accelerating the use of adaptive immune repertoire data to develop new therapeutics, diagnostics, and patient monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Special gut proteins called proteases can harm intestinal function in patients with irritable bowel syndrome. We have discovered that healthy microbes in the gut suppress proteases, whereas, unhealthy microbes do not. We will determine which microbes are critical in suppressing proteases and how they do it. Lastly, we plan to demonstrate that replacing these good microbes improves intestinal barrier function offering a strategy to treat irritable bowel syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  In this study, we will investigate the functional roles and mechanisms of one of the DNA methyltransferase, DNMT1, in regulating cyst progression and address if a histone methyltransferases, SMYD2, serves as a recruitment platform for DNMT1 on specific gene methylation, thus highlighting a previously unrecognized direct connection between two key epigenetic repression systems. We will then test whether de-methylation of hypermethylated DNA mediated by DNMT1 and/or together SMYD2 with their inhibitors delays cyst growth in vivo. Accomplishing this project will lead to a better understanding of the mechanism of renal cyst formation and will provide novel therapeutic targets for ADPKD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Diverse perspectives in biomedical and behavioral research lead to greater innovation and greater recognition of issues that continue to threaten the health, well-being, and inclusion of underrepresented communities. Consequently, increasing the diversity of biomedical and behavioral research scientists increases our potential to address the most urgent public health challenges, and is critical to the full realization of our national research goals. The proposed SF2UF program would integrate activities between a two-year college and a major research university to expand the pool of traditionally underrepresented (UR) students who are considering a career as a research scientist, recruit UF trainees from this pool and place them in mentored research environments with experienced faculty mentors at the research university, and support these trainees through to their graduation with a B.S. degree and continuation to a successful career in biomedical and behavioral research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Urban children with asthma are at high risk for short sleep, due to an environment that jeopardizes both sleep and asthma management. Further, urban children with asthma suffer from altered immune balance, a key biological process contributing to individual differences in asthma morbidity and sleep health. In the proposed research, we will examine the effects of shortened and recovery sleep on immune balance and associated changes in lung function in urban children with allergic asthma through an experimental design.

PHR: In this project the investigators seek to understand novel mechanisms of embryonic development and postnatal growth control in the gastrointestinal tract. Our study is focused on gastrointestinal mesenchyme, a fundamentally important tissue layer within the gastrointestinal tract that is often understudied. The proposed studies on regulation of the critical YAP/TEAD signaling in gut mesenchyme are essential to gain mechanistic insights into and develop new therapeutic strategies for GI diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Endocrine interactions have been demonstrated as causal and contributory to most common, most notably obesity, type 2 diabetes and resulting cardiovascular complications. The goal of this proposal is to closely bridge computational and experimental methods to systematically dissect mechanisms by which tissues communicate and how these interactions are perturbed in disease settings. Collectively, we will begin with newly developed and unbiased computational approaches which survey population data, validate using high-throughput in vitro assays and evaluate therapeutic potential of new endocrine interactions using mouse models of metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human tumors frequently develop following environmental exposure to toxins and xenobiotics. These compounds result in DNA damage to epithelial cells and induce an inflammatory microenvironment. We believe that the protein kinase MK2, and a subset of critical RNA-binding proteins function as lynchpins connecting inflammation to cancer, and that therapeutic targeting of these molecule will both reduce the incidence of tumor formation in response to environmental/inflammatory stimuli, and dramatically enhance the ability of tumor cells to be killed by conventional anti-cancer agents. We also propose to characterize a poorly understood RNA damage response that is induced by environmental stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many bacteria, including pathogenic Burkholderia species, utilize specific surface proteins to deliver an anti-bacterial protein toxin to neighboring bacteria upon direct cell-cell contact. Our proposed studies aim to determine the molecular requirements on both the `killer' and `target' cells for this inter-bacterial communication. By studying anti-bacterial proteins produced by these bacteria, this research will lay the foundation for the development of new antimicrobial therapies against Burkholderia and other antibiotic resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Primary and permanent tooth decay predicts lifelong oral health issues, and when left untreated, may produce pain, infection, and destruction of teeth and surrounding tissue, and myriad economic and social ramifications. Black children and adolescents in low-income households are at substantially greater risk for poor oral health outcomes. We will expand and test a culturally competent, online professional development course to prepare community health workers (CHWs) to provide oral health outreach to low-income Black parents/guardians of children and adolescents to build knowledge about oral health care and oral health resources, including how to navigate the oral health care system to prevent tooth decay and improve oral health across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Higher brain functions such as learning, memory and cognition require synaptic plasticity, i.e. the controlled changes in the strength of the connections between neurons. These functions require the Ca2+/calmodulin(CaM)-dependent protein kinase II (CaMKII) and are impaired both in normal aging and in Alzheimer's disease (AD), but to significantly different degrees. Preliminary studies indicate that the impairment in normal aging versus AD both involve mis-regulation of CaMKII, but by completely different mechanisms. These mechanisms will be tested further, with the ultimate goal to develop new therapeutic strategies for improving different cognitive impairments seen in the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to manipulate the expression of genes in cells and organisms is foundational to the study of genetics and to the development of gene therapies, yet simple and scalable methods to increase gene expression remain challenging. Through a combination of innovative high- throughput screens and cutting-edge computational modeling, we will develop a cohort of CRISPR-based tools that enable potent, tunable, and predictable increases in gene expression at any gene. The efforts described in this proposal will provide a next-generation gene activation toolkit with broad applicability in genetic screening and therapeutic gene activation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mild Traumatic Brain Injury (MTBI) is a major public health problem with U.S. annual incidence of over 2 million yet the underlying pathology remains unclear and clinicians cannot identify those who will have prolonged symptoms. Early studies often grouped a broad variety of symptoms together (e.g., cognitive, vestibular, oculomotor, behavioral), making it difficult to parse imaging markers sensitive to particular clinical symptom domains. This proposal aims to employ innovative MRI techniques to study microstructural and macrostructural injury as they specifically relate to cognitive symptoms in MTBI patients, translating promising evidence from cell and animal studies to a clinical MTBI population; the results of this investigation are expected to establish the dynamic longitudinal microstructural changes that occur after MTBI, investigating the link between white matter injury, cortical volume loss and cognition-specific outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research program aims to advance our knowledge on myosin-3 motors, unique kinase-myosin hybrids that play crucial roles in the organization of the actin cytoskeleton in fundamental processes including hearing and vision. This research uses biochemical, biophysical, structural and cell biological approaches to understand the enzymology, regulation and interactome of myosin-3 motors. Results from this research are expected to provide detailed mechanistic insights into the role of myosin-3 motors in human health and disease.

PHR: Project Narrative: NPM-ALK+ anaplastic large cell lymphomas are aggressive forms of pediatric mature T cell lymphoma and over 30% of patients experiences disease progression or relapse without robust prognostic biomarkers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: It is thought that many neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders, including ones that effect visual perception, lead to disruptions in synaptic integrity and stability, resulting in wiring deficits and perturbed brain function. We understand little regarding how disruptions in synapse formation and circuit connectivity arise, largely due to paucity of methods to visualize such events as they occur in vivo. In this proposal we combine innovative in vivo imaging technology and labeling methods with classical visual manipulations to establish a baseline characterization of the molecular events in excitatory synapse formation and stabilization, and investigate how the proteomic content of a synapse reflects its circuit identity, dynamic lifetime, and propensity for plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: III. PROJECT NARRATIVE Human metapneumovirus (HMPV) is a debilitating infection and leading cause of severe respiratory infections in young children, the elderly, and the immunocompromised. The specific mechanism behind the impaired immune response to HMPV in the elderly leading to severe respiratory disease is incompletely understood. In this proposal, I aim to elucidate the age-specific differences in the immune response to HMPV in the lung utilizing the aged murine model to identify candidate molecules/pathways that ultimately can be clinically translatable and targeted in an HMPV vaccine as well as the management and treatment of related respiratory viruses afflicting the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Bridges to the Doctorate Training Program at California State University, Long Beach will partner with University of California, Irvine to form a seamless bridge to support biomedical Master’s degree students transitioning to Ph.D. programs. Both universities have a highly-diverse student population and rigorous STEM programs, nationally recognized for their excellence. This proposal describes curriculum and activities at both CSULB and UCI that aim to develop a strong sense of science identity and belonging along with superb research design and technical skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  New treatments are needed for bipolar disorder (BD), a lifelong illness in ~3% of United States adults that is associated with disability, chronic medical problems, and premature death. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a focal, non-invasive form of brain stimulation that shows promise for BD, but the optimal brain regions to target for mania, depression, or mood stabilization are unclear. The purpose of this project is to derive treatment targets for BD using brain lesions that cause mania or depression, and to validate these lesion- derived targets in patients with BD using functional neuroimaging and behavioral testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Prostate cancer is the second most commonly diagnosed malignancy in men, and there are urgent needs to identify causally related protein biomarkers and build improved prediction models for prostate cancer risk and aggressiveness. The proposed study will identify causally related protein biomarkers for prostate cancer using an innovative design of combining novel statistical methods and functional characterization and develop improved prostate cancer prediction models across Africans and Europeans using novel methods. Knowledge generated by this project will not only significantly contribute to the etiologic understanding of prostate cancer, but also have potential utility in improving its risk/aggressiveness assessment in Africans and Europeans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Overall The Core Grant for Vision Research provides support and facilities which are not available and cannot be obtained through individual grants to 24 vision research investigators at Baylor College of Medicine, carrying 19 eligible NEI RO1s. The Core facilities are used to study how visual system disorders, such as retinitis pigmentosa, age-related macular degeneration, glaucoma, amblyopia and strabismus occur and to determine what neuronal and synaptic mechanisms in the visual system are responsible for the pathogenesis of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are major public health issues in the United States that are expected to burden an increasing number of older adults and their families in the coming decades. This proposal will examine how characteristics of the social context shape trajectories of cognition and ADRD, focusing on changes in social networks, social activities, and neighborhood social infrastructure, and the roles of olfactory functioning and inflammation as potential mechanisms. The results of this project will inform research on the social pathways of sensory and cognitive functioning, and illuminate the social context as a potential site of intervention for preventing or slowing age-related cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every researcher benefits from understanding what has been done previously by other scientists prior to beginning their own scientific investigation. The proposed project, the creation of freely available educational modules on the topic of evidence synthesis, aims to help scientists do this. Creating better literature review skill sets among scientists means less wasteful research is generated and a higher likelihood of improving public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is an age- and neurodegenerative related disease estimated to affect five million or more of the ageing American population by 2050. There is thus an urgent need to identify unique predictive signatures that correlate with developing AD. By using multi- parametric measurements with enabling technologies like multiplexed ion beam imaging (MIBI) we will be able to uncouple unhealthy brain senescence, that could be therapeutically targeted, from that associated with the normal aging process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Genomics and Bioinformatics Module The Genomics and Bioinformatics Module is an important resource that addresses the increasing need of the vision researchers at Baylor College of Medicine to access the state-of-the art genomic technologies that are not available in individual laboratories and provides critical bioinformatics support in deciphering the vast amount of data. This module will leverage the expertise, technologies, and resources at the BCM Human Genome Sequencing Center (BCM-HGSC), one of the three major genome centers in the US. In addition to providing service, the module will also serve as a key mechanism to introduce cutting edge genomics and single cell technologies to vision researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with advanced cancer have not fully benefited from advance care planning due to the high levels of anxiety and depression experienced and other barriers that affect their appraisals and coping. Despite the protective effects of resilience, there have been few clinical trials improving the resilience skills of patients with advanced cancer and their family caregivers to help initiate advance care planning discussions and sustain engagement. This research will provide new insights through using a dyadic intervention approach to advance care planning while developing and evaluating a web-based resilience- building intervention to improve the completion of advance directives, resilience, coping, anxiety, and depression for patients with advanced cancer and their family caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Rapid and quantitative detection of KRAS circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) from blood with a simple workflow and inexpensive instrument will open opportunities for point of care therapy selection and remission monitoring. To address limitations of sensitivity, sequence specificity, cost, and complexity of existing technologies, this project will develop and rigorously characterize a digital-resolution biomolecular sensing technology combined with an isothermal CRISPR/Cas-based amplification process to achieve multiplexed detection of mutant genes with <0.001% mutant allele frequency. The approach is applicable to broad classes of ctDNA for many forms of cancer with FDA-approved targeted therapies, and even more cancers for minimal residual disease monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative (Public relevance statement) This project enhances understanding of developmental language disorder within diverse populations. Children with developmental language disorder have different profiles of language deficits that reflect their language-learning environments, but they may share common underlying deficits in basic cognitive processing skills such as attention, memory, and processing speed. This project will investigate these processing skills at the individual level in monolingual and bilingual school-age children with and without developmental language disorder and determine whether deficits in cognitive processing skills can contribute to effective identification of developmental language disorder in children who have different language- learning experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the novel computational models developed will be able to leverage experimental data to help answer fundamental biological questions about the causes and effects of inﬂammatory swelling. Computational models are essential for understanding the complexity of biological systems, and offer safe and effective methods for the testing of hypotheses. Therefore, the project is relevant to the NIGM's mission of increasing our understanding of biological processes and laying the foundation for advances in disease, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Natural product compounds occupy a central role in medicine in providing lifesaving drugs. Supply challenges however often constrain the biomedical potential of promising bioactive natural products from rare or environmentally sensitive marine organisms. Our discovery of the first terpenoid biosynthesis genes in marine animals and amongst the first in marine algae towards flagship bioactive molecules like the anti-inflammatory pseudodopterosin and anticancer halomon offers a path to bioengineering drug leads from marine organisms from sustainable laboratory microbial fermentation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE By modulating the activity of ligand gated ion channels (LGICs) and G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), complex natural products have the potential to reveal critical insight into the function of these therapeutically important membrane receptors. This proposal investigates the synthesis and evaluation of two classes of natural products and their development into new chemical tools to investigate LGIC and GPCR pharmacology. By providing new directions to rationally design small molecules that engage their receptors targets, the results from this research will ultimately lead to safer, more effective medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Million Marker is the first company to provide tools and services that allow people to understand their personal environmental chemical exposures (i.e. endocrine disrupting chemicals, EDCs) in order to prevent diseases and optimize their health by changing their lifestyle choices. This work aims to develop an affordable and scalable intervention program, with interactive curriculum and individualized support, that can be readily disseminated and commercialized to help customers reduce exposures to EDCs. Completion of this proposal will allow Million Marker to offer EDC testing and intervention to the general public, thus taking steps to address this global health crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Measurements of blood pressure are broadly used as a cardiovascular health indicator, but the common cuff-based device by artery occlusion cannot be reliably translated into the central systemic circulation and will miss the entire pulmonary circulation. We propose to develop a noninvasive wearable radio-frequency sensor to measure the instantaneous vibration characteristics of the aorta and pulmonary artery, which can then in turn be used to derive the entire blood pressure transients in each heartbeat, including the systolic and diastolic blood pressures of the systemic and pulmonary circulation. A mechanical model and a pig animal model will be employed to verify the measurement accuracy against the gold-standard catheter-based fluid pressure-volume sensor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is nearly unique to older persons, affects 2.5 million individuals, and has no proven medication treatments. In this project, we will test repurposing of metformin, a generic, inexpensive, well-tolerated drug with a wide range of beneficial anti-aging properties, to determine if it will improve symptoms and quality of life in older persons with HFpEF. We will also examine if metformin acts by improving inflammation originating from the bacterial environment in the gut (microbiome).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section The nuclear protein PARP-1 is an enzyme that controls gene expression programs in a variety of hormone- and diet-regulated biological systems, including adipogenesis and inflammation.  Our proposed studies will shed new light on the molecular mechanisms underlying the control of gene expression by PARP-1 in preadipocytes and macrophages, two cell types in adipose tissue that function as important mediators of obesity.  Out studies may suggest better ways to target PARP-1 to regulate metabolism and mitigate the pathological effects of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Poor sleep among persons with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) and their caregivers negatively impacts both of their health outcomes and caregivers’ ability to keep their loved ones at home. This proposal will test efficacy of an innovative sleep intervention program (in-person and telehealth) that targets both members of the dyad simultaneously in a randomized controlled trial. Improved sleep in persons with ADRD and their caregivers may improve health and quality of life, and prevent or delay admission of ADRD patients to institutional settings, potentially leading to decreased healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perturbations in blood clotting and inflammation are present in many Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients. We will use purified proteins as well as mouse and human samples to study how the interaction between the pathogenic AD peptide Aβ and the blood protein fibrinogen leads to disease severity. These studies may help clarify the contributions of fibrin, the major blood clotting protein, in AD pathology to pave the way for new diagnostics and therapies for human AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation (AF) is an increasing clinical problem, and despite identification of strong genetic connections, genetic findings have yet to achieve clinical applications. This Program aims to advance AF genomic discoveries toward the bedside, focusing on genes to mechanisms, genes to drugs, and interactions of genes with metabolism and environment. The 4 highly integrated projects and cores aim to bridge basic research in AF towards clinically actionable therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gender inequities are prevalent and persistent in the biomedical sciences, and workforce inequities have worsened over the past 18 months as the COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately impacted on female, minority, and early career investigators. To reduce pandemic-related effects and minimize worsening inequities long-term, we propose a randomized study to evaluate a novel, scalable, and theory-based professional coaching intervention called iACTIVATE directed at early career female investigators. We will test whether this coaching program can lead to improved self-efficacy, research productivity, and career advancement as well as examine potential mechanisms for outcomes; if successful, the novel program will be ready to scale to the broader biomedical research workforce nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Chicago ARea Excellence in Education & Research (CAREER) program is committed to training postdoctoral scholars as researchers, focused on cutting-edge biomedical science relevant to human health, and as teachers, with an emphasis on preparing trainees to educate diverse and underserved populations. Collaboration between UIC and Governors State University serves as the foundation for this program and incorporates team-based mentoring from both schools, along with career development, to generate outstanding future faculty. Postdoctoral scholars trained by CAREER will therefore be well-prepared for careers in academia and as such will have a significant impact on training the future generations of students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Patients who have heart failure, or the inability of the heart to pump blood efficiently to the body, have reduced quality of life, exercise intolerance, and are at greater risk for poor outcomes including death. This proposal seeks to define a novel pathway of treatment in patients with heart failure using an alternative energy source (ketone bodies). If beneficial, the results of our study may inspire larger studies and trials of such therapy in patients with heart failure in order to improve symptoms, quality of life, and ultimately reduce morbidity and mortality from heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is an autoimmune disease driven by activated lymphocytes with significant morbidity and mortality and no FDA-approved therapy for its treatment. Our company, Trethera, is developing a novel small molecule drug, TRE-515, to treat ADEM by targeting a pathway required for lymphocyte proliferation. In the proposed project, we will conduct critical preclinical work to further evaluate how TRE-515 affects immune cell development and interacts with other drugs used to treat ADEM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The HIV and opioid epidemics intersect, impacting millions of people worldwide. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) has improved and extended the lives of people with HIV, PWH. However, milder chronic HIV associated neurocognitive impairments (NCI) of varying severity known as mild HAND or HIV-NCI persist. HIV-NCI affect 15-40% of PWH and because they persist for life, can worsen with age, and affect adherence to medications, they can significantly reduce quality of life and increase mortality risk. NCI progression appears to correlate with increased HIV in the CNS despite ART. Ongoing low level neuroinflammation also mediates HIV-NCI. Many PWH have opioid use disorder, a comorbidity in PWH that can potentially exacerbate NCI. Our exciting and novel results suggest that buprenorphine, an established opiate substitution therapy (OST) that is used to treat addiction and withdrawal, prevents/reverses cognitive impairment in EcoHIV infected mice, by reducing inflammatory HIV infected/uninfected monocyte entry into the brain, limiting viral seeding of CNS reservoirs, and thus the neuroinflammatory and viral neurotoxic activities that mediate HIV-neurocognitive impairment. Our proposed studies are to characterize the mechanisms by which buprenorphine can mitigate cognitive impairment in PWH with and without OUD. We hypothesize that the positive impact of buprenorphine on HIV- NCI is mediated though MOR and KOR, and specifically their expression on monocytes and myeloid cells. For our innovative studies we will use human monocytes HIV infected in vitro, the Eco-HIV infected mouse model, and PBMC from three different groups of PWH on ART who will undergo cognitive testing at the time of blood draw: 1) PWH taking no opioids or opioid antagonists, 2) PWH taking buprenorphine, and 3) PWH taking prescription opioids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioids cause many changes in the brain, some of which underlie substance use disorder, but most of which merely reflect exposure to drug, including benefits such as pain relief. Identifying the neural substrates underlying the pathologic side effects of opioid use, and disentangling them from the beneficial effects of opioid drugs in particular, will be critical for intervening in the opioid crisis. Here we will assess cell type specific changes in gene expression that occur in mice that do and do not develop opioid dependence.
