IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal focuses on understanding how a loss-of-function genetic variation of an enzyme called DUOX2 that controls gut bacteria within our GI tract could lead to early stages of disease development in IBD. A more in-depth investigation of a defect in DUOX2 activity is expected to uncover the overgrowth of disease-triggering gram-negative bacteria able to cause a breach in the intestinal barrier triggering the early stages of GI disorders including IBD but also other diseases associated with similar changes in gut microbiota such as colon cancer, obesity, diabetes, fatty liver disease, and metabolic syndromes. Because our study addresses an early event common to a number of diseases, the successful completion of our project may have significant implications for disease prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biological networks are often spatially organized to ensure that reactions inside cells occur at the right place and time, particularly in fundamental processes like cell signaling and genome regulation. We will systematically explore the relationship between spatial organization and function in these systems with quantitative biochemical assays, structural methods, cell-based studies, and new synthetic biology tools. This approach will enable us to understand underlying regulatory principles and how to intervene when these processes are misregulated in human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite many recent advances to diversify the STEM workforce, many groups remain unequally and unjustly represented in the biomedical sciences research workforce, with an increase in underrepresentation in matriculation to 4-year colleges and universities from community college. The Bridges to the Baccalaureate Research Training Program at Florida A&M University aims to provide structured, evidence-based approaches in the recruitment, training, and graduation of talented and motivated underrepresented undergraduate students from Tallahassee Community College and Florida A&M University. Implementation of such approaches within a partnership between a community college with a high underrepresented student population and Florida’s only state-funded Historically Black College and University (HBCU), will equip trainees and students at both institutions with the technical, operational, and professional skills required for careers in the biomedical research workforce, thereby aiding in diversification of the STEM workforce, and enabling graduates to address the nation’s biomedical, behavioral, and clinical research needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with postoperative delirium are at higher risk for other surgical complications, prolonged hospital stays, cognitive decline, higher costs, and mortality. As nearly half of delirium cases can be prevented with multicomponent interventions, identifying high risk patients preoperatively may offer an opportunity to improve their perioperative cognitive health. This project will develop and test a passive method for postoperative delirium risk prediction using routine care electronic health data and artificial intelligence techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria remains one of the biggest infectious disease problems in the world, and a major reason for the continued problem is resistance of malaria parasites to available drugs. Resistance appears to be increasing, in particular to components of new artemisinin-based combination regimens. The goals of this project will be to assess resistance to antimalarial drugs in Uganda, to characterize genetic features of parasites with varied drug sensitivity, and to characterize impacts of varied drug sensitivity on parasite fitness, all to offer tools to better control the spread of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surgery is the current mainstay treatment for head and neck cancer and the survival rate in these patients has not changed in the past decade. To avoid positive tumor margins, excessive normal tissue is also surgically removed exacerbating the poor quality of life in these patients. There is no localized treatment that can shrink the tumors to avoid surgery or to enable minimal removal of normal tissue. To address this major need, we are developing a nanoplatform called Verosite to aid in image-guided oxygen enhanced photodynamic treatment of tumors that can drastically reduce normal tissue resection and recurrence rates leading to improvement in the overall health and patients’ quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease is a devastating disease with enormous unmet medical need and few treatments, and it is likely necessary to understand, detect, and treat Alzheimer’s Disease earlier in disease development. Patients often exhibit aberrant neural activity very early, even before Alzheimer’s Disease pathology or cognitive decline, and aberrant neural activity may be a primary driver of and tractable therapeutic target for Alzheimer’s Disease. This project has discovered a neural stimulation approach that fully restores learning and memory function in an Alzheimer’s mouse model, and will use cutting-edge systems neuroscience techniques to conduct single-cell resolution examination and perturbation of the brain to determine the mechanistic role of aberrant neural activity in cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s Disease and how it is reversed, to help the intelligent design of new, precise, and earlier biomarkers, diagnostic strategies, and therapeutic treatments.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulation of gene expression at the RNA level in the germline is crucial for directing proper germ cell function and gametogenesis while maintaining the plasticity necessary for embryonic development. This study will explore the role of ADARs, a class of RNA binding protein, in germline RNA regulation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To explore therapeutic platforms for glioblastoma (GBM), we have developed a new transgenic mouse model of T cell receptor (TCR)-directed cell therapy (“MISTIC”) against an endogenous neoantigen in GL261 to explore the efficacy of this treatment approach in established transplantable mouse models and also a novel model of EGFR-driven and neoantigen-defined spontaneous GBM. We will evaluate how to engineer MISTIC T cells to be able to remodel the GBM microenvironment and effectively treat heterogeneous GBM tumors and also explore why some tumors are able to escape adoptive cell therapy. Together, our proposed work will provide new insights into the effective use of directed and engineered TCR cell therapy in GBM that will expand our understanding of immunotherapeutic approaches in the central nervous system and also establish a foundation for immediate clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will integrate chemoproteomics, metabolomics, and mouse physiology to identify intracellular transport mechanisms for signaling metabolites. Using metabolite-like chemical probes, we will perform proteome-wide interaction studies to map dedicated protein machinery responsible for trafficking nuclear receptor ligands to the nucleus. Completing this work will shed light on the regulation of intracellular metabolite trafficking and its impact on nuclear receptors’ transcriptional activity. Additionally, completion of these studies will provide new targets for developing therapeutic agents that modulate nuclear receptor function by controlling ligand availability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will determine how T cells are activated. T cells are the cells of the immune system that kill tumor cells and provide protection against viruses and bacteria. When T cells are mis-activated they can attack one’s own organs and cause autoimmunity. The results of our work will provide new ways to engineer T cells for better anti-tumor specificity as well as new ways to use drugs to counter over-activated or mis-activated T cells, thereby reducing inflammation and autoimmunity. This project supports the NIH’s mission and aligns with its high-priority effort to address critical current and future issues in public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) accounts for disproportionately high morbidity and mortality in the pediatric population; one-third of patients will relapse, many despite having no detectable disease after therapy by all clinically available assays. Our research will evaluate the predictive value for relapse of novel molecular modalities for measurable residual disease (MRD) detection in retrospective and prospective cohorts of pediatric AML patients. Through this work we will lay a foundation for more comprehensive MRD assessment in pediatric AML that will ultimately enhance relapse prediction and early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The neurotransmitter dopamine is essential for central nervous system control of locomotor activity, cognition and reward mechanisms. As such, dopamine is involved in several neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric disorders, such as Parkinson’s disease, schizophrenia, ADHD and drug addiction. Dopamine transporter (DAT) serves to terminate dopamine neurotransmission and is a principal target of cocaine, methylphenidate and amphetamines. Revealing the components and processes that regulate DAT in intact brain as proposed in this application may lead to new strategies in the therapeutic intervention with drug addiction.

This project is designed to create a laboratory measurement, called a biomarker, that is used to monitor whether a treatment is having beneficial effects, and speed up the process of making new treatments available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The stomach is an important barricade that kills many bacteria before they can cause illness, in part by using its acidity to inactivate bacterial proteins. Some bacteria contain small chaperone proteins called HdeA and HdeB that help protect other proteins from becoming permanently inactivated and therefore help bacteria survive and cause infection. We are interested in studying, in-depth, how HdeA and HdeB work as a team to protect other proteins, and also how targeted modifications of each chaperone affect their structure and function; the insight we gain may aid others in the development of vaccines or therapeutics that combat dysentery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recommendations for addressing the high burden of insufficient sleep among adolescents largely focus on individual-level factors (e.g. sleep hygiene), but the contribution of adolescents' larger environmental context to sleep health has been understudied. The proposed study will expand traditional approaches to assessing environmental effects on health by using advanced, spatiotemporal exposure assessment methods to understand how adolescents' home and neighborhood environments adolescents influence their sleep. This work will provide foundational knowledge regarding adolescents' environmental risks that will lead to an improved understanding of the determinants of adolescent sleep and development of an approach that can be applied across a wide range of modifiable health behaviors to inform preventive interventions and health policies aimed at improving cardiovascular health across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Meal timing and frequency impact the glycemic responses of both diabetic and nondiabetic individuals, and we have shown that the insulinemic response to the first meal is the key determinant of the metabolic response to the second meal. The proposed studies will address questions relevant to this, including whether the direct effect of morning hyperinsulinemia on the liver is the key factor impacting the second meal response and, if so, whether insulin delivery into the peripheral circulation (the route of delivery for the majority of those with insulin-treated diabetes) can produce a similar response. Moreover, we will identify the second meal factor (elevated glucose or insulin or the signal generated by intraportal entry of glucose) most clearly impacted by the first meal, which can also provide valuable information for designing new treatments for those with diabetes and pre-diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project aims to develop and apply advanced and scalable and interpretable statistical and machine learning methods and tools to empower the integrative analysis of large-scale biobanks, germline and somatic whole genome/exome sequencing (WGS/WES) cancer studies and experimental single cell based cell-specific omic data. These methods and tools will accelerate the progress in advancing from cancer gene mapping to mechanisms to cancer precision prevention and medicine. We will develop open access high-performance cluster and cloud based software of these methods and data resources and make them available to the cancer research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: The long-term goal of this study is to determine how vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) regulates basal dopamine transmission and methamphetamine regulation of dopamine neurons. Our preliminary data support the idea that VNS can decrease methamphetamine- mediated stimulation of dopamine transmission. Our proposed mechanism is that VNS depolarizes dopamine neurons, internalizes dopamine transporter, and increases basal dopamine levels to bring about methamphetamine desensitization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension remains a major contributor to morbidity and mortality in the United States, and a fifth of affected individuals have a form of hypertension that appears resistant to usual approaches. The ability to reliably distinguish true resistant hypertension from pseudo-resistant hypertension (due to under-prescribing, medication non-adherence, or white coat effect) is essential for minimizing diagnostic and therapeutic errors. We will use electronic health record based analytics and tools to develop a clinically feasible and pragmatic approach to improving the quality and value of care for patients with resistant hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study addresses two key questions: Does the chronic stress of dementia spousal caregiving accelerate molecular aging? Can caregiving-related distress propel molecular aging and shorten health span (the length of time that a person is healthy—not just alive)? This project will provide insight into the pathways through which caregiving can produce substantial health risks, and it will also explore possible paths to caregiving’s potential health benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing evidence demonstrates that systemic sclerosis-related constipation (SSc-constipation) is a common and often severe problem, associated with significant morbidity and mortality. However, several subgroups of SSc-constipation exist [i.e. slow colonic transit, rectal hyposensitivity, or anorectal dyssynergy (i.e. pelvic floor dysfunction)], and are hypothesized to have different mechanisms which may involve abnormal autonomic and pelvic reflexes. In this proposal we will interrogate the relationship between each SSc-constipation subgroup and [1] physiological responses to transcutaneous electrical acustimulation (an intervention that is known to alter autonomic and pelvic reflexes); [2] measures of autonomic dysfunction; and [3] inflammation to better understand disease mechanism and predict response to therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral palsy (CP) is a common (prevalence 1 in 500) developmental brain disorder affecting early motor development, and although birth asphyxia was long considered the most frequent cause, it actually accounts for less than 10% of CP cases. Recent evidence, which requires further investigation, indicates that a large proportion of CP is likely genomic in origin. We propose a novel, cost-effective strategy to leverage genomic and clinical data from Geisinger’s healthcare-based population and referrals from a major clinical genetics laboratory to enroll individuals with CP and identify the critical regions of the genome and individual genes responsible for CP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance to Public Health Older adults disproportionately experience high rates of “low-value care” – tests and procedures with no benefit that often harm patients. This proposal aims to advance academic-health system partnerships in real-world settings to reduce wasteful spending, ensure that patients receive appropriate and high-quality care, and reduce racial and ethnic disparities in the receipt of high-value care. The proposed infrastructure will also facilitate mentoring and support the next generation of patient-oriented researchers in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Clinical trial of the photovoltaic substitute for the lost photoreceptors in AMD patients confirmed the safety of such implants (PRIMA) and spatial resolution closely matching the 100µm pixel size. This proposal describes three complimentary approaches to advance this technology towards 20µm pixels in order to enable visual acuity exceeding 20/100, which should allow highly functional restoration of sight. All three approaches, including the pillar electrodes and optical current steering, demonstrated very encouraging preliminary results, and will now be developed to the full extent.

PHR: NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic, systemic autoimmune disease with a female to male ratio of 9:1. We recently identified an evolutionary conserved sex-biased transcriptional regulator VGLL3, which leads to development of an IL-7 dependent SLE-like disease when overexpressed in skin. In this application we will elucidate the mechanism of this novel VGLL3-IL7-autoimmune pathway in SLE pathogenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian cerebral cortex is the center of remarkable cognitive, perceptive, and motor capabilities, the execution of which depends on the correct assembly of circuit connectivity during development. Miswiring of cortical circuitry can contribute to disorders of brain development. In this study, we seek to understand the roles of subplate neurons in orchestrating the formation of cortical circuits, and the potential contribution of subplate neuron dysfunction to neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Amblyopia (`lazy eye') is the leading cause of monocular vision loss in children worldwide and affects 3-5% of the population. With current patching treatment, the success rate is about 60-80% with 20-25% recurrence following the treatment, leaving about one third of affected children with amblyopia that persists into adulthood. Visual suppression plays a critical role in developing amblyopia, failure of treatment, and regress following the treatment. This project aims to comprehensively investigate the neural basis of how and where amblyopic suppression occurs in the brain. Understanding the neural mechanisms underlying visual suppression can significantly help prevent and treat amblyopia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is a leading modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular and renal disease that remains suboptimally controlled in at least one third of treated patients, putting them at an increased risk of premature death. Biological sex has become increasingly recognized as a pivotal factor affecting the development and pathophysiological outcomes of hypertension, however limited understanding of the sex-specific mechanisms regulating blood pressure poses a critical barrier to the optimization of antihypertensive therapies. The current proposal addresses this knowledge gap and improves our understanding of blood pressure control mechanisms in both sexes.

PHR: NARRATIVE Hand tendon injures are very common and need surgical repair, however, the clinical results after repair have not reached patients’ satisfaction because of adhesion and scar formation that glue the injured tendon to the neighboring tissues and harms the hand function. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Many Hispanics who have an alcohol use disorder face much greater difficulties getting treatment than non- Hispanic Whites. This disparity exists partially because there are not enough Spanish-speaking treatment providers who can deliver culturally adapted treatments. This research will develop a brief culturally adapted mobile treatment for alcohol use disorder that Spanish-speaking Hispanics can use through their smartphones on days when they are at high risk for drinking (e.g. weekends, holidays).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative DNA breaks and repairs have been linked to opioid use disorders. To elucidate the mechanism for this, we propose to characterize the changes in DNA damage and repair sites and the associated changes in chromatin accessibility and gene expression in specific types of neurons in mice that self-administered heroin. Our study will therefore provide a novel mechanism for the epigenetic regulation of the transcriptional and behavioral maladaptations underlying opioid addiction, which will fundamentally advance the understanding of the neurobiology of drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: Numerous biological processes from the immune system to development rely on the ability of biomolecular systems to correctly recognize one molecular signal, such as a viral or signaling protein or a combination of molecules, against a sea of decoys. The goal of the proposed research program is to develop new computational tools and principles that can harness high- throughput experimental data to provide a predictive understanding of how such recognition works, how recognition can go wrong and how it can be engineered on different scales.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE In 2019, Hispanic/Latinx individuals were awarded 8.6% of the 187,568 doctoral degrees awarded in the US despite accounting for 18.5% of the US population, and African American graduates were awarded 9.2% of degrees awarded despite accounting for 12.5% of the population, a disparity which drives a lack of diversity among faculty at leading health institutions and in the field of substance use research. There is a need to focus on the necessary first step to increasing diversity in substance use treatment and prevention research: getting college-aged scholars of color who have been underrepresented in academic medicine and public health to attend graduate programs at Research 1 (R1; Carnegie very high research activity designation) institutions where rigorous training will enable independence. The primary innovation of this R25 proposal is its ability to deliberately build a substantial and sustainable pathway between six Hispanic-Serving Institutions and New York University to both identify and enroll exceptional underrepresented undergraduate students into a training program that will provide a pathway to doctoral training in substance use research at R1 institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The short-term goal of this K23 award is the development of the PI as an independent investigator skilled in the assessment and behavioral intervention, most especially focused on underrepresented and vulnerable aging populations, in rural regions who are disproportionately impacted by dementia. The proposed research will use a non-pharmacological, environmental approach to develop assessments and tailored interventions that can be delivered via telehealth to improve behaviors and activity engagement for people with dementia in their home. The long-term goal is to empower older adults with dementia to age in place within their home with minimal behavior disruption and maximum activity participation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project narrative Why the repeated activation of the fight-or-flight response increases disease susceptibility and reduces lifespan is poorly understood. Using the nematode C. elegans as a model, this proposal aims to gain fundamental understanding of how stress neurohormones activate the highly conserved insulin pathway that regulates stress resistance and aging. These studies will provide crucial new insights that will inform the treatment of people suffering from stress disorders, which are associated with accelerated aging and increased susceptibility to diabetes, cardiovascular- and infectious-diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative The primary goal of our program is the career development of the next generation of scientific leaders in the biomedical sciences. Our program is uniquely positioned to recruit internal medicine residents of varied backgrounds and experiences to undergo mentored research training that will ultimately help to foster highly diverse and skilled physician-investigators. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a highly aggressive, recalcitrant, and deadly cancer that can only be effectively treated if fortuitously detected early; however, no early detection protocol exists. We have discovered that the presence of tumor-specific autoantibodies can accurately predict SCLC earlier. Radioimmunoconjugates based on these autoantibodies could also be used to image SCLC tumors, creating a paradigm in which the early detection of SCLC biomarkers circulating in blood triggers targeted PET imaging and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Drug-resistant epilepsy is a debilitating disease that affects millions of people. One of the most effective treatments is dietary therapy that changes brain metabolism, but the mechanism by which this difficult diet prevents seizures remains poorly understood. This study uses gene alteration in a mouse to produce a similar metabolism-based seizure resistance, and to define the molecular and cellular mechanism for this seizure resistance and discover pharmacological tools that mimic it, with the ultimate goal of finding new therapeutic approaches that exploit this anticonvulsant mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic changes in the single gene, MYH7, which encodes the major motor protein in the heart, cause a variety of human heart diseases, called cardiomyopathies. Up to 1/250 individuals carries a genetic change in this gene. Through this work, we will detail why specific genetic defects cause a specific type of developmental heart disease which manifest as cardiomyopathies, and this information will help identify and reduce disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Burkitt lymphoma (BL) and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) are highly aggressive and genetically complex B-cell lymphomas. Standard treatment with high-intensity chemotherapy leads to treatment- related mortality in approximately 10% of patients and fails to cure approximately 36-40% of patients. Investigating the genetic, epigenetic and immunological etiology of BL may inform future rational therapeutic strategies, and is likely to improve the outcome of these patients and have a substantial impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Eph cell surface receptors comprise a large family with 14 members; these receptors play important roles in physiological and pathological processes by assembling into signaling complexes that control cell behavior. This proposal will study the unique features of heterogeneous complexes formed by the EphA2 receptor together with other Eph receptors, which we hypothesize have distinctive signaling properties compared to homogeneous EphA2 complexes. We anticipate that our studies will ultimately inform the design of new therapies targeting mixed EphA2-Eph signaling platforms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The onset and progression of Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) stems from the complex interaction between lifestyle, nutrition, and genetics. To better understand how the interaction between diet and genetics contributes to T2D, we are conducting whole-genome studies in the fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster), which like humans, develops T2D when fed a high-sugar diet. Our studies in the fly will identify genes that normally prevent T2D upon chronic sugar consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain bleeding from aneurysm rupture is a life-threatening occurrence in 30,000 people annually in the US, and while a third have good outcome, another third survives with disability. Delayed strokes related to the bleed are a common leading cause of this disability that occurs while patients are hospitalized, but the onset can be subtle and found only in retrospect. We aim to turn an artificial intelligence model that accurately assesses risk of this secondary brain injury into a monitor, capable of implementation in any intensive care unit to maximize opportunities to intervene and improve disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The disproportionate rise in nursing home use among Black and Latino persons living with dementia (PLWD) reflects the inadequacy of existing programs and policies to support aging in place for these most at-risk populations. The goals of this study are to 1) identify the unmet needs that drive Black and Latino PLWD to experience potentially avoidable NH placements at greater rates than their White counterparts using an exploratory sequential mixed methods research design and 2) translate preliminary findings onto the public agenda as a policy issue. This work will inform intervention and policy development aimed at filling gaps in needs significant to Black and Latino PLWD’s ability to remain in the community for their long-term care as long as possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) is associated with deficits in cognitive control, including deficits in behavioral flexibility that contribute to goal-directed decision-making. These deficits contribute to poor daily function and are thought to underlie the lack of behavioral control observed in inflexible and compulsive alcohol use and relapse. Identifying how AUD alters cortical function is a critical step towards restoring cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: A major challenge of genomic medicine is to convert the large catalogue of disease- associated variants and gene expression states into actionable therapeutic targets. The proposed aims will build the foundational knowledge base and tools for controlling gene expression in human cells by delivering synthetic constructs that trigger epigenetic memory of gene expression states. These aims will pave the way for future epigenetic therapeutic strategies that open large portions of the human genome to direct therapeutic targeting with high precision for disease pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyloids are fibrous protein assemblies that play a critical role in the progression of numerous severe human diseases including Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis. My research goals are to delineate the physiological pathways and mechanisms that healthy cells have evolved to regulate formation, function, and reversibility of amyloids. Knowledge gained from these studies will lead to important advances in our understanding of the causes of neurodegenerative diseases and will eventually lead to therapeutic opportunities.

PHR: NARRATIVE Aging and aging-related vascular diseases are associated with decreased cellular functions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anemia and dysregulated iron homeostasis is a common complication of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, the regulation and impact of intestinal iron homeostasis in IBD is unknown. The focus of this proposal is to better understand how intestinal iron is regulated in intestinal inflammation, and whether modulating iron homeostasis might be therapeutic in IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Medicare is the primary health insurance for older adults (65+) living in the U.S., and eligible beneficiaries must choose between two different plan types: traditional Medicare and Medicare Advantage. The number of socioeconomically disadvantaged Black and Hispanic Medicare beneficiaries with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) is growing, and they experience less preventive care and more adverse health events than their White counterparts. The proposed mixed methods study will examine racial/ethnic health disparities within and between the two Medicare plan options and explore the challenges of health plan decision-making among beneficiaries with ADRD to inform policies promoting more equitable health care and facilitating better health plan decision-making for socioeconomically disadvantaged Black and Hispanic Medicare beneficiaries with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Plastin family of the actin cytoskeleton organizers contributes to the activation of immune cells, bone formation, cell division, migration, and adhesion as well as to shaping biological membranes essential for the absorbance of nutrients by the intestine, blood dialysis by kidneys, and audial perception by the inner ear. When disrupted or expressed ectopically, plastins contribute to the metastatic activity of cancer cells, autoimmune processes, congenital osteoporosis, syndrome of diaphragmatic hernia, and deafness. Our investigation will reveal fundamental molecular mechanisms underlying the activity of human plastins and will generate a strong and lasting impact on the fundamental understanding of the actin cytoskeleton leading to potential therapeutic interventions for cancers, familial osteoporosis, and autoimmune disorders.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will benefit NIH and have a direct impact on human health by improving our fundamental understanding of enzymes as biophysical machines. Better knowledge of long-range effects in protein structure and factors that enable high catalytic efficiency of enzymes will enable new approaches for making new and safer drugs as well as use of enzymes as biotherapeutics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Narrative The overall goal of parent Lung Health Cohort (LHC) Study is to establish a US community-based longitudinal cohort of young adults to better understand the earliest indicators of lung disease, thus providing important public health insights. The purpose of this ancillary study is to provide detailed or sensitive lung function measures to the funded LHC study. The mechanistic hypothesis is that some persons have a mismatch of airways and blood vessels both in terms of structure and function, and this mismatch will be a marker of early and incident lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The metastatic spread of cancer cells relies on the ability of these cells to invade into tissue surrounding the tumor. Cancer cells use specialized structures called filopodia to move through tissues and spread throughout the body. The work in this proposal will define how cells make filopodia using a simple model system and will thus aid in the development of therapeutics to block their formation.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: IgE-mediated food allergy is a growing public health concern. Allergen-specific IgE is largely responsible for the clinical manifestations of allergic reactions, such as life-threatening anaphylaxis. The affinity of the IgE plays a major role in determining the outcome of a patient after exposure to food allergen. IgE that is of high affinity can trigger anaphylaxis, while IgE of low affinity poses little risk and may even be preventative. It is well understood that IgG memory B cells can differentiate into IgE producing plasma cells; however, not enough is known on the distinct pathways involved to form high affinity, rather than low affinity IgE, have not been described. This proposal seeks to understand the intrinsic characteristics and/or external cues that regulate memory B cell differentiation into IgE plasma cells. We expect that outcomes of this work will identify immunotherapeutic approaches for the treatment of food allergy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Callous-unemotional traits, which are defined as deficits in empathy, prosociality, and guilt, are highly heritable and can be observed by 3 years of age. This study aims to examine whether the relationship between parent’s CU traits and children’s early-emerging CU traits is mediated by heritable changes in brain connectivity that are present at birth, prior to postnatal environmental exposures. This work may identify brain differences that precede the onset of callous-unemotional traits and are useful targets for earlier and more effective brain-based treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is relevant to public health because many school-age children with type 1 diabetes and their parents experience diabetes distress, which may go under-recognized and undertreated leading to persistent distress and sub-optimal levels of diabetes self-care and glycemic control. Current clinical care guidelines recommend routinely screening children (8 years and older) and their parents for diabetes distress during diabetes clinic visits. If the aims of this project are achieved, the result will be a new screen-to-treat programfor diabetes distress targeting school-age families that could be realistically deployed in a clinical setting, ready to test in a larger trial, and scalable for widespread implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this project is to carry out a detailed study of a key protein, the sodium/iodide symporter (NIS)—a molecule present most notably in the thyroid gland, where it is responsible for the critical first step in the production of the thyroid hormones. One of our research groups was the first to clone and characterize NIS, and our two groups have since collaborated to uncover the characteristics of the molecule and understand them in detail—characteristics including how it handles the molecules it transports (e.g., sodium and iodide) and other molecules that modify its mechanism of action, such as the environmental pollutant perchlorate. In this project, our two groups will continue to use a highly innovative approach that combines biochemical experiments with computational analysis to obtain structure/function and mechanistic information on NIS that will, without a doubt, considerably deepen our understanding of this crucial protein and of other proteins that transport ions and/or molecules across biological membranes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Significant sex differences exist in glioblastoma incidence and survival have been repeatedly documented. However, the implications of these observations, and other observations like them in other cancers, have yet to be routinely incorporated into laboratory-based cancer research and the implications for cancer treatments have not been evaluated. Here, we investigate sex differences in cellular responses to DNA damage. This innovative focus will yield novel insights and support new directions in lab-based and clinical research aimed at curing glioblastoma. !

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Walking is important for maintaining independence and is highly valued by older adults. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Corticosteroids are among the most prescribed drugs in the world, important for the treatment of numerous forms of heart failure and chronic inflammation. This work will dissect mechanisms of corticosteroids in the etiology and treatment of dystrophic cardiomyopathy, using steroid receptor mutations as well as mouse models of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy. By identifying corticosteroid mechanisms that can be selectively targeted, we will provide a basis for improved muscular dystrophy treatments and enable drug development in other diseases with cardiomyopathy or chronic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intestinal epithelium is a critical interface between our body and the environment of our intestinal lumen, coordinating intestinal immune responses and shaping our gut microbial composition. However, how intestinal cells recognize beneficial gut bacteria, and which intestinal cell responses promote their selection within the gut remains poorly understood. This project addresses fundamental questions to improve our understanding of how intestinal innate immunity influences and is influenced by gut bacteria using the model organism C. elegans, providing the fine-sale spatial resolution needed to dissect the intricacies of host-microbe interactions in the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Psychiatric disorders are highly prevalent following kidney transplantation (KT) and significantly reduce survival and quality of life of kidney transplant recipients; however, to date, most studies of risk factors for psychiatric disorders have been small or restricted to retrospective data collection after KT. The overarching aim of this proposal is to systematically investigate genomic, clinical, and psychosocial contributors to MDD and PSTD following KT to improve our ability to understand and mitigate risk of psychiatric disorders for KT recipients. Kidney disease disproportionately impacts traditional US minorities, and most KT recipients are not of European ancestry, so this proposal will build on innovative efforts to apply genomic data to patients with non-European ancestry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections are common bacterial infections in women, but also affect male populations, in some cases with worse outcomes. Infections of the kidney can result in renal scars, which carry risk for chronic kidney disease later in life. In this work, we will use traditional and cutting-edge scientific approaches to reveal how sex and sex hormones affect susceptibility to, and outcomes of, kidney infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: IMPACT OF IMMUNE SEX DIFFERENCES IN THE FIRST 1000 DAYS OF LIFE  AND IN CHILDHOOD AND ADOLESCENCE PROJECT NARRATIVE We believe the reason that sex-specific prevention and treatment strategies have not been developed, even in this age of precision medicine, is that the underlying mechanisms have not been established. In this project we seek to demonstrate that immune sex differences are present in early life, starting in utero, and that these have considerable impact on the protective responses to vaccines, such as BCG, measles vaccine and COVID-19 vaccines, and to outcome from infections such as HIV. Through investigations of sex-discordant twins, mother-child and adolescent cohorts, we will analyse innate and adaptive immunity, DNA methylation and sex steroid profiles to address the fundamental mechanisms underlying early life immune sex differences, that form the basis for lifelong outcomes in response to vaccines and infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall Section  This proposal focuses on elucidating the genomic and microenvironmental determinants, and temporal dynamics underlying efficacy of radiation-based combination therapies. We will use an innovative molecular characterization trial testing radiation plus antibody-drug conjugate in bladder cancer and radiation plus immunotherapy in head and neck cancer to characterize the mechanistic drivers underlying these next generation RT-based therapies. Our studies will help build a foundation to optimize multimodal, radiation- based definitive treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the need for robust gene-editing delivery systems to T cells in situ, we propose to engineer an unprecedented “Ad.AAV” nano-vector system consisting of multiple T cell-tropic adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) conjugated to a T cell-tropic adenovirus (Ad) on its capsid's surface. By virtue of combining the advantages of each virus in this conjoined form, our system holds the promise of greatly enhancing the tissue targeting specificity and efficiency and improving safety profile of existing CRISPR-Cas gene editing therapies. As a proof of concept, we plan to achieve efficient production of the heart disease-targeted CAR-T cells via the Ad.AAV-mediated knock-in of a switchable CAR transgene in the T cells in vivo in mice.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Scientists encounter numerous limitations of studying the human placenta using animal models or cell/tissue cultures from samples obtained from term delivery, which has reduced our understanding of placental functions in normal pregnancy as well as in placental disease-associated adverse pregnancy outcomes (APOs). To overcome these limitations and to better study placental functions, we will develop both normal and disease- state Placenta-Maternal interface organ-on-chip (PMi-OOC) models representing the distinctly different three trimesters of pregnancy. Using these in-vivo-like in vitro models, we will recreate oxidative stress and inflammation-associated placental pathologies that compromise PMi homeostasis, leading to APOs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is to explore the usage of focused ultrasound for ejecting cells from their monolayer on a solid platform, without damage on the ejected cells or the cells remaining in the monolayer. An array of focused ultrasonic transducers will be developed and used to eject living cells, without damage, from their monolayer into nearby microwells for single-cell RNA sequencing for quality control in production of retinal pigment epithelium cell monolayer on a scaffold for treatment of age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is a leading cause of illness and death for children under five years of age globally, with most of these deaths resulting from infection by the Plasmodium falciparum parasite. The process of cell division in the parasite is different from human cells, and the goal of this application is to understand how an essential multi-protein contractile ring, known as the basal complex, controls parasite cell division. Through this understanding, we can identify parasite-specific targets for new anti-malarials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A history of chronic heavy alcohol drinking is a risk factor for memory loss and cognitive decline in older individuals. This research explores cellular mechanisms that involve oligodendrocytes, the myelinating glial cells of the central nervous system, which may contribute to the advancement and exacerbation of cognitive dysfunctions associated with alcohol and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The 2024 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Cardiac Regulatory Mechanisms and its integrated Gordon Research Seminar (GRS), organized by and for early career scientists, are the premier conferences centered on the physiological mechanisms that control normal cardiac function and how they are altered by disease. This meeting will emphasize how basic understanding of regulatory mechanisms can be used to develop new treatments in people. The major goal is to discuss and evaluate the latest findings and emerging new technologies that will improve the treatment of heart disease in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Mitochondria play a key role in human health, and loss of mitochondrial function has been associated with aging- related diseases and overall mortality. We will functionally characterize heteroplasmic nonsense mutations identified in the mitochondrial genome that are associated with increased risk for all-cause mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy is a chronic condition affecting 70 million people worldwide. Development of novel therapeutic strategies to better treat and potentially prevent and cure this devastating condition requires scientific advances to increase our understanding of the multifaceted mechanisms responsible for epilepsy. This conference will bring together experts from around the world, as well as scientists in training, in an intensive, immersive environment to present and discuss novel findings, facilitate dissemination of knowledge and create new, cross-disciplinary collaborations that should significantly advance research directed towards better treatment of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) persist in the built and natural environment leading to human exposure and increased risk of metabolic diseases such as diabetes and obesity. The development of metabolic diseases often begins in adipose tissue, the lipid-rich depot also responsible for PCB accumulation. This project will uncover the systems-level mechanisms by which PCBs contribute to adipose dysfunction and inflammation through the disruption of cellular crosstalk between adipocytes and macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There is a critical need to develop non-antibiotic modalities to tackle multidrug-resistant bacteria. This proposal aims to explore a novel bacteria-specific pro-photosensitizer, which can sufficiently kill multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacteria when combined with light. The success of the study will provide a much-needed non-antibiotic approach to the battle against infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2018, Massachusetts’ Medicaid program, MassHealth, launched a new Accountable Care Organization (ACO) delivery and payment system to better deliver integrated person-centered care that meets members’ social, behavioral, and physical health needs.9 Prior studies have shown that healthcare integration may improve care quality, reduce healthcare costs, and increase patient satisfaction; however, there is limited published research on clinical, behavioral health, and social service integration in primary care practices for Medicaid members with behavioral health conditions.10-12 In this one-year, mixed-methods study, we will analyze the impact of clinical and social services integration on healthcare utilization and experiences of MassHealth members with behavioral health conditions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Care Integration, Supportive Housing, and Outcomes for Medicaid Accountable Care Organization Enrollees with Behavioral Health Conditions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Overall The UAB CFAR catalyzes new and supports ongoing HIV research across all domains – in partnership with communities most affected by HIV. Through our structure, relationships with community, public health, and academic partners, and institutional support, we are positioned to support high-impact discoveries towards the achievement of HIV research priorities and curbing the HIV epidemic in Alabama, the Deep South, and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High dietary salt intake is a well-established risk factor for high blood pressure, cardiovascular disease (CVD) and chronic kidney disease (CKD), yet ~90% of Americans consume excess dietary salt based on the recommendations set by the Dietary Guidelines for Americans and the American Heart Association. The established link between dietary salt with CVD and CKD, particularly in older adults, highlights a critical biomedical research need for strategies to counteract the adverse cardiorenal consequences of high dietary salt; and we have identified beta-hydroxybutyrate, a liver-derived ketone body, as a potential target to counteract the adverse cardiorenal effects high dietary salt. Using a randomized placebo-controlled crossover design study, we will test the hypothesis that concurrently giving a ketone monoester supplement (exogenous source of beta- hydroxybutyrate) with high dietary salt (10 days) will attenuate the effects of short-term high dietary salt on cardiorenal health (blood pressure, peripheral vascular function, kidney injury biomarkers, and kidney blood flow) in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The field of synaptic biology is relevant to nearly every question in neurobiology, from development to aging and from sensory processing to sleep and cognition. Synapses are also the primary site of neuronal degeneration and dysfunction in diseases and disorders ranging from Alzheimer’s to Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ASL), epilepsy, intellectual disability, autism, and schizophrenia. The 2024 Synaptic Transmission Gordon Conference will bring together international leaders and rising stars, creating a diverse, inclusive, dynamic forum to communicate, contemplate and advance our understanding of the most pressing and fascinating current topics in synapse biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall PROJECT NARRATIVE The CFAR’s mission is to advance cutting-edge HIV/AIDS research on the Penn/CHOP/Wistar campus that will contribute innovative solutions to the AIDS crisis. The CFAR achieves this mission by providing scientific and administrative leadership to generate new research directions and collaborations; providing shared resource cores that support research through critical enabling technologies; leveraging institutional resources; training and mentoring the next generation of researchers and leaders and attracting scientists from other fields; and establishing partnerships and generating synergy with other groups on campus, in Philadelphia, nationally and internationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate the role of the understudied gene, CACNA2D4, in the context of inherited retinal disease. CACNA2D4 encodes for a2d-4, which is a subunit of the voltage-gated Cav family of ion channels. Our research is expected to illuminate new mechanisms controlling the processing of visual information in normal and diseased states of the retina, and pave the way for the development of novel therapeutic approaches to treat inherited retinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The biological determinants of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are established decades before clinical symptoms of cognitive decline, memory loss and functional decline are observed. As age is the most reliable predictor of ADRD, the proposed study will test whether biological age, as opposed to chronological age, predicts higher levels of preclinical AD biomarkers, as measured with a highly reliable plasma beta-amyloid (Aβ) marker, and whether Aβ accumulation contributes to cognitive decline in midlife in a well-established longitudinal twin sample, the Louisville Twin Study. The nature of this twin design will inform causal pathways between early life development, biological age, Aβ, and cognitive functioning at midlife, shedding light on genetic and environmental mechanisms that promote risk and resilience of preclinical AD.

PROJECT_TITLE: Contribution of child development, biological aging, and beta-amyloid to cognitive function of the Louisville twins at midlife

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lipoproteins are essential particles that transport fats to different cells in the brain. In individuals with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), lipoproteins are not taken up by cells properly and instead bind to other factors outside the cell such as amyloid, leading to amyloid plaque formation, and damage to brain tissue and function. In this proposal, we aim to enhance the activity of the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL), which can help specialized cells called microglia remove excess lipoproteins, prevent amyloid accumulation, and protect against the development of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative While memory deficits are common among older adults, some individuals remain resilient to cognitive decline. Understanding the functional and neurochemical factors that influence cognitive resilience is key to advancing the field of cognitive aging towards better treatments and care for older adults facing cognitive decline. In this proposal we will use a multimodal neuroimaging approach to study the effects of dopamine, tau, and age on memory ability in the face of Alzheimer’s-related pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to create an entirely new hybrid viral vector delivery vehicle for CRISPR gene therapy which will be able to efficiently insert multiple genes into specified locations within the genomes of target cells. In the long term, this platform technology will enable genetic treatments for complex ailments of aging and aging-related conditions, especially Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The dysregulation of Hox gene expression patterning leads to body part transformations and is associated with tumor progression, thus, precise understanding of Hox gene regulation will enhance our understanding and potential engineering of normal development and disease. However, the current model for Hox gene regulation has only been investigated in piece-meal using tedious low throughput techniques allowing for only a few modifications at a time due to limitations in DNA synthesis and delivery technologies. The proposed research seeks to utilize a novel synthetic DNA engineering approach to ectopically insert an entire HoxA cluster (~130kb) to study its internal regulatory elements and understand how Hox genes decode transient patterning signals into epigenetic information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research studies aim to identify the pharmacokinetic interactions between a ketone supplement and alcohol in blood and brain of healthy, socially drinking adults. The proposed studies will generate fundamental knowledge on the potentially beneficial effects of a nutritional ketone supplement in decreasing alcohol sensitivity and increasing alcohol tolerance in human participants. Ketone supplements may lead to the identification of new approaches for alcohol clearance during intoxication, and/or the development of novel therapeutics for alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In chronically infected individuals, the latent HIV reservoir is not silent and may induce inflammation, but the pathways leading to this aberrant inflammation are poorly understood, particularly in pediatric populations who acquired HIV perinatally. The project will elucidate these pathways in perinatally-infected adolescents and mechanistically define drivers using organoid models as a step towards novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Improving the timeliness and quality of care of rural underserved lung cancer (LC) and head and neck cancer (HNC) patients is important because delays treatment are associated with disparities in disease recurrence, lower survival and poor patient outcomes compared to patients who are not underserved. We will evaluate an intervention that targets key factors associated with treatment delays and poor quality of care. Our objective is to disseminate an evidence-based intervention into clinical practice to effectively improve the timeliness and quality of care for rural underserved patients and reduce disparities in LC and HNC morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder (OUD) ruins the lives of those with the disorder and those around them, while also placing higher healthcare and economic burden on the United States. Here we will use drug self-administration and light sheet microscopy to identify the impact of high vs. low fentanyl seeking on brain in male and female rats and we will test the ‘need-state’ hypothesis by determining whether treatment with a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP-1RA) not only rescues vulnerable rats from fentanyl seeking but also reengages the GLP-1 ‘satiety’ pathway and disengages substrates involved in reward and seeking.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Veterans with dysvascular lower limb amputation (LLA) have a high fall risk, which persists despite completion of conventional rehabilitation. The presence of fall risk could be a primary reason for the high disability and low quality of life outcomes in this Veteran population. A potential novel intervention for this population is to train performance of tasks that require both physical and cognitive attention (i.e, dual-tasking). Therefore, the purpose of this study is to explore relationships between dual-task performance and self-reported falls for Veterans with dysvascular LLA. Further, dual-tasking occurs during everyday life and this project will examine the associations between dual-task performance and participation in activities of daily living (basic and instrumental). The results will form the foundation for development and future study of a novel dual-task training program for Veterans with dysvascular LLA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Maternal immune activation (MIA) is a primer for long-term neuropsychiatric consequences in offspring, although the exact mechanisms underlying offspring neurodevelopmental defects resulting from these maternal immune insults are unknown. Here, we provide evidence that MIA-induced changes in the developing offspring’s extracellular chondroitin and dermatan sulfate glycosaminoglycan (CS/DS-GAG) sulfation patterning, which are key regulator of axonal guidance and synaptogenesis during neurodevelopment, may result in developmental defects that predispose the offspring to mental health disorders in the adult, and studies outlined within this proposal aim to further investigate this possibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a national shortage of qualified clinician-scientists able to conduct the rigorous clinical research needed to address cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases. This training program proposes to continue to address this shortage through the efforts of a distinguished, experienced, and committed training program faculty. Training will continue to be provided to those who desire careers as clinician-scientists focusing on cardiology and pulmonary clinical research through a program that provides trainees with the skills needed to design, conduct, and complete epidemiologic studies that will address the most vexing population-based questions in cardiovascular and pulmonary medicine.

PROJECT_TITLE: Cardiology and Pulmonary Clinical Research Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(OA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic interactions govern the emergence of phenotype from genotype at every level, but our capacity to probe and decipher these interactions is severely limited. We will continue our hybrid computational and experimental effort to decipher the modular hierarchy of the mammalian cell, how interactions govern the relationships between modules, and how rewiring these relationships gives rise to disease states. Our development of next-generation multiplex CRISPR tools will extend the current state of the art and enable researchers worldwide to gain deeper insight into the complexity of the mammalian cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 14-3-3θ phosphorylation at S232 is markedly elevated within insoluble fractions of human brains with synucleinopathy, including Parkinson’s Disease (PD) and Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB). We will examine the effect of 14-3-3θ phosphorylation in the pathophysiology of these disorders. Blockade of 14-3-3θ phosphorylation may serve as a potential therapeutic to reduce alpha-synuclein aggregation, neuroinflammation, and neurodegeneration in synucleinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Giant congenital melanocytic nevi are very large birthmarks which produce increased probability of malignant melanoma formation, and therefore are commonly surgically removed in childhood, leaving major permanent morbidity over much of the body surface. In the current funding period, we generated four mouse models which allowed us to identify drug treatments that kill the nevus cells, including one that also displayed protection against melanoma. We propose studies to build on this progress, aiming to obtain treatment for this devastating childhood condition that can avoid a need for highly morbid permanently debilitating surgeries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adjuvants incorporated into vaccine formulations have a major impact on vaccine efficacy via modulating and prolonging host immune responses. One-fourth of the world’s population is latently infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB), a leading infectious disease killer in the world. In the current proposal, we will develop the use of new adjuvants that drive Th1 responses and Th17 responses along with optimal Mtb antigens to significantly augment vaccine-induced protection against TB. The work proposed in this grant will thus result in a novel, first-of-kind rationally designed Th1 and/or Th17-inducing TB vaccine for use in humans in the near future.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Rotator cuff tears are increasingly common in the aging population. Patients with a nonfunctional rotator cuff are difficult to elevate the arm to perform activities of daily living. With the aging of our veteran population, rotator cuff tears are becoming a more and more important health issue for the VA patients. The development of muscle fibrosis and fatty infiltration (FI) are critical factors that determine the clinical outcome of patients with this injury. However, there is no effective treatment for this disease at this time due to our limited understanding of the mechanisms. Successful achievement of this project will define how clinically relevant factors such as aging and tear size affect stem cell changes within the muscle. Results from this study may lead to new therapeutic approaches to treat this disease. Therefore, our proposal has particular significance for the VA population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HIV/AIDS remains a major threat to public health worldwide. Over the past three decades, Harvard faculty and their post-doctoral fellows supported by this training grant have made critical contributions to the progress in combating this epidemic that has come from research aimed at understanding the pathogenesis of HIV infection and its complications. The goal of this training program is to develop the next generation of scientific leaders poised to eliminate HIV/AIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal nutrition plays a vital role in the trajectory of infant brain development, and omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (n-3 PUFA) deficiency during this sensitive period is linked to white matter defects and psychiatric disorders. This proposal seeks to understand whether low n-3 PUFA status culminates in the dysregulation of myelin, the axon insulator within white matter. These experiments will provide insight into a cellular mechanism by which n-3 PUFAs may contribute to cognitive function and reveal nutritional strategies for the prevention of neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the leading cause of death worldwide, and from leveraging the power of human genetics and mechanistic discovery, we are poised to understand causal mechanisms of disease and design crucially needed therapies. In a groundbreaking discovery through complex disease genetics, RNA editing of double stranded RNA, mediated by ADAR1, has been found to powerfully influence CAD risk. In this proposal, I aim to understand the fundamental mechanisms of RNA editing and atherosclerosis, and further define the potential for targeting the dsRNA sensor MDA5 for clinical therapy — allowing me to advance my training and become an independent physician-scientist in cardiovascular medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project uses both transcriptomic- and genomic-level data to identify mechanisms of individual responses to glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) in Mexican-Americans with prediabetes. The GLP-1 hormone is essential for glucose reduction, weight loss, cardiovascular risk reduction, and renal protection. Newly discovered mechanisms will illuminate causal links between disease genotype and phenotype, which may ultimately guide personalized therapeutic approaches for type 2 diabetes, prediabetes, obesity, cardiovascular disease, renal disease, and other related diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Aortic aneurysm, a swelling of the aorta, can rupture or the layers of its wall can tear apart, namely dissect, and as such, aortic aneurysm is the 15th leading cause of death in people over age 55. Though surgery is currently performed when aneurysms of the ascending thoracic aorta reach specified size limits, unfortunately, rupture/dissection still occur in significant numbers of patients below those size guidelines with no means to predict which patients are at greater risk at this time. This proposal will investigate the role of mechanical loading on aortic aneurysm wall on the dilation and dissection of aneurysm wall among patients whose aneurysm size is below the current surgical size threshold.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The innate immune system can impact all aspects of cancer, from tumor initiation to growth and metastasis. This research program will build on our earlier seminal discoveries related to innate immune sensors and their role in colitis-associated colorectal cancer. We will improve understanding of the role of innate immune sensors, inflammasomes, and inflammasome-mediated processes in cancer to shape future cancer treatment strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 700,00 patients in the United States live with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a genetic heart disease. This knowledge is critical to developing personalized treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative These studies will define the role and heterogeneity of neoantigens and tumor microenvironmental immune cells in SCLC; a poorly characterized disease, due in part to its aggressiveness and challenges with presentation at a metastatic stage, which prevents tissue collection to address biological questions. Our work will generate a mechanistic rationale for more effective immunotherapies that target the diversity of SCLC, which we will leverage to design ensuing clinical trials at Moffitt Cancer Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project deals with natural killer (NK) cells which are immune cells that can control viral infections in vivo. How they do this requires further examination because they express several candidate activation receptors that have been implicated in viral control by in vitro experiments and they express inhibitory receptors that ironically also mediate viral control in vivo. Here the investigator presents recent published data using novel experimental tools that will be used in the current proposal to study how NK cells use these receptors to control viral infections in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Self-care is an evidence-based strategy that can reduce the high morbidity and mortality associated with heart failure. However, little is known about how to implement self-care for heart failure in low- and middle-income country settings in ways that account for the unique needs of different cultures and contexts. Our study, which is designed to prioritize health equity throughout all phases, will compare the implementation, effectiveness, and cost effectiveness of a digital-first implementation strategy vs. a basic evidence-based package and current standard of care to improve self-care in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Our research program uses chemical technologies and systems-level analyses to study ontogeny and oncogenesis. Our current studies focus on optogenetic regulators of developmental signaling pathways and small-molecule inhibitors of aldehyde dehydrogenases associated with stemness, cancer, and spermatogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cerebral Autosomal-Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is a familial vascular dementia characterized by vascular failure due to degeneration of smooth muscle cells. While the cause of the disease has been attributed to mutations in NOTCH3, little is known about the cellular outcomes, vascular dysfunctions, and clinical progression. Through this application an interdisciplinary group of physicians and scientists will translate new information on the disease to improve diagnosis, prognosis and continue to explore the molecular basis of disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The cell has an intricate set of pathways that sense and repair DNA damage, which is an inevitable consequence of cellular metabolism and the environment. Failure of a repair pathway, due to either overwhelming DNA damage or pathway inactivation by mutations, can lead to the propagation of genetic errors and drive the development of cancer. This proposal seeks to determine the 3-dimensional structures of protein assemblies involved in key repair pathways to better understand how they work and how they fail in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the research proposed in this fellowship is to determine the functional heterogeneity of neurons in the paralaminar nucleus (PL), an understudied region of the amygdala implicated in neuropsychiatric disorders. The experiments will use a mouse model to classify the diversity of mature PL neurons by linking their physiological properties, morphological features, and input/output circuitry. The results will provide crucial knowledge for understanding the role of the paralaminar nucleus in amygdala function and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although decades of research have identified genetic master regulator (MR) genes that are essential for the regenerative function of stem cells, the downstream mechanisms that they regulate remain largely unknown. This project seeks to characterize the function of a small set of validated MR targets in the regulation of intestinal stem cells, using the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster as an experimental model system. The research proposed is dually relevant to the NIH mission, for it will contribute to our basic understanding of how stem cells can be used safely and effectively in regenerative medicine, while specifically expanding the repertoire of therapeutic targets for the treatment of gastrointestinal disease.
