IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Simultaneous profiling of the transcriptomic and epigenomic readouts along the one-dimensional (1D) genome and high-throughput three-dimensional (3D) chromatin conformation assays have both advanced to single-cell resolution. This project will propose statistical and machine learning-based models with accompanying software for jointly modeling 3D chromatin structure, transcriptomics, and epigenomics data while deciphering the distal gene regulatory networks in an individual cell. These studies will enhance our understanding of the function of non-coding regions as regulators of cell fate and infer how the cis-regulatory changes lead to different cell types during development and impact immunotherapeutic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity is now among the leading causes of medical morbidity and health care costs in the U.S. The regulation of body weight - and the impact of excess weight on clinical phenotypes such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease and cancer - is extremely complex necessitating special training in centers with broad basic and translational research portfolios for the scientists who will help to break this nexus of disease. The objective of this longstanding training program is to increase the young investigator pool working on the biology of obesity and its co-morbidities through academic course work and sophisticated research experiences, enabling them to become independent investigators who can assume leadership positions in this field. This program has important national implications by virtue of its provision of a critical group of bioscientists.

PROJECT_TITLE: Obesity Research Center Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cells are a part of the immune system able to control tumor growth, but are ineffective in most cancer patients. Our lab has made the groundbreaking discovery that T cells entering tumors experience chronic stress that can exhaust T cell function in tumors. Our proposal will formally prove that targeting the chronic stress response holds the power to restore essential T cell functions and invigorate control of tumors to allow immunotherapy to work better in sarcomas with global implications for all cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: The biogenesis of mRNA is a complex and highly regulated process, requiring coordination between transcrip- tional and RNA processing machinery that each comprise of hundreds of regulatory RNAs and proteins, resulting in many possible alternative isoforms expressed from a single gene. While we can now extensively catalog the abundance and variability of mRNA isoforms across cellular states, we are still limited in our abilities to predict coordination between the molecular steps that give rise to cellular diversity and the rates at which each of these mechanisms occurs. Here, we propose to generate checkpointed time-series RNA-sequencing data and robust statistical models to quantify RNA processing rates, fully characterize the kinetic competition underlying alterna- tive isoform expression, and identify genetic variants associated with variabilty in RNA processing rates across human cell lines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Breakthrough animal experimental evidence and preliminary human data suggest that high fat-dietary intake may disrupt circadian organization and that circadian disruption increases the risk for obesity. This project will determine whether a high-fat diet, vs. a low-fat diet, will alter the circadian system and thereby circadian rhythms in energy intake and expenditure in humans. This research will provide novel mechanistic insights into the link between macronutrient intake and the circadian system, and may help in the design of evidence-based dietary intervention incorporating “timing” to combat the obesity epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In recent years, rapid increases in the prevalence of opioid use disorder have uncovered sex differences in opioid use, such as a predisposition to opioid use in females that can negatively impact treatment outcomes. This is particularly concerning, as females have often been excluded from research studies on reward processing and addiction. This proposal aims to address this research gap by describing the mechanisms by which estrogen impacts heroin seeking, knowledge that could help tailor sex-specific interventions for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The circadian clock in mammals coordinates many aspects of normal physiology and behavior and when these clocks are disrupted, many health problems, including several types of mental illness, cancer and metabolic problems can occur. This project will investigate how the molecular mechanism of the clock works to keep proper time and drive rhythms in cellular function. This information will be critical for future manipulation of the circadian timing system as a treatment modality for humans suffering from circadian-related health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) can cause widespread alteration in brain structure and function, but sample size in imaging studies is often limited, and differences in data acquisition and variables can create obstacles to data sharing. We propose to develop an open-source workflow for utilizing behavioral and MRI data that addresses these concerns and allows for harmonization across sites, supporting “big data” analyses that can identify clinically-meaningful patient subgroups in TBI, a goal that is not feasible with small datasets. Achieving the proposed Aims will make a curated and harmonized dataset available to the TBI community as well as procedures and data processing pipelines adaptable to other disorders in the clinical neurosciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kombucha, a fermented tea that contains probiotic microbes, has seen a surge in popularity in the United States since the turn of the century. Kombucha is purported to have many health benefits, however, none have been rigorously tested and the molecular relationship between the microbial components of Kombucha and the consumer remains unexplored. The impact of individual probiotic microbes on human health is difficult to deconvolute, therefore, I will use C. elegans as a model to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which Kombucha-associated microbes may promote health and longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Evasion of apoptosis is a hallmark of cancer development, maintenance and chemoresistance. Pro-apoptotic BAX functions as gateway to apoptosis induction and our previous work has highlighted direct BAX activation as a promising therapeutic strategy. The goal of this proposal is to investigate small-molecule BAX activators in different type of tumors and investigate novel mechanisms and biomarkers that will facilitate the application of BAX activators to cancer patients.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Cryptococcal meningitis (CM), a fungal infection around the brain, causes 15-20% of AIDS-related deaths in Africa and is the most common cause of neurologic infection in Africa. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lactate is a newly identified substrate of cancer cells, yet its regulatory mechanism is not fully understood. The overall goal of this proposal is to understand a previously unappreciated mechanisms by focusing on BACH1 involved in lactate catabolism of triple negative breast tumors. Our research team will identify whether blockade of BACH1 promotes shift of cancer cell populations toward lactate catabolic pathways, making cancer cells more sensitive to the therapy targeting lactate metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A plant virus-based therapeutic is proposed for treatment and relapse prevention of ovarian cancer. This pro- posal is based on our data demonstrating that the plant virus-based therapeutic stimulates potent anti-tumor responses, suppresses metastatic development and recurrence. We will develop a 3D printed biopolymer im- plant containing the plant virus and irradiated cancer cells to prime tumor specific immunity post-surgery to pro- tect women from relapse and therefore increase survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women constitute 18% of new HIV infections in 2020, and 71% of these were among Black/African American and Hispanic women and yet only 7.4% of PrEP users are women. To understand PrEP equity for women overall, it is essential to evaluate better methods to identify women with PrEP indications, to stratify them by race and ethnicity, and to determine how characteristics of women with PrEP indications vary geographically. We propose to conduct analyses on existing datasets to 1) to better understand the characteristics of women with indications for PrEP, particularly those indications unrecognized by women and their healthcare providers, and re-estimate the number of heterosexual women with PrEP indications, 2) to determine the current racial/ethnic distribution of women PrEP users including creating imputation models for missing data, and 3) to determine spatio-temporal patterns of PrEP uptake among women in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary objective of this study is to identify degrees of change in patient reported outcome measures that matter for guiding changes in clinical management of cardiac conditions. We are evaluating changes in patient reported outcome measures for patients with heart failure and coronary heart disease that are associated with improvements in their condition. The results of this study will build evidence for clinically meaningful changes in patient outcome measures and will include a framework to integrate patient reported outcome information into shared decision making and communication between healthcare professionals and patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 80% of children suffer at least one bout of impaired hearing during a time when the brain is especially vulnerable to deprivation, often causing lasting deficits in speech comprehension which are correlated with impaired perception of changes in the spectral content of sounds. This proposal seeks to 1) establish an animal model to assess perception of spectral modulation, 2) assess the impact of developmental hearing loss on perception and neural coding of spectral modulation and 3) test a novel gene therapy approach to rescue these deficits. This work will address an important lack of understanding of behavioral deficits following hearing loss and help direct future research towards therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE The transition from hospital to a skilled nursing facility is a vulnerable point in the continuum of care, and medication-related errors during transitions are a major driver of avoidable harm and healthcare utilization. Using a cluster-randomized design with a network of four hospitals and 16 skilled nursing facilities, we will compare clinical outcomes of integrating pharmacists into the care transition process, targeting key gaps that contribute to medication errors, and evaluate its impact on medication-related problems and patient and caregiver-reported measures of transition quality.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing Medication-Related Problems in Care Transitions to Skilled Nursing Facilities

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Home dialysis is a preferred treatment for end-stage renal disease but is substantially underutilized, particularly among socially disadvantaged populations. This project leverages a national, randomized alternative payment model that incentivizes home dialysis to identify the structures and processes of care that are associated with higher home dialysis uptake. It also evaluates whether the alternative payment model led to reductions in socioeconomic and racial/ethnic disparities in home dialysis uptake.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Impact of the ESRD Treatment Choices Model on Home Dialysis Uptake and Disparities

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) are one of the most important medical problems of our time. The University of Washington Alzheimer's Disease Research Center is dedicated to understanding the different disease processes underlying dementia and resistance to dementia. It supports a wide variety of research studies of ADRD from the perspectives of genetics, cognition, imaging, and neuropathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The primary focus of my work has been to understand the mechanisms by which cancers subvert normal developmental and stem cell signals to grow, spread and evade therapy. Over the last decade our work has ranged from discovery of new signals involved in cancer growth and progression to preclinical work that has formed the basis of clinical trials testing new agents for drug-resistant leukemias – leading to the recent approval of Glasdegib to treat aggressive leukemia – and pancreatic cancer. In the coming years, we will continue to strive to make important contributions that will have a meaningful impact on the many lives that deeply depend on the discoveries we make as a community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) chronically infects 4% of the global population and up to 30% of people living with HIV as current treatments rarely lead to cure. Protein coding HBV RNAs which have been modified by human proteins are associated with treatment resistance and increased disease in a manner similar to HIV co- infection. We will quantify these modified viral RNAs in HIV-HBV co-infection and HBV monoinfection, a current unknown, and search for novel targets for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple myeloma (MM) is a life-threatening plasma cell malignancy that is 2-3 times more common in African Americans, and is preceded by an asymptomatic stage called smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM) amenable to early therapy. We need to determine why MM occurs more frequently in blacks, identify new biomarkers that predict patients with SMM at high risk of progression, and develop a screening strategy to identify SMM in high risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Cobine, Caroline, A Project Narrative The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) provides an important barrier between the stomach and esophagus. Dysfunction of the LES produces either reflux of gastric contents and damage to the LES, or achalasia, the inability to relax the LES after swallowing, thus preventing food from entering the stomach. This project will investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms of contractile tone in the LES with the hope that the new pathways investigated may help suggest novel therapies for medical treatment of gastric reflux or achalasia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional connectivity brain networks are a promising tool for the identification of biomarkers of adolescent psychopathology, yet heterogeneity between and within individuals limits the validity of inferences made from group-averaged, time-invariant networks. This project will examine the level of data aggregation (group, subgroup, or individual) and time scale (static or dynamic) of resting state connectivity networks necessary for valid individual-level inferences and use these findings to predict adolescent anxiety and depression. Findings will be critical to determining methods of estimating functional connectivity networks that are representative of individuals such that inferences made using them have improved potential for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Injury to the spinal cord results in paralysis below the level of the injury, and current therapeutic strategies are ineffective at restoring function. In this proposal, we focus on strategies to attenuate the acute inflammatory response, and then to alter the environment in the chronic spinal cord injury in order to promote regeneration and restoration of function. At the chronic time point, we combine biomaterial bridges with microtubule stabilization to support the regeneration of motor tract through the injury with re-entry to the host tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Afro-Latinas may be disadvantaged in health outcomes due to the intersectionality of multiple minority identities and distinctive stressors of societal disadvantages, such as residential racial segregation, neighborhood deprivation, and prenatal care utilization. This study aims to use Florida Vital Statistics data to determine differences in pregnancy-related hypertension, pregnancy-related diabetes, preterm birth, and low birth weight among Afro-Latinas compared to mothers of other racial/ethnic identities. The findings from this study will provide important data on Afro-Latina-specific perinatal disparities.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative: At the end of the project, we will have enhanced the website and a printout format that the Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients will use to provide information to the public. We will help patients choose transplant centers by using report cards that provide the new metric, survival rate since listing. The enhanced patient centered report card will work towards improving a broad set of patient-centered outcomes, allowing patients to effectively navigate the health system of transplant centers with varying outcomes, creating greater knowledge, satisfaction with the transplant center selection process, improving access to the waiting list and, in the long-run, improving outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: New Patient-centered Metric for Transplant Center Report Cards

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Populations Underrepresented in Mental illness Association Studies (PUMAS) Project will collect samples from 17,000 individuals with severe mental illness from across African and the Americas to create a total sample dataset of 183,000 from across Africa and the Americas. We will generate and analyze whole genome sequencing data on 40,000 schizophrenia patients, 40,000 bipolar patients and 40,000 controls to learn the similarities and differences of the genetic architecture of severe mental illness across diverse ancestries and environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends screening and prophylaxis for opportunistic infections (OIs) for people with advanced HIV disease (CD4<200 cells/µL) who are at high risk for OIs and death. The objective of this study is to evaluate point-of-care CD4 testing to improve survival in people with advanced HIV disease and evaluate an enhanced package of OI screening and prophylaxis to build on current WHO recommendations. The findings from this study will impact international HIV treatment guidelines on optimal management of persons with advanced HIV disease in order to decrease HIV-related mortality globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic heart failure is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the USA, and patients suffering from this disease have limited therapeutic options that include the surgical implantation of ventricular assist devices and heart transplants. Based on preliminary data I collected, I hypothesize that myocardial lactate production and consumption is integral to cardiac health, and quantifying and understanding this metabolism will uncover novel therapeutic targets to treat cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research seeks to determine how diffusion of cardiac technology, specifically percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), may differentially affect disadvantaged versus non-disadvantaged communities, through changing the types of patients that receive PCI and also the quality of care. This study is relevant to public health because it will provide local, state, and federal bodies with the empirical findings they need to better understand how to balance the benefits and costs of PCI across varying communities, ultimately to create data-driven solutions to the provision of cardiac technology that can both improve overall population health and narrow disparities among disadvantaged communities and individuals. This project is directly aligned with one of NHLBI's Enduring Principles to “innovate an evidence-based elimination of health inequities in the United States.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Excluding skin cancers, colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed in the United States. The American Cancer Society's estimates for the number of colorectal cancer cases in the United States for 2022 are: 106,180 new cases of colon cancer. 44,850 new cases of rectal cancer. According to Foundation Medicine (FM) it is estimate that KRAS mutation frequencies of approximately 50% exist in colorectal cancers. KRAS mutations are present in approximately 25% of all tumors, making them one of the most common gene mutations linked to cancer. They are frequent drivers in lung, colorectal and pancreatic cancers. KRAS drives 32% of lung cancers, 40% of colorectal cancers, and 85% to 90% of pancreatic cancer cases. Mutations G12C, G12D/V and G12/13R are some of the most common KRAS mutations but G12D and V dominate colorectal and pancreatic cancers which is the largest and what we are targeting in this proposal. This work involves breakthrough technology which can target hard to treat KRAS mutations such as G12D and G12V where there are no currently approved drugs to treat this deadly disease. It is estimated that for colorectal cancers alone, this research and finding may impact 30-40% of the colorectal cancer population equating up to ~ 60,000 people annually in the USA alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis experience poor health-related quality of life without access to interventions that target improvement in this outcome. The goal of this proposal is to develop and determine the feasibility and acceptability of a stakeholder-engaged behavioral and educational intervention to improve the health-related quality of life of patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Findings from this innovative pilot randomized trial will lay the groundwork for a future, multi-site, randomized trial testing the effectiveness of the intervention developed here.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Harnessing immune pathways to attack a diseased state, or immunotherapy, is a proven and powerful way to treat disease such as cancer. Yet, there are many natural checkpoints in place to prevent an aberrant immune response. Proposed studies are designed to identify and modulate innate immune checkpoints to reveal previously unsuspected ways to exploit innate immune pathways to treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Lipids are molecular components of biological organisms and play a vital role in maintaining cellular functions. Dysregulated lipid metabolism has been recognized in the pathogenesis of a variety of diseases including many cancers, neurodegenerative disorders, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. Thus, lipid analysis technology aimed at elucidation of full lipid composition and complete structures hold great promise for revealing disease mechanisms and providing new opportunities for disease diagnosis and treatments. The proposed research addresses the current deficit of such technologies through the development of a mass spectrometric probe equipped with novel microdroplet electrochemical methods for complete lipid structural analysis in complex biological samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human gut microbiome is intimately connected with health, with disruptions of its ecological composition associated with numerous diseases. Manipulations of the microbiome via fecal microbiome transplants, in which microbial strains derived from healthy donor stool are introduced to a patient's gut community, have been found to be effective treatments for some diseases but not all. This project will determine the evolutionary processes relevant for colonization and persistence of invading strains to a microbiome community, and in doing so will make contributions relevant both to the basic science of microbiome evolutionary dynamics as well as clinical treatment of microbiome–associated diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Hybrid dysfunction presents an unparalleled opportunity to understand how species diverge in key developmental processes, but despite the commonality and importance of hybrid dysfunction as a foundational process in diversification, we lack an understanding of the evolutionary drivers and genetic basis of most hybrid incompatibilities. I aim to dissect the evolutionary drivers and genetic basis of one of the most important, but understudied incidences of hybrid dysfunction in viviparous organisms- embryo inviability caused by inappropriate development of key nutritive tissues- by pairing quantitative and population genomics techniques with gene expression, epigenetics, and functional genetics approaches. This work will greatly enhance our understanding of if and how natural selection has shaped genome divergence between closely related species, and the consequences of this divergence for offspring health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE

PHR: Cannabis components, including non-psychoactive cannabidiol (CBD), ease pain and anxiety in people living with HIV infection and under antiretroviral treatment. In this program, we shall extend our preliminary findings from mice infected with chimeric HIV that CBD increases virus expression that in turn may exacerbate HIV neurocognitive impairment (HIV-NCI). In particular, we shall test the hypothesis that the effects of CBD upon HIV expression arise from its specific suppression of antiviral immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Parasitic protozoa are a major cause of global infectious diseases and thus, represent one of the most serious threats to public health. Among these are African trypanosomes, the causative agents of African trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness in humans and a wasting and fatal disease (Nagana) in cattle, domestic pigs and other farm animals causing a profound effect on the economy of much of the continent. Our proposed studies will provide an insight into control mechanisms of variant surface glycoprotein expression during the developmental program that leads to the establishment of infectious trypanosomes, which has the potential to expose new strategies to combat the diseases caused by these deadly parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic preoperative opioid use is associated with worse surgical outcomes in total knee arthroplasty. Tapering opioids preoperatively holds potential to improve outcomes for these patients, but high-quality evidence of efficacy is lacking, and the best approach to taper opioids in this setting is not known. This application will support an early-career investigator to develop and begin testing a preoperative opioid tapering intervention, which has the long-term potential to improve care in this very common operations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) afflicts 6.5 million US adults and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Reverse remodeling and recovery of cardiac function has been reported in ~15% of patients with advanced HF. Fatty acid metabolism and more specifically sphingolipids play a pivotal role in the pathogenesis of HF. Understanding the factors and mechanisms associating FA metabolism with cardiac recovery could lead to the development of novel personalized therapies to improve outcomes in the greater HF population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: mRNA localization has classically been studied in the context of embryology and neurobiology, but recent genome-wide assays have now determined that mRNA localization is a general feature of cell biology impacting many unexplored aspects of cellular regulation. The proposed project will elucidate novel mechanisms of mRNA localization and determine their impacts on protein production and development. By innovating high-resolution and genome-wide technologies, the project will leverage Caenorhabditis elegans as a robust model system for linking molecular mRNA dynamics to embryogenesis.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research project Transforming Kidney Care in the Emergency Department (ED) using Artificial Intel- ligence Driven Clinical Decision Support is to determine best-practice methods for incorporating artificial intelligence (AI)-derived insights into emergency care delivery. This investigation will use the iterative develop- ment and evaluation of an AI-driven clinical decision support (CDS) system to prevent or mitigate acute kidney injury (AKI) as a reference use-case. The proposed research aims to increase our understanding of human-AI interactions in the emergency care setting through the development and evaluation of a novel AI-driven deci- sion support system for kidney disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Nearly one in four Veterans (1.6 million individuals) receiving care from the Veterans Health Administration has diabetes. The treatment of diabetic complications is integral to Veteran health care. There is growing evidence that the bone is negatively affected by diabetes. People with type 2 diabetes have a higher risk of hip fracture, worse fracture healing, and higher rates of death following fracture. Because of the serious consequences of osteoporosis and fracture, it is critical to understand the mechanisms of diabetic bone disease. Diabetes alters the fat within the bone marrow and may play a role in diabetic bone disease. Understanding how marrow fat affects the bones will provide insight into the mechanisms of diabetic bone disease and could lead to targeted preventive and therapeutic treatments. Further, this research will shape future investigations into diabetic bone disease and osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elevated levels of sedentary behavior are prominent and persistent among stroke survivors and associated with poor cardiovascular and cardiometabolic health outcomes which elevate the risk for recurrent stroke. Engaging key stakeholders to adapt a promising post-stroke sedentary behavior intervention for remote delivery using telehealth will expand its potential reach. Further, findings from the pilot randomized controlled trial will enable future efficacy trials to advance the development of interventions that can reduce sedentary behavior to improve health outcomes after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Public Health Relevance Of the 3.5 million Americans who suffer from kidney stones each year, 230,000 have large stone volumes that require either invasive surgery, or long-duration endoscopy which incurs high complication rates. To remove stones faster, we propose a new device that transforms almost instantaneously from an endoscope to a steer- able catheter with a large open lumen for suctioning out stone fragments. Success in this research will re- duce operation times, improve stone-free rates, and make many more patients candidates for minimally invasive ureteroscopy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our gut microbes have many well-established effects on our health, but many of the most common gut microbes are only distantly related to typical laboratory model organisms. The proposed research develops quantitative, data-rich approaches to understand how these microbes grow, behave, and interact in different environments. In the future, this line of research could both improve our ability to interpret case-control studies of the microbiome, and lead to more precise, safer therapies that target our microbiome to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Using data drawn from the Adolescent Behavior and Cognitive Development (ABCD) study, this longitudinal study will examine the individual and joint contributions of adverse childhood events and community environments (ACEs) and genetic variation in delay discounting (DD) on the development of DD and subsequent substance use. The proposed study will be one of the most comprehensive investigations of the contextual and genetic determinants of the unfolding of DD across the adolescent years. Findings have the potential to inform the development of novel preventions and interventions aimed at improving DD and negative sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relative to their heterosexual peers, sexual minority women are at heightened risk of developing an eating disorder, which has the highest mortality rate of all psychiatric illnesses. The limited knowledge pertaining to the unique risk factors that contribute to eating disorders among sexual minority women prevents intervention efforts from effectively reducing eating disorder risk in this population and has limited the community resources to rectify the disparity. In partnership with community stakeholders, this proposal will identify salient social and environmental risk factors that contribute to eating disorder behaviors in diverse sexual minority women, which will inform targeted interventions and community resources to diminish disparities in this group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcoholic Hepatitis (AH) is a severe inflammatory disease that causes significant mortality among patients with Alcohol-related liver disease. In this project, we will investigate how the innate immune system and the micro- and myco-biome interact via a family of genes called the C-type lectin receptors (CTLs) to increase inflammation and disease severity among AH patients. The results of this project will expand our understanding of CTLs and immune surveillance, and provide new therapeutic targets for treatment of AH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability of cells to transit through different cellular states underlies many biological processes important for human health and disease. Cells can elicit state transitions by exerting control over gene expression. We propose to interrogate the fundamental mechanisms that modulate one layer of gene expression to drive cell state transitions in order to better understand how these programs function in healthy cells or may be hijacked during disease.

PHR: Project Narrative HIV/AIDS continues to be a major global health issue. AIDS-related death has steadily decreased in recent years, but alarmingly, chronic liver disease has become a major cause of HIV-mortality. Several contributing factors are recognized including hepatotoxicity of anti-HIV drugs and widespread alcohol abuse. The likelihood of concurrent use of other addictive substances is high. The goal of the project is to provide mechanistic details on how these contributing factors interplay, validate biomarkers for efficacy/safety and adherence monitoring, and build strong foundations for developing mitigation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many age-related neurodegenerative diseases—including Alzheimer's disease (AD)—are associated with misfolded protein deposition that promote inflammatory responses, neuronal dysfunction, and cognitive deficits. In this proposal we will address the hypothesis that aging immune cells (in particular, aging T lymphocytes) produce inflammatory molecule, IFN, which interacts with brain-draining lymphatic vessels in the borders of the brain and disrupts their function, subsequently leading to dysfunctional clearance of the brain's waste. We will assess the mechanism and therapeutic approaches to target this route as means to ameliorate Alzheimer's disease progression.

PHR: Project Narrative  The Innate Immunity Training Program proposed here is designed to educate the next generation of biomedical researchers in cutting-edge, high quality science. Innate immunity is of critical importance to several common human diseases including septic shock, heart disease (atherosclerosis), autoimmune diseases, and nearly all infectious diseases. Trainees will receive a comprehensive classroom-based foundation in innate immunity (and allied ﬁelds) upon which their laboratory research experience will build.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Subversion of DNA replication is an essential part of oncogenesis, and mutations in DNA replication proteins cause a variety of diseases (from cancer, to dwarfism, and even neurodegeneration), so it is critical for human health that we gain a complete understanding of how DNA replication works. This proposal will study how DNA replication is normally completed and the replication restart mechanisms that support completion of DNA synthesis. These processes are particularly important to understand because they involve several major tumor suppressors (e.g. BRCA1, BRCA2) and are targeted by chemotherapeutics (e.g. etoposide, olaparib, cisplatin).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: II. Narrative The proposed MADURA R25 Training Program combines thoroughly integrated, culturally relevant, group and individual mentorship experiences, training, outreach activities, professional development support, and paid MSTEM Aging and Alzheimer's disease research placements to UC San Diego Hispanic undergraduates. Its primary objective is to promote improved student academic success and retention in the near term, and subsequently, greater Hispanic inclusion in MSTEM Aging and Alzheimer's disease research, graduate education, and careers. The results, protocols and materials from this rigorously evaluated program will be broadly disseminated, benefitting diversity promotion efforts across aging-focused and broader public health education, research and clinical settings.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Humans are born with a limited pool of oocytes, which remain dormant for decades until they are recruited for ovulation as a fertilizable egg. The longer oocytes persist in this dormant state with increasing maternal age, they lose their competency to undergo embryonic development. This research seeks to better understand how oocytes are maintained in their dormant state, which will inform approaches for human assisted fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV (PLWH) are at the higher risk for impaired cognitive functions due to higher use of legal and illegal opioids that could affect their immune functions and exacerbate CNS (central nervous system) impairment. However, little is known about the HIV harboring cell types in brain, effect of therapy on specific CNS cell types, and the modification of brain functions by opioid use. Results of these innovative single-cell studies will generate cellular part list for brain regions and will illuminate novel insights into transcriptomic and epigenetic landscapes of CNS and how they are altered by HIV and opioid use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (IHC) is a devastating, largely incurable cancer, with a rising worldwide incidence and few effective treatment options. The goals of this research project are to 1) establish the efficacy of hepatic arterial infusion of floxuridine (FUDR) combined with systemic chemotherapy for the treatment of unresectable IHC and 2) to use the unique collection of tissue, blood, and radiographic samples from trial patients to uncover biomarkers of clinical response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Neurodegenerative illnesses such as Parkinson’s (PD) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) affect nearly 15% of adults over age 65, are associated with reductions in patient and caregiver quality of life, and represent two of the leading causes of death in the US. There is an emerging body of research that applying palliative care approaches may help improve the quality of life of patients and families affected by neurodegenerative illnesses by addressing potential causes of suffering including pain, psychosocial issues and spiritual needs. As palliative care approaches are new to the field of neurology the present application is designed to provide necessary training and research experiences to allow the candidate to lead efforts to advance the development, testing, implementation and dissemination of palliative care approaches to improve outcomes for patients and families affected by neurodegenerative illnesses.

PHR: Project Narrative We have found that the DNA sensor cGAS, long thought to be a cytosolic protein, is a tightly tethered nuclear protein that is carefully regulated to prevent detection of self-DNA. We will define how nuclear tethering prevents cGAS autoreactivity and enables it to respond to foreign DNA.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Kinshasa School of Public Health - University of North Carolina Research Partnership is the ideal team to continue as a research unit in the Eunice Kennedy Shriver NICHD Global Network for Women’s and Children’s Health Research. Our overall goal is to discover evidenced-based strategies to improve health outcomes in low and middle-income countries. To achieve this goal, we will: 1) execute high-quality studies with early identification of pregnancies, rigorous tracking of outcomes and follow-up rates >90%, 2) support the Global Network with innovative trials and trial designs, and 3) strengthen research infrastructure in the DRC and develop the next generation of research leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project narrative Despite promising new therapeutics, lung cancer remains a devastating disease and is the top cause of cancer mortality. We and others recently showed that a a protein named SMARCA2 is essential for growth of a subtype of lung cancer and discovered a potent chemical molecule that degrades this protein. In this proposal, we aim to perform in depth biological studies to better understand the mechanism of the growth inhibitory activity of SMARCA2 degradation using chemical biology and genetic approaches as well as explore the therapeutic potential of SMARCA2 degradation by our molecule in such tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have developed new animal models and assays to elucidate the contribution of microtubule disorganization to the pathogenesis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. We have also established state-of-the-art methods to perform the first ever side-by-side mechanical comparison of single dystrophin and utrophin molecules. Our proposed studies will provide new understanding into the functions of dystrophin and utrophin in healthy muscle, and will inform on the potential for miniaturized dystrophins and utrophin to functionally replace full-length dystrophin as therapeutic approaches for Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This project will yield an expected outcome of intelligent OCT imaging technology that can increase the number of healthy kidneys available for transplantation by making the most efficient use of available donor kidneys, eliminate the possible use of bad donor kidneys (i.e., excessively damaged ischemic or diseased kidneys), provide a measure of expected post-transplant renal function, and allow better distinction between post- transplant immunological rejection and ischemic induced acute renal failure. This technology is uniquely suited for transplant kidney, and no alternative is currently available in clinics. Such a technology promises to improve the efficacy of transplantation, enhance the life quality of ESRD patients, and significantly reduce the ESRD healthcare burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and coronary microvascular dysfunction (CMD) are prevalent conditions that predominantly impact women, while no targeted therapies for HFpEF exist. The application will test the hypothesis that chronic CMD-related ischemia results in an intra-cardiomyocyte metabolic shift leading to myocardial steatosis and pre-HFpEF traits using comprehensive cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging, CMR spectroscopy and inflammatory eicosanoid profiling. Understanding the role of cardiac steatosis in CMD and HFpEF promises to reveal novel targets for preventing and treating HFpEF, especially in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The microglia surfaceome serves as a critical cellular hub that enables neuroprotective, neurotoxic, and neuroinflammatory signaling in the diseased brain. The ability to precisely target and manipulate diverse microglia states and function therefore holds tremendous experimental and therapeutic potential. The proposed project will use innovative tools and technologies to mechanistically interrogate and modulate microglia phagocytosis in Alzheimer’s disease and thus holds important therapeutic implications for treating this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with kidney disease suffer major metabolic abnormalities, which can be life-threatening. Part of this effect may be due to so-called uremic toxins. Our studies will help define how a certain drug transporter, OAT1, regulates whole body and organ metabolism in the setting of kidney disease. This could set the stage for new therapies designed to circumvent the loss of OAT1 function in kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Numerous systemic therapies have been approved for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer; while little comparative effectiveness data exists on these therapies, there are substantial price differences. These high drug prices often result in significant patient financial burden with devastating consequences: poor adherence and worse outcomes. The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand the economic and non-economic factors that determine the choice of first-line systemic therapy for advanced prostate cancer, and to design and pilot test an intervention aimed at decreasing patient out-of-pocket payments for prostate cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer is the most common non-skin cancer among men and androgen deprivation therapy is an effective mainstay treatment that has greatly reduced mortality related to primary cancer. However, men who undergo androgen deprivation therapy are more likely to develop hypertension and die from cardiovascular diseases than men who are treated for prostate cancer without the use of androgen deprivation therapy. Therefore, I am seeking to determine the neural and renal contributions to hypertension in men who undergo androgen deprivation therapy, as well as the mechanistic influence of inflammation on these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: The goal of this project is to define the biological fate of low risk (Grade Group 1) prostate cancer in both African and European Americans. This project will allay patient concerns related to disease progression and the presence of co-existing higher-grade cancer—factors that play central roles in the safe and effective implementation of surveillance. Ultimately, findings from this research will enhance patient selection for surveillance and inform how to improve the quality of its implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The studies proposed herein will determine the impact of BCL2, a protein that supports the survival of cancer cells responding to treatment, on the immunological configuration of hormone receptor (HR)+ breast cancer (BC), as well as the therapeutic value of combining radiation therapy (RT) with BCL2 inhibitors in immunocompetent mouse models of HR+ BC. These findings will provide preclinical ground to the initiation of clinical trials testing RT plus venetoclax (a BCL2 inhibitor currently approved by regulatory agencies for use in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia) in women with HR+ BC, a type of BC that still affects >200,000 and kills >25,000 new women every year in the US.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Postpartum hemorrhage occurs when the uterus bleeds excessively after childbirth and is often caused by failure of the uterus to contract properly. This study uses non-invasive genetic biomarkers to determine how well the uterus will respond to oxytocin, a common medication used during childbirth to help uterine contraction and treat hemorrhage. The biomarkers will allow us to develop new ways to predict risk for hemorrhage before birth and design treatments that are more effective, thereby saving mothers’ lives and minimizing long-term health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our recently completed CRISPR screening campaign has revealed the poorly studied phosphatase SCP4 and the kinases STK35/PDIK1L as catalytic vulnerabilities in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). This multi-PI project will take an inter-disciplinary approach to elucidating the upstream and downstream mechanisms and deep biochemical and structural mechanisms of this novel signal transduction pathway that functions as an acquired dependency in AML. Since AML cells are addicted to the catalytic function of this phosphatase-kinase complex, the outcome of this work carries a strong potential to drive the development of novel tool compounds and therapeutics for a malignancy with significant unmet clinical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative NFIA is a critical transcription factor for glial development, astrocyte-neuron network, and astrocyte activation after brain injury. The proposed research will define whether and how the manipulation of astrocytic NFIA is critical for the initiation and progression of Alzheimer's disease through delineating functional relationships between astrocytic genes, cellular signaling, transcriptome analysis, and behaviors of the newly generated AD models. Furthermore, these studies will enhance our knowledge of astrocytic and/or reactive astrocytic mechanisms that may be dysregulated in AD pathogenesis.

With age, oligodendrocytes increasingly produce a mysterious cytokine, interleukin 33 (IL-33), a potent immune regulator in peripheral systems. We will study the role of oligodendrocyte-derived IL-33 in brain aging and Alzheimer's disease-related neuroinflammation with genetically engineered mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are many challenges when determining the presence and severity of joint inflammation by physical examination in children with Juvenile Arthritis. This research will 1) determine if a novel 10-joint musculoskeletal ultrasound score effectively assesses joint inflammation at the bedside, and 2) investigate the relationship of the 10-joint musculoskeletal ultrasound score with serum and synovial biomarkers. It is anticipated that accurate detection of joint inflammation may support safer and more appropriate choices for the treatment of arthritis, which in turn will improve the outcomes and quality of life of children with Juvenile Arthritis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study seeks to design and field Wave 8 of the National Survey of Sexual Health and Behavior (NSSHB), a U.S. nationally representative probability study of individuals ages 14 and over, at a similar time frame as the United Kingdom, France, and Australia in order to facilitate cross-national comparisons. The NSSHB provides population data on sexual health indicators and has consistently tracked sexual, contraceptive, and reproductive behaviors for nearly a decade; new in Wave 8 are opportunities to establish population-representative data on understudied sexual behaviors as well as associations between those behaviors and sexual and reproductive coercion. NSSHB data have implications for informing health policies, education, and sexual health-related services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is no known treatment to heal the human spinal cord once it is damaged; however, recent reports show electrical stimulation at specific locations near the surface of the spinal cord restores functions such as standing and stepping in humans with paralysis from spinal cord injury. Insufficient scientific evidence is available to explain how spinal stimulation interacts with the spinal cord to recover functions, and although the outcomes are promising, prior studies were conducted in a very small number of humans with wide-ranging degrees of paralysis. In order to better understand how spinal stimulation produces functional gains, we will conduct a mechanistic exploratory clinical trial in 32 humans with spinal cord injury that is designed to examine how electrical stimulation affects the signals that enter and exit the spinal cord during spinal stimulation with intense rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cigarette smoking remains one of the leading preventable causes of death and disease in the world. The goal of the proposed project is to develop a better understanding of the psychological and neurobiological factors that contribute to smoking lapses during cessation attempts. Results from the project will provide a foundation for future research aimed at improving the effectiveness of strategies for preventing smoking lapses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons are poorly recognized by the immune system which contributes to the ability of neurotropic pathogens to persist in the CNS. However, there is evidence that T cells can promote clearance of these organisms from neurons, but the basis for this activity is not well understood. The parasite Toxoplasma gondii, has a latent cyst forms that survives in neurons which helps it evade immune surveillance and ensures chronicity. There is a dire need for new therapies for this latent stage. To understand how T. gondii is recognized in neurons and how the parasite can evade surveillance, novel reporter systems for parasites will be used to track the fate of infected neurons in vivo and studies performed to determine if cyst specific responses can help eradicate this pathogen. These studies will have a significant impact on understanding how CD8+ T cell-neuron interactions lead to pathogen control and be relevant to other neurotropic infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertension (HTN) is especially morbid for patients living in underserved urban communities, who experience healthcare-related disparities. The proposed research is relevant to public health by improving HTN treatment and self-management in urban individuals with this common, chronic condition. This proposal expects to empower individuals residing in communities with socioeconomic disadvantage and will provide critical data to develop an acceptable technological tool for HTN self-management.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The goals of the Intellectual and Disabilities Research Center at Boston Children's Hospital and Harvard Medical School are threefold: support outstanding, trans-disciplinary research into the causes of neurodevelopmental disorders, train a diverse next generation of researchers in this field and most importantly develop new therapies for individuals and families affected with these disorders. The Center is composed of four scientific core facilities, each focused on a different level of investigation and complementing each other, ranging from genetics, cellular imaging, animal behavior and physiology to clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methadone is an effective treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD) yet historically the care delivery model requires directly-observed therapy (DOT) at opioid treatment programs which is a barrier to clients. The pandemic initially exacerbated those challenges but ultimately led to the revision of regulations, paving the way for more flexible models of care. Our prior Phase I research demonstrated the feasibility, safety, and acceptability of an innovative mobile health platform to provide asynchronous, video DOT and to screen for symptoms of COVID-19 for patients treated for OUD with methadone; this proposal aims to test the implementation of video direct observe therapy (video-DOT) for methadone across a large, multisite OTP organization via a Hybrid Type 2 Effectiveness Implementation study with stepped wedge cluster randomized trial design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal investigates how mRNAs with early stop codons are repressed. The proposal focuses on the biochemistry and requirements for effectors of the mRNA cleavage step, and the role that ribosomes and the protein UPF1 have in mRNA targeting. Results from this work will illuminate mechanisms of translation and mRNA degradation for a class of genetic mutations (early stop codons) present in a substantial fraction (~11%) of disease-causing alleles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are different types of non-bleeding strokes and identifying the correct cause of a stroke, for example a stroke secondary to heart disease, is critical in the proper treatment of patients. In many cases, a clear source of the stroke is not recognized and this may be due to inadequate evaluation of heart function. More advanced, focused imaging of the heart may provide the necessary information to critically guide future patient care, in order to prevent recurrent strokes and poor patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: At a time of unprecedented, forced migration coupled with limited access to mental health resources, this K01 application focuses on developing skills and knowledge needed to adapt, scale up and sustain community- based mental health prevention and care interventions for refugees across the displacement continuum. The proposed study will advance the field by integrating human-centered design and implementation science to adapt and deliver a multiple family group intervention that responds to the multi-level needs of refugees and has high likelihood of adoption, and impact. The candidate’s expertise in these methods will contribute to improving access to care for refugees and war-affected populations in the U.S. and globally with implications for U.S. military families as well as trauma-affected communities impacted by mental health disparities in the U.S. and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer screening with annual low-dose chest CT is effective at reducing lung cancer mortality in high-risk current and former smokers; however, the mortality benefits of screening may be limited by poor adherence to annual follow-up after negative or positive lung cancer screens. The proposed research will address this implementation gap by identifying barriers and facilitators to screening follow-up in community settings and adapting and evaluating evidence-based interventions to support screening follow-up at diverse community partner sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Involuntary weight loss, anorexia, fatigue, and exercise intolerance are common in patients with cancer. New research demonstrates that these problems limit quality of life for many patients, and also are a significant contributor to risk of death. Our studies are designed to investigate the ways in which cancer leads to these disabling changes in behavior and metabolism to better understand how this might be treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite their lack of a fixed structure, disordered proteins have emerged as central drivers of biological function, with key roles in cell signaling, transcription, and genome organization, all of which contribute to diseases ranging from viral infections to cancer. Although clear examples in which disordered proteins are essential for disease progression exist, our understanding of the role of intrinsically disordered regions in disease etiology is limited. This proposal will study disordered protein-nucleic acid interactions in SARS-CoV-2 and in the context of cancer using a collection of single- molecule techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medicare’s Merit-based Incentive Payment System (MIPS) is a value-based payment model designed to improve healthcare value by adjusting clinician payments based on cost and quality measures, including recently introduced patient-reported outcome measures. This study aims to evaluate the impact of MIPS on heart failure care by determining the effect of routine patient-reported outcome assessment on heart failure quality of life, and evaluating the association between MIPS and heart failure therapy patterns, mortality and cost. These findings will impact heart failure treatment and patient outcomes by guiding policy-makers in the design of future value-based payment models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite being the most common muscle disease after the age of 50, inclusion body myositis (IBM) remains of unclear etiology and refractory to any form of treatment, with almost all patients eventually becoming wheelchair dependent. Herein, we propose that the mitochondria play a primary role in IBM, and we plan on evaluating the mitochondrial function by a series of very innovative techniques. Our proposal has the potential to clarify underlying disease mechanisms, and identify new diagnostic tools and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone metastatic prostate cancer is currently incurable, and patients typically survive only 2-3 years after diagnosis. Standard of care androgen-targeted therapy drives cancer resistance and immune evasion, contributing to cancer recurrence. This proposal aims to utilize neutrophils, the most abundant bone immune cell, as a candidate target for enhancing current therapies through neutrophil-driven anti-tumor immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is an aging disorder that can harm thinking, memory, movements, sleep, and behavior. Because it is difficult to diagnose DLB, particularly early in its disease course, many individuals with DLB experience long delays in receiving a diagnosis, which then delays interventions and causes significant caregiver burden. To address these delays, this study will investigate wearable technologies and standard clinical observations that together have the potential to improve the diagnosis of early DLB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Integrase (IN) Strand Transfer Inhibitors (INSTIs) are first-line therapeutics used to treat people living with HIV/AIDS, which work by blocking integration of viral DNA into host chromosomes through inhibition of the HIV intasome nucleoprotein assembly, but the emergence of IN variants resistant to INSTIs is becoming a greater clinical problem. This work will make use of structural biology and complementary enzymological, biophysical, virological, and computational approaches to define mechanisms of HIV drug resistance against the latest clinically used INSTIs, identify and characterize patterns and pathways through which clinically relevant resistance arises, synthesize potent third generation INSTIs based on the concept of substrate mimicry, and use our collective tools to mechanistically explain drug potency against viral resistant variants. The results of this work will improve our understanding of this important class of drugs used to treat people living with HIV, identify mechanisms, pathways, and patterns of clinically relevant resistance to INSTIs, and suggest specific guidelines for their rational improvement, thus providing realistic strategies for combatting drug resistance to HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular interventions used to treat severe atherosclerosis often fail due to the development of arterial restenosis secondary to neointimal hyperplasia. The overall goal of this proposal is to develop a novel, targeted, drug-releasing nanotherapeutic that will be administered intravenously yet localize specifically to the site of injury to prevent neointimal hyperplasia following vascular interventions in an atherosclerotic environment. Completion of these studies will position us well to start pre-IND meetings with the FDA to begin first-in-human testing with the ultimate goal to improve human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social deficits occur across a wide array of neuropsychiatric (NPD) and neurodevelopmental (NDD) disorders, persist over time, and contribute to poor outcomes and considerable public health costs. The Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) initiative operationalizes an initial set of basic, biologically meaningful components that underpin social functioning and can be used to better understand mechanisms behind social deficits seen across NPD/NDD and inform personalization of treatments. The proposed projects aims to refine and stringently validate a new quantitative comprehensive parent-report measure of key RDoC Social Processes constructs and subconstructs with the hope of unlocking etiological and treatment-oriented research in social deficits across NPD and NDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug-resistant tuberculosis (TB) remains an important threat to global public health. Early identification, at the critical juncture between outbreak and epidemic, can prevent disease and deaths due to drug-resistant TB infections. In this project, we use genetic data from TB infections and data on human mobility to advance new strategies for early detection and containment of emerging strains of drug-resistant TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a novel digital phenotyping approach using deep learning to identify objective digital biomarkers from video-recorded interviews to predict posttraumatic stress disorder risk after Emergency Department (ED) discharge to better target early interventions and reduce delayed treatment. We will determine how candidate digital biomarkers that are designed for practical feasibility under the demanding acute care priorities in the ED add to the prognostic value of psychometric assessments and electronic health records. The proposal contributes to the NIMH’s mission aiming to “enable practical, scalable, and sustainable mental health screening and triage, and providing interventions at scale”.1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This K99/R00 application describes a mentoring strategy for Dr. Benjamin Freedman to gain the necessary aging biology, biomaterials, and drug delivery skill set to develop and evaluate a new cell delivery approach to augment tendon. With increased participation in recreational activities and sport, and a more active aging population, the incidence of acute and chronic tendon injuries is rising. In this project, we will develop and examine how biomaterials can dynamically recruit, expand, and release cells in vivo, which will yield improved cell delivery strategies for tendon injuries throughout aging and have broad applications to other tissues and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in three children in the US experience early life stress such as abuse, neglect, and household dysfunction, which puts them at greater risk of cardiovascular disease later in life. The gut microbiota are known to produce metabolites that mediate cardiovascular function. This project seeks to determine how early life stress induced changes in gut microbial composition and metabolic function leads to increased risk of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative. Coccidioidomycosis is a significant source of morbidity, mortality and cost within endemic regions. Disease presentation can range from asymptomatic to life threatening disseminated disease in immunocompromised individuals. It is also estimated that between 15%- 30% of community acquired pneumonia is attributable to coccidioidomycosis within endemic regions. Those on immunosuppressive therapies, such as those receiving organ transplants, are at risk for severe Coccidioides infections. The development of an ex vivo cytokine release assay has several potential benefits to aid in the diagnosis, management and distribution of coccidioidomycosis. It could be used to test for previous infection in populations or in individuals. This use could help establish prevalence in geographic areas and determining the measures to take before beginning immunosuppressive therapy. The test could also have prognostic value, as development of a lasting cellular immune response has been associated with positive outcomes. The presence or absence of an adaptive cellular immune response and the ability to reliably monitor it will be critical to the development and monitoring of individuals that will receive a future coccidioidomycosis vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We previously showed that normal plasma cells and cancerous multiple myeloma (MM) cells, have abundant, inefficient immunoglobulin synthesis and impaired protein degradation, resulting in accumulation of polyubiquitinated proteins and proteotoxic stress. We recently discovered that critical depletion of ubiquitin, a small protein necessary for both protein degradation and DNA repair, occurs during B lymphocyte differentiation. We hypothesize that functional ubiquitin depletion during B cell differentiation is a novel cancer-causing mechanism by impairing DNA repair, paving the way for development of innovative therapies in MM and potentially other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Recent exciting developments in psychiatry and neuroscience hold great promise for our understanding of the causes and treatments for mental illness. However, a critical shortage of physician-scientists limits our ability to advance this science and translate discoveries into effective prevention and treatment strategies. This application seeks to continue support for a psychiatry residency research training program that aims to increase the number of physician-scientists conducting innovative and rigorous research on the causes and treatment of psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative of CARE 2.0 This project will implement CARE 2.0, an extension of the ongoing CARE (Collaborative Approach for Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians & Pacific Islanders (AANHPI) Research and Education) registry, launched in October 2020 to improve representation of AANHPI groups in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Disorders (ADRD), aging, and caregiving research. As a critical next step, CARE 2.0 will 1) strategically expand the registry in the US with emphasis to increase enrollment of AANHPI groups underrepresented in CARE 1.0 and examine registry participants’ research attitudes in participation in health research; 2) examine and develop methods to improve registry retention; and 3) optimize CARE registry participants’ inclusion in ADRD, aging, and caregiving research and examine the factors associated with research enrollment decisions by registry participants. To our knowledge, CARE is the only US multi- lingual registry with a focus on supporting ADRD, aging, and caregiving related research for AANHPI populations and will be uniquely positioned to improve representation of AANHPI groups in research while also advancing the science of recruitment and retention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood abuse and trauma (early life stress) impacts disease and health later in life by increasing risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) and autoimmunity. Systemic Lupus Erythamateous (SLE), an autoimmune disease, has high CVD burden and poor outcomes in patients with ELS. This project will examine the potential cause for increased CVD risk in ELS by examining the observed prevalence of macrophages, an immune cell mediator of vascular maintenance, and by examining CVD risk markers in conjunction with mitochondrial derived superoxide in a model of SLE with or without ELS exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uncontrolled inflammation, arising from abnormal anti-inflammatory T lymphocytes (T regulatory cells, Tregs), is implicated in a lethal cardiopulmonary condition called pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). This proposal seeks to understand how genetic risk factors and environmental triggers provoke Treg defects in PAH. By testing whether restoring Treg immunity reverses established PAH in experimental models, this proposal provides the foundational science to guide the design of a novel cell-based therapy for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with common cancers in the United States receive surgical care within health systems, but quality is inconsistent across system hub and spoke sites. This project will evaluate the effect of treatment in a health system hub or spoke on receipt of evidence-based surgical cancer care and will identify health system characteristics and strategies that are associated with system performance and consistency across sites. The product, an intervention map for system-level implementation of oncologic evidence, can be used by health systems to provide consistent, high-quality care across sites, increasing equity in cancer care delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative.  Chronic renovascular disease can deteriorate renal function leading to chronic kidney disease and the need for dialysis, and it increases the risk of heart attacks, strokes, and death. Current treatment for renovascular disease involving renal angioplasty and stenting combined with anti-angiotensin agents and statins are ineffective in up to half of the patients. The goal of this Phase II STTR is to extend efficacy and safety studies completed in Phase I using a biopolymer-stabilized vascular endothelial growth factor to recover the kidney microvascular density and function, including performing cGMP manufacturing; GLP toxicology in rats, minipigs, and beagles; and extended efficacy testing in multiple chronic kidney disease models of varying etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal exposures to inorganic arsenic have been shown to modulate offspring lung function, but less is known about how early-life exposure to arsenic promotes respiratory diseases like asthma. This research will examine the effect of maternal arsenic exposures on placenta function and offspring lung development over the adult life course. The completion of this research will allow the field for a better understanding of the impact of environmental arsenic exposure on women and children’s health, that inform strategies to prevent or reduce adverse respiratory health in affected communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer mortality in women world-wide. The goal of this proposal is to understand intratumor heterogeneity, a major driver of tumor progression and therapeutic failure responsible for patient deaths, by applying multidisciplinary approaches in experimental and clinical breast cancer. I expect that the new insights gained will lead to new, more effective individualized treatment strategies.
