IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease with an unknown cause or cure that most commonly affects the lungs, but it can also affect almost any other organ. A significant obstacle to successfully managing sarcoidosis patients is our inability to identify individual patients at greater risk for poor disease outcomes. By investigating immune cells and signaling proteins related to sarcoidosis inflammation, I hope to 1) determine their immunologic properties, and 2) understand their potential as biologic markers for clinical outcomes in the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) with genetic alterations in the KRAS oncogene is the most common lung cancer diagnosed in smokers, and strategies to intercept this ominous malignancy heavily rest on understanding the earliest events in its development. While it is understood that tobacco carcinogen exposure results in widespread injury in the lung in the form of molecular and inflammatory changes that commence in visually normal cells, we still poorly understand how KRAS-mutant LUAD is conceived from the tobacco-exposed lung. This project will discern how a unique population of lung cells that arise following tobacco exposure evolve to premalignancy and KRAS-mutant LUAD, discern mechanisms that promote their oncogenic progression, as well as identify drugs that can target these cells and prevent development of KRAS-mutant LUAD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Training Program will provide support for MD and PhD trainees to work with a collaborative group of senior scientists, conducting medically-relevant research to address important questions in pulmonary and critical care medicine. Through a combination of a mentored research experience and select graduate-level courses, trainees will be prepared to pursue the new biology of pulmonary and critical care medicine for the future, working as part of collaborative teams linking basic and clinic research to bring new discoveries to the care of patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Female infertility due to disorders of androgen imbalance, namely polycystic ovary syndrome and ovarian insufficiency, are a growing public health problem in the U.S. and worldwide. This project aims to delineate the mechanisms of androgen actions in the ovary, focusing on novel non-coding RNA regulation by androgen receptor in granulosa cells and the role of cytoplasmic adaptor protein paxillin. The training plan is designed to groom a young physician-scientist for an independent career in reproductive science, and the findings will advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying female fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The elimination of cervical cancer as a public health disease requires the adoption and implementation of strategies that are easily accessible, affordable, acceptable and are equally efficacious in women living with HIV. Hence, we will study the safety and acceptability of a novel formulation of a combination protease inhibitor (Lopinavir/Ritonavir) developed as a self- administered vaginal capsule for use as treatment or an adjunct to treatment for women who screen VIA positive, a surrogate for cervical precancer. Additionally, we seek to establish pilot efficacy data in support of implementing a large-scale clinical trial of this innovative approach to secondary cervical cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is a novel, asymptomatic condition that predisposes to the development both leukemia and cardiovascular disease; however, while CHIP appears to be quite common, the mechanisms underlying its pathogenesis are not well understood. This study will investigate the contributions of inflammatory pathways and hematopoietic lineages to CHIP-associated cardiovascular disease and their potential as therapeutic targets. The development of innovative therapies targeting these pathways may enable the treatment of established CHIP-associated cardiovascular disease, which would significantly improve the clinical outcomes of patients with CHIP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The tumor suppressor p53 is essential in the prevention of human cancers, and its loss of function leads to tumor initiation and progression. Half of all human cancers have inactivated p53 by mutation or deletion, which results in aberrant aggressive growth. Our proposal focuses on the development of novel Mdm2 degraders to activate p53-independent activities of Mdm2 as an improved therapeutic approach against these aggressive tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There has been tremendous excitement for the therapeutic potential of iPS cells in treating genetic diseases. The intent of this grant is to perform preclinical studies with cGMP-compatible pluripotent stem cell-derived myogenic progenitors in nonhuman primates (NHPs) as well as to determine for the first time the impact of HLA mismatch in muscle engraftment through the transplantation of allogeneic and autologous cells using the NHP system. This cell therapy has the potential to provide long-term therapeutic effect in DMD, as well as other devastating types of muscular dystrophies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is prevalent in the world with a 5-year survival rate around 18%. Using human cells and animal models, we will characterize the molecular consequences of NRF2 hyperactivation in ESCC, determine the mechanisms of action and efficacy of NRF2 inhibitors, and find NRF2- responsive kinases and their functions in NRF2-driven ESCC biology. If successful, this work will help develop targeted therapy of NRF2high ESCC in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE The majority of persons with HIV (PWH) in the US consume alcohol, despite that alcohol use is associated with lower levels of HIV care engagement and HIV viral suppression. The overarching goals of the current grant proposal are to advance understanding of the mechanisms influencing adherence to contemporary HIV therapeutic regimens, and to incorporate alcohol-related interventions into emerging clinic- and community- based strategies to achieve and maintain HIV viral suppression across diverse populations. The rich information we collect in this project will establish a solid foundation for our next step: a hybrid implementation/effectiveness trial of an integrated alcohol intervention across a large network of clinic- /community-based HIV settings in Florida.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bridges to Baccalaureate in Portland Metro (B2B PDX Metro) will build on past collaborations among Portland Community College, Clackamas Community College, and Portland State University to increase the number of diverse community college students who transfer to four-year universities in biomedical science majors. To achieve this, the investigators will rely on evidence-based approaches, including hands-on learning; research experiences; and an integrated and supportive community of mentors, faculty, and peers at the institutions. This research responds to the Public Health Service Act (Section 304 (242b) by “providing for an expanded and continuing supply of individuals qualified to perform the research, evaluation, and demonstration projects” that contribute to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability to trace, distinguish, and quantify different oxidation states of the same redox active metal ion (RAMI) simultaneously in vivo is critical in understanding the labile cellular pool, which a fundamental role in diseases arising from homeostatic imbalances. DNAzymes offer a promising method of accomplishing this, but our current gap in knowledge regarding metal ion-DNAzyme interactions precludes our ability to finely tune their sensing capabilities. This work will make significant contributions to healthcare by improving our fundamental understanding of the interactions of DNAzymes with RAMIs, specifically Fe3+, Fe2+, Cu2+, and Cu+, providing the insight necessary to develop these systems into highly sensitive and selective metal ion sensors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RESEARCH STRATEGY Oligonucleotide agonists of the retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) pathway hold significant promise as antiviral agents, vaccine adjuvants, and cancer immunotherapeutics. However, their biological activity and efficacy is limited by poor pharmacological properties, including nuclease degradation, inefficient cellular uptake and cytosolic delivery, and rapid clearance. This proposal aims to address these challenges through the development, optimization, and preclinical evaluation of RIG-I activating nanoparticles (RANs), a platform technology for immunopotentiation via the RIG-I pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: In this project we are proposing comprehensive, highly synergistic, and rigorously controlled studies that will allow to address, directly in vivo, how the size and relative distribution of the HIV reservoir in CD4 T cells and macrophages govern viral persistence on ART, the extent of residual inflammation and neuropathogenesis, as well as viral rebound after ART interruption. We believe our studies will provide critical insights into the mechanisms that govern the cellular and anatomic origins of persisting and rebounding virus. We hope that these insights ultimately will inform the design of novel therapeutic strategies aimed at achieving HIV remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative (Relevance) Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest cancers and effective therapies are lacking. We have developed a vaccine-based immunotherapy approach to target the Anterior Gradient-2 (AGR2) protein, which is highly  expressed in pancreatic tumors. Our strategy relies on utilizing AGR2 conjugated to the bacterial superantigen  (SAg) SMEZ-2 that activates a robust anti-AGR2 immune response. We anticipate that these studies will reveal  new ways of treating pancreatic cancer in preclinical models of cancer, setting the stage for clinical development  and the delivery of a new treatment regimen to patients in need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The studies described in this application use translational mouse models of chronic low back pain and osteoarthritic knee pain, in conjunction with patient serum and tissue samples, to advance our understanding of the adaptive immune changes mediating the transition from tissue injury to chronic localized pain. It is anticipated that these investigations will provide foundational support for future clinical trials utilizing rituximab, avacopan, and other FDA approved treatments for autoimmune diseases. The identification of novel target specific pharmacologic treatments for these chronic musculoskeletal diseases could reduce pain and enhance the quality of life in many patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public health relevance: The mortality associated with rheumatoid arthritis associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD) is unacceptably high and clinicians are unable to accurately predict prognosis for a disease that is markedly heterogeneous. The overall goal of the proposed research is to identify patients with RA-ILD that are at the highest risk for progressive disease and may potentially benefit from more targeted, and potentially less harmful, treatment. Our proposed research focuses on a critical unmet public health need in RA-ILD by contributing to the fundamental understanding of identification of clinically meaningful disease phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is among the most prevalent causes of years lived with disability among adults worldwide. While antibiotics use may be part of periodontitis treatments based on empirical notions, there are currently no guidelines for periodontal treatment adjunctive antibiotics, which may lead to antibiotic misuse and lack of efficacy. This project will yield reliable clinical and patient-perceived data on the efficacy of periodontal adjunctive antibiotics, which will be translated to evidence-based clinical guidelines for their use only when they are expected to be effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Southern Africa faces numerous public health challenges due to the high prevalence of communicable and non- communicable diseases. For this reason, innovative public health research, such as data science (or ‘big data’) approaches, are crucial to promote population health and reduce health inequality. The Research for Ethical Data Science in Southern Africa (REDSSA) project will explore the ethical, legal and social implications of the Harnessing Data Science for Health Discovery and Innovation in Africa (DS-I Africa) initiative by conducting empirical, conceptual and normative research, and developing contextualized evidence-based guidance with the overall aim of enhancing the governance of data science research for health promotion in southern Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single-cell proteome profiling promises to greatly benefit cancer research by providing insights into the tumor microenvironment, interactions between tumor cell types and specific responses to cancer therapies that cannot be determined using bulk measurements. While unbiased single-cell proteomics (SCP) has advanced rapidly in recent years, the sensitivity, throughput and quantitative performance of these measurements must dramatically improve to have a transformative impact on biomedical research. We will develop a novel platform for multiplexed SCP that quantifies >2000 proteins/cell at an unprecedented measurement throughput of >1000 cells/day.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Persons with pre-diabetes and type 2 diabetes, females, and Hispanics are important risk groups for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) addressed in this proposal. Our proposal addresses several focus areas and milestones of the National Institute on Aging (NIA) AD + AD and related dementias (ADRD) Research Implementation Milestones including Population Studies, Precision Medicine and Health Disparities (milestones 1A,1C), Disease Mechanisms (2D, 2S), and Biomarkers and Diagnosis (9G).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The study of Bb transmission dynamics has been foundational for understanding the emergence of LD and other tick-borne diseases. This work will comprehensively expand this foundation by incorporating myriad effects of the tick microbiome to improve understanding of the Bb enzootic transmission cycle, which, in turn, directly informs LD risk. The conceptual and quantitative frameworks developed will be foundational for microbiome-informed vector-borne disease modeling in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Cytotoxic lymphocytes, which are critical for immune responses against viruses and cancer, kill infected or transformed target cells via specialized cell-cell contacts known as cytolytic immune synapses. This proposal seeks to understand how the dynamic physical activity of the cytolytic synapse and the mechanical properties of the lymphocyte and target cell contribute to the killing response. Understanding the biophysical basis of cytotoxic lymphocyte function could aid immunotherapeutic efforts to fight cancer and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The safe and effective treatment of alcohol abuse disorder (AUD), for which less effective FDA-approved medications currently exist, poses a major public health challenge in the United States. AM6527 is a CB1 neutral antagonist that has displayed its therapeutic value in relevant animal models, with a markedly reduced side-effect profile compared to previously known CB1 receptor inverse agonists. We now propose to advance AM6527 using the U01 mechanism toward IND-enabling studies for treating AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood-forming stem cells in the bone marrow regenerate blood and immune cells throughout life. Defects in stem cell maintenance lead to anemia, impaired immunity and leukemia, but the underlying cause of these defects in some human blood disorders are unknown. This proposal will examine if blood-forming stem cell maintenance and function are impaired by mutations in tRNAs, which are key molecules that support protein production.
